Authors: Weick B.L., Bhushan B.
Title: The relationship between dynamic mechanical behavior, transverse curvature, and wear of magnetic tapes
Affiliations: Comp. Microtribology C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, 206 W. 18th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210-1107, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weick, B.L., Comp. Microtribology C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, 206 W. 18th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210-1107, United States; Bhushan, B., Comp. Microtribology C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, 206 W. 18th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210-1107, United States
Abstract: Dynamic mechanical measurements of the viscoelastic behavior of magnetic tapes and substrates are presented. Five types of tapes were analyzed including three polyethylene terephthalate (PET) tapes with metal particulate, barium ferrite particulate, and metal-evaporated coatings. A polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) tape with a barium ferrite particulate coating was also analyzed along with an aromatic polyamide (ARAMID) tape with a metal-evaporated coating. From the dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), the storage (or elastic) modulus, E′, was obtained as a function of temperature and frequency along with the loss tangent, tan δ, which is a measurement of viscous energy dissipation. Frequency-temperature superposition was used to predict the dynamic mechanical behavior of the tapes and substrates over a 10-12 decade frequency range. Results show that the advanced PEN and ARAMID tapes tend to have higher storage moduli than the PET tapes, and the PET tapes are more susceptible to non-recoverable deformation at higher frequencies due to their higher loss tangents. Also, storage moduli for the tapes are typically higher than those for the substrates, due to the role that the particulate or metal-evaporated coatings play in increasing the overall modulus of the tapes. Tapes with particulate coatings have somewhat higher loss tangents than their constitutive substrates, whereas ultra-thin metal-evaporated coatings contribute little to the loss tangent behavior of a tape. The DMA data is used in a model to predict the resistance of a tape to transverse curvature when tension is applied. Transverse curvature of a magnetic tape is related to higher edge wear of a head. To facilitate the prediction of edge wear and enable the design of better magnetic tapes, a technique is presented which can be used to predict transverse curvature from the elastic moduli, substrate orthotropy ratios, and thicknesses of the substrates and coatings.
Author Keywords: Composite; DMA; Modulus; Polymer; Tribology; Viscoelasticity
Index Keywords: Bending (deformation); Coatings; Elastic moduli; Frequencies; Mathematical models; Polyethylene terephthalates; Polymers; Substrates; Temperature; Tribology; Viscoelasticity; Wear of materials; Aromatic polyamides; Dynamic mechanical analysis; Frequency temperature superposition; Orthotropy; Polyethylene naphthalate; Storage moduli; Transverse curvature; Magnetic tape; magnetic tapes; wear

Authors: Wittels P., Gunga H.-Chr., Kirsch K., Kanduth B., Günther Th., Vormann J., Röcker L.
Title: Fluid regulation during prolonged physical strain with water and food deprivation in healthy, trained men
Affiliations: Spezialabteilung F. L., Heeresspital, Wien, Austria; Physiologisches Institut; Inst. F. Molekularbiologie Biochem., Freie Universität Berlin, Germany; Spezialabteilung F. L., Heeresspital Wien, Brünner Straße 238, A-1210 Wien, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Wittels, P., Spezialabteilung F. L., Heeresspital, Wien, Austria, Spezialabteilung F. L., Heeresspital Wien, Brünner Straße 238, A-1210 Wien, Austria; Gunga, H.-Chr., Physiologisches Institut; Kirsch, K., Physiologisches Institut; Kanduth, B., Spezialabteilung F. L., Heeresspital, Wien, Austria; Günther, Th., Inst. F. Molekularbiologie Biochem., Freie Universität Berlin, Germany; Vormann, J., Inst. F. Molekularbiologie Biochem., Freie Universität Berlin, Germany; Röcker, L., Physiologisches Institut
Abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate fluid-regulating mechanisms, with special regard to the role of plasma proteins in the control of plasma volume (PV), and the role of the superficial tissues as a water storage organ of the body during prolonged physical strain. 29 male subjects (mean age 22.2 ± 2.8 years) were studied during a 5 day period of survival training with multifactorial strain including restricted water intake (11 H2O·day-1) and food intake (628 kJ·day-1) additionally to physical exercise and sleep deprivation (20 h within 5 days). Under field conditions the heart rate was monitored continuously, and body mass, body composition, thickness of the shell tissues, and blood parameters were measured at (T1), after 72 h (T2), after 120 h (T3) and in the recovery period after 48 h (T4) and 72 h (T5). The estimated energy expenditure was approximately 24,000 kJ·day-1. The mean decrease of body mass was 6.77 kg (9.5%) at T3 (p < 0.001), 0.95 kg (1.3%) at T4 (p < 0.05) and 0.68 kg (0.9%) at T5 (n.s.). A reduction of total body water of 3.8l was estimated at T3. Serum creatinine ([Cr]) was raised at T3 by 18.5% (p < 0.0001). No relationship was found between [Cr] and other parameters. The PV decreased by 3.7% (p < 0.0001) at T2, increased by 1.6% (p < 0.0001) at T3 and was not different to baseline at T4 (+0.2%; n.s.). Total protein concentration ([TP]) increased at T2 (11.7%; p < 0.0001) and T3 (2.6%; p < 0.01), and decreased (p < 0.0001) at T4 (8.2%) and T5 (5.7%). Plasma proteins shifted into the intravascular space at T2 and T3 and moved out of the intravascular space at T4 and T5. This gives support to the hypothesis that one of the counterregulatory mechanisms maintaining PV during prolonged exercise is provided by protein shifts from the extravascular into the intravascular space. Our data provide evidence that this mechanism assists PV homeostasis efficiently over a period of 120 h with multifactorial strain, even under conditions with a fluid loss of almost 8% of the total body water.
Author Keywords: dehydration; fasting; fluid regulation; physical strain; plasma proteins

Title: Protection by Carolina rinse solution, acidotic pH, and glycine against lethal reperfusion injury to sinusoidal endothelial cells of rat livers stored for transplantation

Abstract: The critical injury causing graft failure after prolonged liver storage involves reperfusion-induced killing of sinusoidal endothelial cells and activation of Kupffer cells. Treatment of stored livers with Carolina rinse solution (CRS) prevents endothelial cell killing, reduces Kupffer cell activation, and improves graft survival. Accordingly, our aim was to evaluate the components of CRS and other agents for protection against reperfusion injury to rat livers stored 24 hr in University of Wisconsin solution. CHS virtually abolished endothelial cell killing, prevented denudation of the sinusoidal lining, and decreased structural changes in Kupffer cells indicative of activation. The only component of CRS preventing endothelial cell killing was acidic pH of 6.5. However, when pH was subsequently increased to 7.4, antioxldants (allopurinol, deferoxamine mesylate, and glutathione), vasodilators (adenosine and nicardipine), and possibly energy substrates (fructose, glucose, and insulin) partially blocked pH-dependent cell killing (pH paradox). Na+/H+ exchange inhibition, protease inhibition, and Ca2+-free buffer did not decrease reperfusion injury, but the amino acid glycine protected strongly. Strychnine, which binds to glycine receptors in the central nervous system, protected equally well. Protection by glycine and CRS was synergistic, virtually eliminating cell killing after 48 hr of storage. Unlike CRS and some of its components (adenosine and Ca2+ channel blocker), glycine did not block tumor necrosis factor-α release by cultured rat Kupffer cells, although gabexate mesylate, a protease inhibitor, strongly blocked tumor necrosis factor-α release. In conclusion, the combination of CRS and glycine enhanced protection against reperfusion injury to stored livers and may prove beneficial in improving graft function and survival after liver transplantation.

Abstract: The mechanism of slip and its consequence in the process of energy storage during uniaxial tension of austenitic steel was studied. The interpretation of the energy storage process in terms of the slip development and microscopic shear band formation is presented.

Authors: Podczeck F., Newton J.M., James M.B.
Title: The influence of constant and changing relative humidity of the air on the autoadhesion force between pharmaceutical powder particles
Affiliations: Department of Pharmaceutics, School of Pharmacy, University of London, 29/39 Brunswick Square, London WCIN 1AX, United Kingdom; Glaxo Wellcome R. and D. Ltd., Parkroad, Ware SG12 0DP, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Podczeck, F., Department of Pharmaceutics, School of Pharmacy, University of London, 29/39 Brunswick Square, London WCIN 1AX, United Kingdom; Newton, J.M., Department of Pharmaceutics, School of Pharmacy, University of London, 29/39 Brunswick Square, London WCIN 1AX, United Kingdom; James, M.B., Glaxo Wellcome R. and D. Ltd., Parkroad, Ware SG12 0DP, United Kingdom
Abstract: The influence of the press-on force appled and the relative humidity of the air during the storage of autoadhesion samples made from lactose monohydrate or salmeterol xinafoate has been studied using the centrifuge technique. Capillary forces can be obtained for lactose monohydrate if subjected to a relative humidity of 75% or more. The resulting strong autoadhesion forces are reversible by subsequently storing the autoadhesion samples at. low humidity environment. The strength of the capillary forces depends on the storage time, and to reach an equilibrium level requires more than 72 h. For the less polar salmeterol xinafoate the performance of capillary forces could not be proved with certainty, It appears that a very small increase in autoadhesion force at higher relative humidity levels is more likely caused by adsorbed water acting as a plasticizer. Model calculations of capillary forces did not prove successful in predicting the autoadhesion force of the materials if stored at a high relative humidity of the air. The knowledge of the surface free energy and its polar component gave a better basis for a prediction.

Authors: Spodaryk K., Czekaj J., Sowa W.
Title: Relationship among reduced level of stored iron and dietary iron in trained women
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, Academy of Physical Education, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland; Medical College, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland; Department of Physiology, Academy of Physical Education, Al. Jana Pawla II 78, Cracow, Poland

Jana Pawla II 78, Cracow, Poland; Czekaj, J., Medical College, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland; Sowa, W., Medical College, Jagiellonian University, Cracow, Poland
Abstract: The aim of the study was to assess the relationship between dietary iron intake (both haeme- and non-haeme-iron) and its status in trained female subjects. Forty female athletes and forty non-trained women of the same age participated in this study. Blood samples were taken to assess haematological (red blood cell count - Er, haemoglobin concentration - Hb, packed cell volume - PCV) and iron related parameters (serum ferritin concentration - SE, serum iron concentration - SI, total iron binding capacity - TIBC). A self questionnaire was used to record food intake for seven days and diets were analyzed on the basis of mean daily nutrient intake, energy values, iron intake and sources of dietary iron. According to established clinical criteria for iron deficiency some athletes and control subjects have shown iron depletion (20% and 10%, respectively), iron deficiency erythropoiesis (10% and 7.5%, respectively) and iron-deficient anaemia (10% and 7.5%, respectively). There was no difference in the mean total dietary iron intake between the two female groups, while the mean intake of haeme-iron was significantly lower in the control group. The findings in the present study are: (1) the significant relation exists between serum ferritin level and quantity of haeme-iron intake (but not with total iron intake), and (2) 10% of female athletes have iron deficiency.
Author Keywords: anaemia; athletes; ferritin; iron intake

Authors: Sills H., Brown P.
Title: Design of a propylene storage facility
Affiliations: Stevens Institute of Technology, United States; Dept. of Chem. Sci. and Engineering, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sills, H., Stevens Institute of Technology, United States, Dept. of Chem. Sci. and Engineering, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, NJ, United States; Brown, P., Stevens Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Problems faced by senior design students in designing a propylene storage facility are discussed. Some of the main problems faced by students are mass and energy balances, sizing of heat exchangers, separators and adiabatic flash valves. A degrees of freedom analysis revealed that there is only one degree of freedom making thin an open ended problem. Students used CACHE software to determine temperature and solve other problems. The students integrated the concepts and had an experience of writing a formal report and progress reports.

Authors: Simonen F.A., Scott K.V., Pfluger D.C.
Title: Acceptance criteria for ultrasonic flaw indications in the inner liner of double-shell waste storage tanks
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Pac. Northwest Natl. Laboratory, Battelle Memorial Institute, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Westinghouse Hanford Company, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simonen, F.A., Pac. Northwest Natl. Laboratory, Battelle Memorial Institute, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Scott, K.V., Westinghouse Hanford Company, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Pfluger, D.C., Westinghouse Hanford Company, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Abstract: Radioactive defense waste, resulting from the chemical processing of spent nuclear fuel, has been stored in double-shell tanks (DSTs) at the Hanford Site since 1970. As part of the program to assure that the DSTs maintain their structural integrity, an inspection plan is being developed and implemented. This paper describes the technical bases for acceptance criteria for flaw indications detected during ultrasonic inspection of inner liners of the DSTs. The types of indications addressed arc crack-like flaws, wall thinning, and pitting. In establishing acceptable flaw sizes, the evaluations have taken into consideration the potential for crack growth by the mechanism of stress corrosion cracking. Critical flaw sizes have been based on elastic-plastic fracture mechanics with calculations being performed using the approach of the failure assessment diagram. In developing flaw acceptance criteria consideration was given to technical approaches used in ASME Codes, for reactor tanks at the Department of Energy (DOE) Savannah River facilities, and in recommendations by the DOE Tank Structural Integrity Panel The goal was to ensure that indications discovered during inspections are not large enough to ever cause a leak or rupture of the tank inner liner. The acceptance criteria were intended to be simple to apply using a set of tables giving acceptable flaw sizes. These tables are sufficiently conservative to be appicable to an double-shell tanks. In those cases that a flaw exceeds the size permitted by the tables, it is proposed that additional criteria permit more detailed and less conservative evaluations to address specific conditions of stress levels, operating temperature, flaw location, and material properties.
Index Keywords: Crack propagation; Failure analysis; Fracture mechanics; Linings; Pitting; Radioactive waste storage; Standards; Stress corrosion cracking; Tanks (containers); Ultrasonic applications; Acceptance criteria; Crack like flaws; Double shell tanks; Ultrasonic inspection; Wall thinning; Inspection

Authors: Robertson S.H., Pilling M.J., Green N.J.B.
Title: Diffusion approximations of the two dimensional master equation
Affiliations: School of Chemistry, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Department of Chemistry, King' s College London, London, WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robertson, S.H., School of Chemistry, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Pilling, M.J., School of Chemistry, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Green, N.J.B., Department of Chemistry, King' s College London, London, WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The effects of rotational energy transfer on unimolecular dissociation are assessed using a two-dimensional master equation approach. The collision operator for such a system can be very large, and approximations are sought that reduce the size of the matrix that has to be stored. The density of states of the vibrational energy is large for most molecules and can be treated as virtually continuous. As a consequence, motion in vibrational energy space can be treated using a diffusion equation approach. This reduces the storage requirements greatly and increases the speed at which diagonalization occurs. Results are presented for the dissociation of ethane and methane. © 1996 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Laprade B., Dykstra M., Langevin F.
Title: The development OfAn ultra small pore microchannel plate for space sciences applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Galileo EIectroOptics Corporation, Galileo Park, Sturbridge, MA, 01566, United States
Authors with affiliations: Laprade, B., Galileo EIectroOptics Corporation, Galileo Park, Sturbridge, MA, 01566, United States; Dykstra, M., Galileo EIectroOptics Corporation, Galileo Park, Sturbridge, MA, 01566, United States; Langevin, F., Galileo EIectroOptics Corporation, Galileo Park, Sturbridge, MA, 01566, United States
Abstract: Infroduction Microchannel Plates (MCPs) are solid state electron multipliers consisting of miffions (10E5 - 10E7 channels/cm2) of microscopic (typically 10 - 25 microns) continuous dynode electron multipliers all fused together in a solid array. (figure 1) Fabricated from a alkali doped, reduced lead silicate glass, microchannel plates are known as excellent high gain , low noise, two dimensional detectors of charged particles and electromagnetic radiation. The microchannel plate manufacturing process begins with a series ofglass fiber draws in which an acid soluble core glass (figure 2) is combined with an alkali soluble clad tube and drawn to form a mono fiber. Mono fibers (typically 2,000 to 4,000) are then assembled into a hexagonal preform called a multi wrap. The preform is again drawn to form a multifiber producing an overall feature size reduction of typically 2000: 1. The multi fibers then become the basic building blocks. Hundreds ofmulti fibers are next arranged to form the active area ofthe MCP. High temperature vacuum fusion is then used to fuse the multi fibers together with the solid glass border (ifused) to form a billet or boule. Standard semiconductor slicing, lapping and polishing techniques are used to prepare the wafers for chemical processing. Chemical processing consists of etching open the microchannels, adjusting the open area ratio (OAR) and preparing the silica rich emissive layer. A hydrogen firing produces is used to reduce the lead glass making it electrically conductive. Finally a thin (typically 2,000 - to 3,000 Angstroms) film ofmetaiization is vacuum deposited on both sides ofthe microchannel plate to electrically connect each of the channels in parallel, therefore ensuring the same potential is applied to each channel. Microchannel plates operate on the principle of secondary electron emission. In operation primary events enter the input side of the MCP and collide with the channel wall. If the primary event has sufficient energy, secondary electrons will result. The resultant secondary electrons will be accelerated down the channel by the electric field produced when a high voltage is applied between the electrode faces. Additional coffisions with the channel walls produce still further secondary electrons.
Index Keywords: Basic building block; Electrically conductive; Lapping and polishing; Lead silicate glass; Manufacturing process; Secondary electron emissions; Solid-state electron; Two-dimensional detectors; Astronomy; Channel flow; Chemical industry; Electric fields; Electromagnetic waves; Fibers; Gamma rays; Glass; Preforming; Secondary emission; Silicates; Vacuum; Image storage tubes

Abstract: 15 μm SOI p-MOSFFTs were fabricated hv XRL (x-ray lithography) for gate and contact layer's patterning and optical lithograph) for other layers*. We prepared x-ray mask blank with 2 μm in thick silicon nitride film as a membrane as shown in Fig. 1. The additive process" was utilized for x-ray mask fabrication as indicated in Fig. 2. We deposited 10 nm thick chromium layer and 200 nm thick gold layer over the membrane for the effective absorber electroplating. 400 nm thick gold film was electroplated as an absorber after the patterning by electron-beam lithography using resist FMMA. For the XRL process, Alladin storage ring of 800 MeV energy in Wisconsin University in U.S.A. and Karl Suss XRS 200 stepper were utilized. We used SAL 603 negative resist(from Shipley Co.) and AZ-PF positive resist(from Hoechst Co.) of 0.75 μm thickness for the patterning of gate poly-Si and contact hole, respectively. The gap distance between mask and wafer on the stepper was set at 40 μm in automatic mode and the irradiation dose was 200 mJ/cm2 The alignment accuracy, die by die, was better than 150 nm. Figure 3 shows the vernier patterns which indicate the good alignment and XRL patterning results for poly-Si layer of 0.15 μin line and space. SOI p-channel MOSFHTs were fabricated by a conventional CMOS process except two XRL steps for the gate and contact layers on SIMOX SOI substrates. 6.5 nm gate oxide was thermally grown in dry O2, ambient at 900 °C. The final surface silicon thickness was about 0.1 μm, while the thickness of the source/drain region was 0.03 m thinner than that of the channel region. Figure 4(a) shows the TFM photograph of the fabricated SOI p-MOSFRT and figure 4(b) shows the I V characteristics of the device. As shown in the l-V characteristics, the saturation drain current ld.M was about J (K) jjA/fjm and the threshold voltage V1, was about 0.4 V. The breakdown voltage BV, s between the source and drain measured at Va. = 0 V and I4 = 10 nA was larger than 4 V. The lower I, i( was caused mainly due to the high source/drain resistance resulted from the non-silicided thin Si layers. We also measured the interface trap density I):. by using the charge pumping current method to confirm any damage at the Si/SiO2: interface of the p-MOSFFT on the normal bulk-Si substrate. Measured Dit was about 4 x 10 eV cm . This value is almost same as that of previous measurement1 1 and somewhat lager than than the value of 1.5 x 10 thcm2 which was measured in the device fabricated using conventional optical lithography. Authors: Korin E., Pasternak D., Cohen S., Klotz H., Drori U.
Title: A solar greenhouse based on water sleeves and a movable thermal screen for use in arid regions
Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Dept., Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Nifla Ltd. Greenhouses, Kfar Harif, 79830, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Korin, E., Chemical Engineering Dept., Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Pasternak, D., Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Cohen, S., Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Klotz, H., Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O.B. 653, Beer-Sheva, 84105, Israel; Drori, U., Nifla Ltd. Greenhouses, Kfar Harif, 79830, Israel
Abstract: A cost effective solar greenhouse for growing out-of-season winter crops in semiarid regions was designed and studied experimentally. The system is based on a combination of two components: 1) water sleeves, which function as a passive element for the day-time collection of solar energy that is then used for warming, mainly during the night; and 2) a movable thermal screen, which is spread over the plants at night to reduce heat loss to the surroundings. The solar greenhouse is designed to operate as a closed system most of the winter to enable maximal solar energy storage in the sleeves. This concept was applied to melon production, as a test crop to assess whether high-quality fruit could be obtained during the winter for export to Europe. The experiment was carried out in six identical tunnels, 4 m wide, 11 m long, and 2 m high. Average increase of the water temperature in the sleeves was about 7.5°C on a clear day compared with about 4°C on a cloudy day. On a typical clear night following a sunny day air temperatures in the greenhouse at a height of 0.5 m above the ground were 6-7°C higher than outdoor temperatures, and comparable soil temperatures (at a depth of 20 cm) were 8.5-9°C higher indoors. After a cloudy day this difference in air temperature was reduced to about 5°C. On the assumption that there are 120 growing days per season, the average energy stored in the water sleeves was estimated to be equivalent to 4.2-7.5 kg/m 2 of petroleum per season.
Index Keywords: Cucumis

Authors: Pasternak D., Drori U., Korin E., Klotz H., Cohen S.
Title: A versatile solar system for environmental control in greenhouses
Affiliations: Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; NIFLA Company, Kfar Harif 79830, Israel; Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pasternak, D., Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Drori, U., NIFLA Company, Kfar Harif 79830, Israel; Korin, E., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Klotz, H., Institutes for Applied Research, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Cohen, S.
Abstract: A versatile solar greenhouse for the production of a range of out-of-season protected crops has been developed and tested. In this system the solar energy collection and storage unit (solar cell) is separated from a walk-through plastic tunnel by means of a mobile curtain allowing a) ventilation of the greenhouse without affecting the efficiency of solar radiation collection and b) the storage of solar heat to the late hours of the night, only after greenhouse air temperatures drop below a threshold level typical for each crop species. Two prototypes were tested. In the first prototype the walk-through tunnel had an east-west orientation and one solar unit was placed on the south facing side. The second prototype had a north-south orientation and the solar cells were placed on both the east and the west facing sides. The results demonstrated that the first prototype was not suitable for production of trailed winter melons because of shading effects of the southern rows over the northern rows. The systems can be fully automated or it can be hand operated. Trials carried out during the winter of 1995 have demonstrated the efficacy of this new system.
Index Keywords: Benincasa hispida; Cucumis

Authors: Hultman E., Spriet L.L.
Title: Chapter 8 Muscle fatigue
Authors with affiliations: Hultman, E.; Spriet, L.L.
Abstract: Fatigue in Isolated Skeletal Muscle Fibers. This section examined small muscle preparations stimulated electrically or skinned muscle fibers maintained in superfused baths with different substance concentrations. The electrical stimulation was either continuous or intermittent for relatively short durations. High frequency fatigue or fatigue during continuous high frequency stimulation seems to be mainly due to impaired propagation of the stimulating impulse in the T-tubular system. Fatigue during intermittent tetanic stimulation is caused by three mechanisms: (a) decreased maximum Ca2+ activated tension, (b) decreased Ca2+ sensitivity of the contractile proteins, and (c) decreased Ca2+ release from the SR. The first two mechanisms are probably due to the combined effects of myoplasmic accumulation of Pi and H+ formed when PCr and glycogen are degraded in muscle when the rate of oxidative ATP formation is insufficient. Crossbridge movements are impaired due to the Pi increase and crossbridge formation is decreased when Ca2+ binding sites on troponin are occupied by H+. The third fatigue factor, reduced Ca2+ release from the SR, is related to metabolism and the decrease in MgATP following the depletion of the PCr store. The MgATP decrease may inhibit Ca2+ release from the SR due to the increased free [Mg2+] and the decrease in ATP. A decreased [ATP] could affect action potential propagation, IP3 turnover rate and the activity of the SR Ca2+ pump. A fall in SR Ca2+ pump activity together with increased Ca2+ binding in the myoplasm of fatiguing muscle would decrease the SR Ca2+ availability. During intense contractions Pi and H+ accumulation begins early, resulting in a decrease in maximum Ca2+ activated tension and an increase in the Ca2+ concentration necessary to produce tension. Both phenomena are potentiated when the Ca2+ release from the SR falls during continued stimulation, resulting in nearly complete loss of tension development. Fatigue in Intact Skeletal Muscle of Human Subjects During High Intensity Exercise. High intensity exercise requires skeletal muscles to contract with forces that represent 40-100% of the maximal voluntary contraction force. Fatigue factors in human subjects during high intensity exercise include the accumulation of H+ and Pi, with effects on Ca2+ sensitivity and maximum Ca2+ induced tension, and the availability of PCr and total creatine. The size of the PCr store is directly related to the MgATP/ADP ratio in the myoplasm of exercising muscle, while free creatine may have an impact on the rate of mitochondrial ATP and PCr formation, thereby adding to the regulation of the ratio during exercise. The MgATP/ADP ratio is involved in several processes regulating SR Ca2+ release. Fatigue in Intact Skeletal Muscle of Human Subjects During Submaximal Exercise. Submaximal exercise in human subjects requires skeletal muscles to contract with forces that are below 40% of the maximal voluntary contraction force. Submaximal exercise intensities are expressed as a percentage of the power output required to elicit maximal oxygen uptake (VO2 max). During exercise at 85-100% VO2 max, anaerobic energy is required to supplement oxidative energy at the onset of exercise and in some muscles that cannot meet the energy demand aerobically. This produces accumulations of Pi and H+ and produces fatigue as described in the high intensity exercise sections. At 100% VO2 max, muscle fatigue will occur in 5-7 min or less, and at 85% VO2 max in ∼30 min. Muscle fatigue during exercise at 60-85% VO2 max may occur following 30 min at 85% VO2 or after several hours at 60% VO2 max. Fatigue is related to the ability to provide adequate amounts of oxidizable fuel to the muscles. Carbohydrate in the form of muscle glycogen is the required substrate and muscle fatigue coincides with glycogen depletion. Diet and exercise manipulations increase the storage of muscle glycogen thereby delaying muscle fatigue. Hypoglycemia can also occur during exercise when liver glycogen stores are depleted, leading to fatigue caused by central nervous system dysfunction. Ingestion of CHO during exercise can delay fatigue either by preventing hypoglycemia or slowing the rate of muscle glycogen use. During exercise below 60% VO2 max, there is greater reliance on fuel sources from outside the muscle (plasma glucose and FFAs). Since exercise can be sustained for 3-5 hours at 50% VO2 max and over eight hours at or below 40% VO2 max, there is a strong possibility that dehydration and/or hypoglycemia will occur. Routine ingestion of meals and liquid feedings rich in CHO throughout exercise prevent these problems from occurring. Muscle injury and soreness will occur when exercise is performed by an individual unaccustomed to exercise or during exercise requiring a large number of eccentric contractions (e.g., downhill running). The affected muscles will be unable to generate normal forces while injured. Prevention of muscle injury through gradual increases in the amount of activity performed is recommended, but antiinflammatory agents decrease the soreness and improve force generation when muscle injury has occurred. © 1996 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mezheritskii S.M., Eremenko T.V.
Title: Experimental determination of thermophysical characteristics of gassipol resin as a heat-storage material of solar modules
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Affiliations: Tashkent State University, Uzbekistan
Authors with affiliations: Mezheritskii, S.M., Tashkent State University, Uzbekistan; Eremenko, T.V., Tashkent State University, Uzbekistan
Abstract: The solar energy utilization can be raised by way of accumulation of heat in the storage system which stores heat entering the solar chamber in the daytime. Gassipol resin is suggested as a heat-storage material, which, when heated, accumulates the heat of melting (softening). The specific heat of gassipol resin was determined by a calorimetric technique as the key parameter of its heat-storage ability. The technique is based on the measurement of the amount of heat released in the calorimeter by the studied substance of specified mass in its cooling within the specified temperature range. To check the technique's validity specific heats of known liquids were measured. © 1996 by Allerton Press, Inc.

Authors: Kaptan I.N., Kilic A.
Title: A theoretical and experimental investigation of a novel built-in-storage solar water heater
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Affiliations: I. T. U. Mechanical Engineering Faculty, Gumussuyn-Istanbul, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kaptan, I.N., I. T. U. Mechanical Engineering Faculty, Gumussuyn-Istanbul, Turkey; Kilic, A., I. T. U. Mechanical Engineering Faculty, Gumussuyn-Istanbul, Turkey
Abstract: In this work, a novel built-in-storage type of solar water heater has been investigated theoretically and experimentally under thermosyphon mode with no drawoff. In the theoretical study, transient performance of the system is predicted by solving the mathematical model consisting of energy balance equations written for each control volume comprising one length of pipe. These equations are converted to finite difference from and then solved by a digital computer. The experiments have been performed inside the laboratory using an artificial sun consisting of twenty seven lamps. The water temperatures were measured at various locations in the system. The experimental results were compared with the numerical ones. © 1997 by Allerton Press, Inc.

Authors: Mcquillan K.
Title: Alumina fiber insulation modules improve efficiency of cracker furnaces
Affiliations: ICI/BP Chemicals, Tessside, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mcquillan, K., ICI/BP Chemicals, Tessside, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Olefins 6 ethylene furnace complex at the ICI/BP Chemicals in Teesside, England, reduced installation time 30% by relining cracking furnaces with energy efficient insulation modules containing alumina fibers named Saffil®. The key goals of the refurbishment project were that the lining be energy efficient, have a ten-year lifespan in continuous operation, and require minimum maintenance. The alumina fiber linings reduced heat loss through the furnace wall, and provided better specific heat capacity and neat storage properties in comparison with brick. The linings were manufactured in M. H. Detrick's Skelmersdale plant and delivered to the site to meet the agreed build program of one furnace per month. Demolition of the old linings, and installation of the new modules, were carried out by the company's personnel. The contract included removing the burners and associated pipework and replacing them with new materials.

Authors: Mileikowsky C.
Title: How and when could we be ready to send a l,000kg research probe with a coasting speed of 0,3C to a star?
Source title: JBIS - Journal of the British Interplanetary Society
Affiliations: Doctor of Technology, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Mileikowsky, C., Doctor of Technology, Sweden
Abstract: Because the cost of interstellar flight would be extremely high we would need indications of a "worthy" target star of very large scientific interest, e.g. one with a proven planetary system. For psychological decision-taking reasons, the mission time - defined as the time from decision to incoming results - should not exceed a human lifespan. This tough criterion demands a coasting speed of 0.3 times the speed of light, or 0.3c. The kinetic energy of the 1,000kg coasting probe is then no less than 1,180 billion kWh. The cheapest investment to achieve this appears to be the laser-propelled lightsail, LPL. The LPL has an efficiency of electric energy to laser beam energy of 30% and an efficiency of laser beam energy to kinetic probe energy of 6-7%, so the total efficiency becomes 2% (D. Andrews). Therefore, 59,000 billion kWh of electric energy have to be supplied during a typical acceleration time of 900 hours, for technical reasons. This means in turn that 65,000 GWe of installed electric power capacity has to be available, plus the corresponding laser equipment. In this paper the electricity requirements of two other methods will also be treated: the particle beam propelled magsail, PBPM, and the antimatter propelled rocket, AMP. As to storage of electric energy, it would increase the capital cost of LPL and decrease it for PBPM, which nevertheless remains much costlier than LPL. The huge electric power levels needed during acceleration stresses the importance of the lowest possible capital cost of electricity generation plant or of storage plant. D.R. Criswell and D. Waldron have suggested and studied the concept of a very large photovoltaic electric power plant on the Moon, mainly manufactured there, producing 20,000 GWe intended for transmission to Earth by microwaves. The stated total cost is ̃ 900 USD/kW, but most of this is the rectenna receivers on Earth. The capital cost of the Moon power station alone is between 25 and 65 USD/kW. In comparison, the current capital cost of nuclear power is 2,000 USD/kW. The cost of the Moon power station plus the microwave transmitters is 2,000 BUSD for 20,000 GWe excluding development cost. This would become 6,000 BUSD for 60,000 GWe It is hard to estimate the cost of the lasers and their development - they do not yet exist at that strength. For simplicity let us assume extremely roughly that their cost would be comparable to that given by Criswell-Waldron for the microwave transmission plant. The total cost for the 60,000 GWe power plant plus the laser plant on the Moon would then amount to 6,500 - 7,500 BUSD, including the development cost of the lasers. (The development of the power plant is assumed to have been repaid by the terrestrial power business.) Even if a 20-year period is taken to accumulate this kind of money, the yearly cost of 350 BUSD represents almost 2% the current Gross World Product of 20,000 BUSD. The NASA budget, 14 BUSD per year is only 0.25% of the GNP of the USA, the richest and most science-minded nation in the world today. 0.25% of current GWP, or 50 BUSD per year during say 20 years, would obviously be totally insufficient for a 1-tonne probe. For such a project the GWP would have to be 15 times larger, i.e. 300,000 BUSD, and the world population would have to be willing both to spend 0.25% thereof on space activities and to earmark half of that expenditure for the space probe. Demographers predict that Earth's population will grow by a factor of 2 during the next 60 years. That future population of 12 billion will have to have an extremely optimistic per capita GWP of 25,000 USD (that of rich industrialised nations today) in order for the GWP to reach 300,000 BUSD. In view of continuing miniaturisation and compactisation, the question arises as to whether a much lighter probe at a considerably lower cost could give sufficiently interesting information from a flyby. (Note: 1 BUSD = 109 USD; 1Bkwh = 109 kwh; 1 GW= 109W).
Index Keywords: Acceleration time; Development costs; Electric energies; Electric power level; Interesting information; Interstellar flight; Microwave transmission; Microwave transmitters; Costs; Electric energy storage; Electric power plants; Electricity; Investments; Kinetics; Laser beams; Microwave devices; Moon; NASA; Probes; Rockets; Stars; Cost benefit analysis

Authors: Montalto A., Vinciguerra S., Menza S., Patanè G.
Title: Recent seismicity of Mount Etna: Implications for flank instability
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Istituto di Geologia e Geofisica, University of Catania, Catania, Italy; Osserv. Sismologico Protez. Civile, Acireale, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Montalto, A., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, University of Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Vinciguerra, S., Istituto di Geologia e Geofisica, University of Catania, Catania, Italy; Menza, S., Osserv. Sismologico Protez. Civile, Acireale, Italy; Patanè, G., Istituto di Geologia e Geofisica, University of Catania, Catania, Italy
Abstract: This study considers seismic activity recorded beneath the low eastern flank of Etna during the period between April 1989 and December 1991 with the aim of placing some seismological constraints on the investigation of slope instability related to the gravitational sliding of this unsupported side of the volcano. The seismicity essentially consists of rather superficial (z < 10 km for more than 90% of cases), low-magnitude (usually M < 3) earthquakes. Foci of earthquakes are clustered on the main fault systems crossing the region, such as the Santa Tecla fault and the San Leonardello fault system, that have in recent times produced earthquakes of unusually high intensity covering the whole of the Etnean area. The broad picture of seismicity may be partially attributed to the accumulation of stress related to the seaward displacement of moving blocks in the vicinity of the Valle del Bove and adjacent regions in response to the storage and release of elastic energy associated with frequent episodes of magma intrusion. We propose that eastward sliding probably involves a complicated ensemble of moving blocks, resting on shallow independent décollements rather than on a single, widespread decoupling surface.

Authors: Miernikiewicz A., Surowiec I., Miśta H.
Title: Deposition costs and energy gains during release of stored materials in the bank vole (Clethrionomys glareolus, schr. 1780)
Affiliations: Department of Animal Ecology, Institute of Environmental Biology, Jagiellonian University, Ingardena Str. 6, 30-060 Krakow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Miernikiewicz, A., Department of Animal Ecology, Institute of Environmental Biology, Jagiellonian University, Ingardena Str. 6, 30-060 Krakow, Poland; Surowiec, I., Department of Animal Ecology, Institute of Environmental Biology, Jagiellonian University, Ingardena Str. 6, 30-060 Krakow, Poland; Miśta, H., Department of Animal Ecology, Institute of Environmental Biology, Jagiellonian University, Ingardena Str. 6, 30-060 Krakow, Poland
Abstract: Energetic costs of deposition and release of stored materials were estimated in the bank vole. Two kinds of food differing in the composition and energy content were used. In experimental groups, consumption, metabolism, and body composition (energy, protein, fat, and water contents) were compared. The calculated costs of the deposition of reserve materials were three times higher than the energy gain from their utilization. This noticeable difference provides evidence that the habitat rich in food makes it possible to bear high costs of the storage of nutrients.
Author Keywords: Clethrionomys glareolus; Costs of using nutrient reserves; Fat; Protein; Resting metabolism

Authors: Bidlake W.R., Boetcher P.F.
Title: Near-surface water balance of an undeveloped upland site in west-central Florida
Source title: US Geological Survey Water Supply Paper
Authors with affiliations: Bidlake, W.R.; Boetcher, P.F.
Abstract: Quantitative description of water balances of wildland ecosystems provides information that is useful in management of water and other resources of those systems. The near-surface water balance of a homogeneous area of wildland vegetation in west-central Florida was described quantitatively for June 1991 to October 1992. The study area was in the dry prairie vegetation type common to central Florida. The water balance was defined on a unit area basis for a depth of 5.5 meters. The period of field measurements encompassed two summer wet seasons; one was drier than normal and one was wetter than normal. Water-balance components were measured, estimated, or computed as the residual in massbalance computations. The water-balance components precipitation, evapotranspiration, and the rate of soil-water storage were measured or estimated using independent techniques. A layer of clay starting at a depth of 5.5 meters was assumed to limit vertical flow at that depth to negligible amounts. The equation for the water balance was arranged to compute water yield as the residual. Water yield was interpreted as being the sum of (1) the difference between surface-water inflow and outflow, (2) the difference between ground-water inflow and outflow, and (3) errors in the other water-balance components. Alternative techniques were used to measure precipitation and evapotranspiration in order to assess the reliability of results. Precipitation was measured using tipping-bucket and accumulating rain gages. Precipitation recorded using the two gages agreed to within 1 percent. Evapotranspiration was estimated using the micrometeorological techniques energy-balance Bowen ratio (EBBR), energy-balance wind and scalar profile (EBWSP), and eddy correlation. Because reliable measurements of vapor-pressure gradients could not be routinely made at night and during early morning periods, and because numerical results from the EBBR technique are inherently unstable during early morning and evening periods, results from that technique were augmented using the EBWSP technique to produce continuous 24-hour records of evapotranspiration. Eddy-correlation measurements were made intermittently for 24-hour periods during the study. Daily evapotranspiration, computed using the combined EBBR-EBWSP approach, was significantly correlated with daily evapotranspiration estimated using eddy correlation (r2 = 0.89). The slope of the relation between the two estimates was not significantly different from 1 and the intercept was not significantly different from 0. Rate of soil-water storage was computed using a time series of replicated measurements of soil-water content. Volumetric soil-water content in the uppermost 0.15 meter of soil was measured using core samples. Volumetric soil-water content between depths of 0.15 and 1.7 meters was measured using a neutron moisture gage. Depth to the water table was never more than 1.7 meters during the study, and changes in water content between that depth and a depth of 5.5 meters were assumed to be negligible. Precipitation during the 498 days of field measurements was 2,245 millimeters, which made it the largest component in the water balance. Evapotranspiration, the second largest component, was 1,419 millimeters. Water yield was 808 millimeters and the change in soil-water storage was 19 millimeters. When the water-balance was integrated annually to include the drier of the two wet seasons, precipitation was 1,019 millimeters, evapotranspiration was 1,000 millimeters, water yield was 215 millimeters, and the change in soil-water storage was -197 millimeters. When the water balance was integrated annually to include the wetter of the two wet seasons, precipitation was 1,561 millimeters, evapotranspiration was 981 millimeters, water yield was 540 millimeters, and the change in soil-water storage was 41 millimeters.

Authors: Marks F.A.
Title: Effects of sample preparation on the optical properties of breast tissue
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: General Electric Corporate Research and Development Center, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marks, F.A., General Electric Corporate Research and Development Center, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Abstract: The optical properties of biological tissue should be determined in vivo whenever possible. However, for those instances when in vivo studies are impractical, too expensive or inappropriate, and when blood flow is not an issue, the ability to perform in vitro studies then becomes invaluable. Optical absorption spectroscopy shows that it may be possible to obtain meaningful information about the optical properties of human breast tissue from in vitro samples if strict preparation and measuring protocols are used. That a strict protocol for storing and handling tissue is critical can be seen from our observations of changes in the optical absorption spectra that occur in response to formalin fixation, the passage of time, application of stains and dyes, and storage in growth medium of the excised tissue. In vivo optical absorption spectroscopy measurements have been made on human breast cancer xenografts and compared with in vitro measurements on breast biopsies prepared according to precise collection and treatment protocols. There is a 'window of opportunity' before time dependent changes in the UV optical absorption spectra of the excised tissue specimens occur. This time window of opportunity widens at longer wavelengths with the least changes occurring in the optical spectra in the NIR. ©2004 Copyright SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering.

Authors: Ramenah H.K., Bertrand P., Soubari E.H., Meyrueis P.
Title: Cross-talk and diffraction efficiency in angular multiplexed memories using improved polypeptide
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Louis Pasteur University, Photonics Systems Laboratory, E.N.S.P.S, Boulevard Sébastien Brandt, 67400 Illkirch, France; Imagine Technologies Company, 115 Chemin du Geffrier, 83190 Ollioules, France
Authors with affiliations: Ramenah, H.K., Louis Pasteur University, Photonics Systems Laboratory, E.N.S.P.S, Boulevard Sébastien Brandt, 67400 Illkirch, France, Imagine Technologies Company, 115 Chemin du Geffrier, 83190 Ollioules, France; Bertrand, P., Imagine Technologies Company, 115 Chemin du Geffrier, 83190 Ollioules, France; Soubari, E.H., Louis Pasteur University, Photonics Systems Laboratory, E.N.S.P.S, Boulevard Sébastien Brandt, 67400 Illkirch, France; Meyrueis, P., Louis Pasteur University, Photonics Systems Laboratory, E.N.S.P.S, Boulevard Sébastien Brandt, 67400 Illkirch, France
Abstract: We studied energy coupling between gratings and angularly multiplexed 20 gratings with a uniform diffraction efficiency within 25 micrometer layer thickness of dichromated gelatin. The dependence of diffraction efficiency on beam ratio is given. We recorded a matrix form memory of nxmxp elements, where n and m are the rows and columns and p the number of multiplexes. For indication only, n equals m equals 10, p equals 20, the surface area of the matrix is 1 cm2. Color diffractive images and digital data are illustrated as well as video, cartography and medical applications. ©2005 Copyright SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering.

Authors: Lu Y., Rong A.
Title: Optical property study of phase change optical recording thin film media
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Amorphous Physics and Opto-Information Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing 100083, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Y., Amorphous Physics and Opto-Information Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing 100083, China; Rong, A., Amorphous Physics and Opto-Information Laboratory, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing 100083, China
Abstract: Room temperature reflectivity measurement over the energy 0.7eV to 7eV has been made on the phase change recording thin film based on Ge-Sb-Te alloy. The reflectivity curves have been obtained by spectrophotometer. An analysis of reflectivity curves for this recording medium has been made by use of Kramers-Kronig (KK) relation. The refraction index n(ω) and extinction coefficient k(ω) have been obtained as a n energy function. The optical gaps of the recording medium are 0.71eV in glassy state and 1.32eV in crystalline state. The research results show that this recording medium can be used as a phase change optical storage material in short wavelength range. This paper provides a research method by use of KK relation to obtain optical properties of recording thin film, and gives a practical application of this phase change recording medium in short wavelength range and high density storage. ©2005 Copyright SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering.

Authors: Moudjahed M., Kauffmann J.M.
Title: Simulation of power system stability by using superconducting magnet energy storage
Source title: International Journal of Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Univ. Franche Comté, Inst. de Genie Energetique, 2, Avenue Jean Moulin, 90000 Belfort, France
Authors with affiliations: Moudjahed, M.; Kauffmann, J.M., Univ. Franche Comté, Inst. de Genie Energetique, 2, Avenue Jean Moulin, 90000 Belfort, France
Abstract: The superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is one of the effective measures to suppress instabilities which will occur in a power system if there are system disturbances. A 12-pulse cascaded bridge-type AC/DC converter is an interface between the three-phase power system and the superconducting coil. This paper presents a general mathematical model of a SMES unit and its integration into a multimachine power system which is studied for load change and short-circuit faults. The SMES unit can be located at any bus of the system. Computer studies show the benefit of the SMES unit on power system stability. The impact of the system parameters on the size of the SMES is also examined.
Author Keywords: Simulation; SMES; Stability

Authors: Flanagan K.A., Fang T.T., Baluta C., Davis J.E., Dewey D., Markert T.H., Graessle D.E., Drake J., Fitch J.E., Juda J.Z., Woo J., Kraft S., Bulicke P., Fliegauf R., Schoize F., Ulm G., Bauer J.
Title: Modeling the diffraction efficiencies of the AXAF high energy transmission gratings: II
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Flanagan, K.A., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Fang, T.T., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Baluta, C., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Davis, J.E., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Dewey, D., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Markert, T.H., Center for Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Graessle, D.E., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Drake, J., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Fitch, J.E., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Juda, J.Z., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Woo, J., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Kraft, S., Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Bulicke, P., Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Fliegauf, R., Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Schoize, F., Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Ulm, G., Physikalisch-Tech N Ische Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Bauer, J., Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Abstract: In order to characterize the instrumentation on AXAF, each of the science instrument teams carries out sub-assembly calibrations. For the High Energy Transmission Grating (HETG) group, this means individual measurements of the diffraction efficiencies of each of the 336 grating elements that goes into the completed HETG assembly. Measurements are made at a number of energies (corresponding to X-ray emission lines) which fix the parameters of a model. This model is determined from first principles and verified by extensively testing sample grating elements at synchrotron radiation facilities. Here we present new synchrotron radiation (SR) data obtained at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) and at the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) using the electron storage ring BESSY in Berlin. The gratings are from AXAF flight lots, and we apply an improved data reduction technique which builds on our experience from last year (Markert et al., SPIE Proceedings 2518, 424, 1995). Our analysis takes into account the effects of small extended wings in the diffraction of the various orders in the NSLS data. Our goal is to obtain efficiencies in the 0th and +/-1st diffraction orders which are accurate in the 1% level, except near absorption edges, where accuracies in the 5% to 10% level are required. With a few exceptions (discussed here) our new data/improved model meet these goals.
Author Keywords: synchrotron radiation; transmission gratings; X-ray astronomy; X-ray spectroscopy
Index Keywords: Electron storage ring; Energy transmission; National Synchrotron light sources; Physikalisch-technische bundesanstalt; Reduction techniques; Synchrotron radiation facility; Transmission gratings; X-ray astronomy; Astronomy; Diffraction efficiency; Electromagnetic wave emission; Gamma rays; Instruments; Measurements; Synchrotron radiation; X ray spectroscopy; Diffraction gratings

Authors: Opgenoorth H.J., Persson M.A.L., Olsson A.
Title: The substorm onset seen with ground-based instrumentation results, problems future possibilities
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Swedish Institute of Space Physics, Uppsala Division, S-75591 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Opgenoorth, H.J., Swedish Institute of Space Physics, Uppsala Division, S-75591 Uppsala, Sweden; Persson, M.A.L., Swedish Institute of Space Physics, Uppsala Division, S-75591 Uppsala, Sweden; Olsson, A., Swedish Institute of Space Physics, Uppsala Division, S-75591 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: The substorm onset itself, in spite of the global nature of magnetospheric energy storage and final release, is a very localised process, initially only affecting the auroral zone ionospheres of both hemispheres in regions not larger than 1000 km in longitudinal and 500 km in latitudinal direction. The corresponding magnetospheric region is not larger than a few Earthradii in both directions. Nevertheless, it is the global nature of the energy input and subsequent energy transport and release, which determines when and where exactly the initial localised substorm onset takes place. The global magnetospheric state also determines the details of the later substorm development. One obvious problem of substorm observations is therefore that one must keep an eye on the global magnetospheric development, and at the same time observe detailed processes of substorm onset and expansion at an a-priori unknown location, somewhere near magnetic midnight at auroral latitudes. Thus one needs both a global network of stations and several denser networks, enhanced with advanced equipment, at key geographic locations. Here we will review the value of ground-based network observations for the understanding of substorm physics. Intrinsic problems and possibilities of ground-based observations will be discussed, and future perspectives for advances in substorm research with combined ground-based and space instrumentation will be outlined.

Authors: El-Haggar S.M., El-Baz A.R., Ezz Eldean S.
Title: Thermal behavior of a stratified energy storage tank
Affiliations: American University in Cairo, Engineering Department, P.O.Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt; Ain Shams University, Mech. Power Engineering Department, Abassia, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: El-Haggar, S.M., American University in Cairo, Engineering Department, P.O.Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt; El-Baz, A.R., Ain Shams University, Mech. Power Engineering Department, Abassia, Cairo, Egypt; Ezz Eldean, S., American University in Cairo, Engineering Department, P.O.Box 2511, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Thermal stratification plays a significant role in the behavior of solar energy systems. This study deals with the variation of temperature within a cylindrical insulated tank and the energy storage associated. The tank is thermally charged by hot fluid introduced at different inlets. Experimental studies were conducted to investigate the temperature variation inside the storage tank during both charging and discharging modes. Normalized forms of temperature, time and storage energy were obtained and used to study the time history of both temperature and energy during the charging mode. Temperature profiles along the height of the tank were investigated during both charging and discharging modes. The discharging mode was investigated with circulation and no circulation. Energy stored was calculated for different circulation flow rates, inlet temperature, and inlet pipe locations. The tank was modeled using the transient one dimensional energy equation. A numerical solution was obtained using a fully implicit finite difference scheme. The solution was used to study the transient thermal behavior of the cylindrical water tank during the charging mode. The results were compared with the experimental data, and a fairly good agreement was achieved.

Authors: Kanari K., Takano K., Saito Y.
Title: Thermal behavior and simulation of a lithium secondary battery
Source title: Denshi Gijutsu Sogo Kenkyusho Iho/Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Kanari, K.; Takano, K.; Saito, Y.
Abstract: In the "New Sunshine Program" of AIST, the R & D under "Distributed Battery Electric Energy Storage Technology" is going on, and the high energy density and long life types of lithium secondary batteries are being developed. One of the important issues of the lithium secondary batteries for distributed electric energy storage is estimation of the temperature change during battery operation. In this study, the temperature changes of an about 1Ah scale lithium ion cell (a cylindrical type C/LiCoO2 cell) during charging and discharging for 0.2C to 2C have been experimentally investigated. We have also estimated the temperature changes of the lithium ion cell during charging and discharging by applying a two dimensional thermal conduction model, and compared them with the experimental results. In case of discharging mode, fairly good agreement between the estimated and measured temperatures is obtained.
Author Keywords: Battery energy storage; Lithium secondary battery; Temperature measurement; Thermal simulation

Authors: De Jonge L., Garrel D.R.
Title: Role of the sympathetic nervous system (sns) in the thermogenic response to food (trf) in man
Affiliations: Medical Research Center, Hotel-Dieu Hospital, Montrael, PQ, Canada
Authors with affiliations: De Jonge, L., Medical Research Center, Hotel-Dieu Hospital, Montrael, PQ, Canada; Garrel, D.R., Medical Research Center, Hotel-Dieu Hospital, Montrael, PQ, Canada
Abstract: Introduction: TRF consists of two components in man; an obligatory one related to digestion, absorption, and storage of nutrients, and a second that is facultative and associated with oropharyngeal stimulation. In rats SNS plays a role in TRF, but for humans, the literature is contradictory. Aim of the study: The aim of our study was to explore the role of the SNS on the two components of TRF in healthy subjects. Methodology: Ten healthy lean subjects participated in this study which consisted of four sessions of seven hours each, during which resting metabolic rate (RMR) and TRF were measured by indirect calorimetry either after the ingestion of an oral meal (OTRF) or after intragastric administration of the same blenderized meal (IGTRF). A 0.9% NaCI solution or propranolol (Bolus: 80pg/kg/1 Omin; continuous: 1//g/kg/min) was perfused during each session. TRF was calculated as energy expenditure above RMR as measured the same day, and was expressed as percentage of energy intake. Facultative TRF was calculated by subtracting IGTRF from OTRF. Results: RMR (kJ/h) TRF (U/h) Facultative TRF (kJ/6h) OTRF + NaCI 226±58 205±26 OTRF + propranolol 238±47 148±18 57±12++ IGTRF + NaCI 229±51 136±22 IGTRF + propranolol 238i47 138±23 4±9 p < 0.01 (vs OTRF + NaCI) ++: p < 0.01 (difference from 0) There was no significant difference in RMR between sessions. Propranolol significantly decreased OTRF, but had no effect on IGTRF. Conclusions: The results of this study in man concur with work in the rodent suggesting that the SNS plays a role in TRF and furthermore indicate that only the facultative component is influenced by SNS activity.

Authors: Schuch R., Asp S., Biedermann C., Dewitt D.R., Gao H., Hvarfner J., Justiniano E., Lindroth E., Quinteros T., Zong W., Andler G., Danared H., Källberg A., Pajek M.
Title: Reactions of cooled ions with cold electrons in cryring
Affiliations: Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Institute of Physics, Pedagogical University, 25-509 Kielce, Poland; MPI Für Plasmaphysik, Bereich Berlin, D-10117 Berlin, Germany; Department of Physics, East Carolina University, Greenville, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schuch, R., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Asp, S., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Biedermann, C., Institute of Physics, Pedagogical University, 25-509 Kielce, Poland; Dewitt, D.R., MPI Für Plasmaphysik, Bereich Berlin, D-10117 Berlin, Germany; Gao, H., Department of Physics, East Carolina University, Greenville, NC, United States; Hvarfner, J., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Justiniano, E., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Lindroth, E., Institute of Physics, Pedagogical University, 25-509 Kielce, Poland; Quinteros, T., MPI Für Plasmaphysik, Bereich Berlin, D-10117 Berlin, Germany; Zong, W., Department of Physics, East Carolina University, Greenville, NC, United States; Andler, G., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Danared, H., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Källberg, A., Institute of Physics, Pedagogical University, 25-509 Kielce, Poland; Pajek, M., MPI Für Plasmaphysik, Bereich Berlin, D-10117 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Cooler-storage ring facilities offer unique experimental possibilities for the study of electron-ion recombination processes at low relative energies by employing the electron cooler as a target. Through the use of an adiabatically expanded electron beam in the cooler of CRYRING, reactions down to 10-4 eV relative energies can be measured at an energy resolution in the order of 10-2 eV PWHM with ions stored in the ring at around 10 MeV/amu energies. A review of our measurements of radiative recombination, laser stimulated recombination, and dielectronic recombination is presented.

Authors: Häggström S.
Title: First exclusive measurement of η production in quasifree pn collisions
Affiliations: Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Häggström, S., Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: Quasifree η-production in proton-deuteron collisions has been studied using a D2 internal cluster jet target at the CELSIUS storage ring in Upp-sala. By exploiting the Fermi momentum of the target nucleons the excitation functions for the reactions pp → ppη, pn → pηη and pn → dη could be measured staying at a fixed proton beam energy of 1.35 GeV. Preliminary results for excess energies in the centre of mass from 15 to 115 MeV are reported.

Authors: Babich M.W., Benrashid R.
Title: Energy storage materials and coatings. DSC and flammabiltty studies
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Florida Institute of Technology, 150 West University Blvd., Melbourne, FL 32901-6988, United States
Authors with affiliations: Babich, M.W., Department of Chemistry, Florida Institute of Technology, 150 West University Blvd., Melbourne, FL 32901-6988, United States; Benrashid, R., Department of Chemistry, Florida Institute of Technology, 150 West University Blvd., Melbourne, FL 32901-6988, United States
Abstract: Tremendous potential exists in the area of ESM's for energy storage and in the area of moisture storage materials coupled with the ESM's. The efficacy of ESM materials for energy storage has clearly been demonstrated as has the utility of moisture storage agents for humidity control. The effectiveness of coatings in reduction of rate of flame spread, onset of smoke production and rate of heat release is indisputable. DSC is clearly the method of choice for preliminary studies of these systems.
Author Keywords: Energy Storage Materials; Flammability; Phase Change Materials

Authors: Keller A.A., Werth C.J., Goldstein R.A.
Title: Modeling the oceanic storage of fossil fuel emissions
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94303, United States; Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, A.A., Department of Civil Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94303, United States; Werth, C.J., Department of Civil Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94303, United States; Goldstein, R.A., Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States
Abstract: We use the GLOCO model to analyze the potential for oceanic storage of carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion, as well as the effect on atmospheric CO2 (pCO2) concentration. From a sensitivity analysis of the global carbon cycle, we find that the rate of transport of carbon to the deepest oceanic layers is rather insensitive to the atmospheric-ocean surface gas exchange coefficient, but to a larger extent on the upwelling velocity. Tne location of the carbon emissions, whether they are released in the atmosphere or in the middle of the oceanic thermocline, has a significant impact on the maximum pCO2 subsequently reached, suggesting that oceanic burial of a significant fraction of carbon emissions (e.g. via clathrate hydrides) may be an important management option for limiting pCO2 buildup. The effectiveness of ocean burial decreases asymptotically below about 1000 m depth, considering a one-dimensional ocean model, i.e. perfect mixing at the various ocean levels where the carbon is injected. With a constant emissions scenario (at 1990 levels), pCO2 rises to 501 ppmv by the year 2100 if all the emissions go to the atmosphere. With ocean burial of 50% of the fossil fuel emissions at a depth of 1000 m, pCO2 rises only to 422 ppmv. An alternative scenario looks at stabilizing pCO2 at 450 ppmv; with no ocean burial of fossil fuel emissions, the rate of emissions has to be cut drastically after the year 2010, whereas oceanic burial of 2 GtC/yr allows for a smoother transition to alternative energy sources.
Author Keywords: Fossil fuel emissions; Global carbon cycle; Ocean disposal

Authors: Medrano-Cerda G.A., Eldukhri E.E., Caldwell D.G.
Title: Optimal control of a biped robot
Affiliations: Dept. Electronic and Electrical Eng., University of Salford, Salford M5 4WT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Medrano-Cerda, G.A., Dept. Electronic and Electrical Eng., University of Salford, Salford M5 4WT, United Kingdom; Eldukhri, E.E., Dept. Electronic and Electrical Eng., University of Salford, Salford M5 4WT, United Kingdom; Caldwell, D.G., Dept. Electronic and Electrical Eng., University of Salford, Salford M5 4WT, United Kingdom
Abstract: An eight degree of freedom biped robot actuated by DC motors is considered. The robot can walk along the sagittal plane on smooth level terrain.The control sytem is essentially an observer based controller utilising optimal state feedback, integral action and feed forward control. The robot posture is controlled by selecting constant reference set points for the control system. Locomotion is achieved by suitably modifying the reference set points. The robot walks a predetermined number of steps with a step length of approximately 0.3m and a walking speed of about 0.03m/s. The paper also explores the design of a bipedal robot using Pneumatic Muscle actuators. Muscle co-ordination and control sequences for striding and standing activities are considered. It is shown that these actuators are very capable of providing a reliable drive source with linear actuation, low mass, fast response, compliant energy storage and simple construction.
Author Keywords: Balancing control, robot actuators; Biped robot; Legged locomotion

Authors: Van Deursen W.
Title: Integrating dynamic environmental models in GIS: The development of a prototype dynamic simulation language
Affiliations: Resource Analysis, Zuiderstraat 110, 2611 SJ Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Deursen, W., Resource Analysis, Zuiderstraat 110, 2611 SJ Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: A modelling language is presented to run dynamic models in a GIS environment. The focus of the language is on environmental applications. The approach taken was to design and build a GIS which includes a modelling language for the formulation of the dynamic behaviour of environmental systems. The spatial modelling language allows for a component-based modelling approach without the burden of technical implementation of database and algorithm details. Generic components, representing storages and fluxes of mass or energy, can be linked to create hydrological and environmental models.

Authors: Klyachko A.V., Naumova N.M., Potashev S.I., Razin V.I., Spevak V.Ya., Dronov V.V., Stifutkin A.A., Sumarokov A.V.
Title: System of multiwire proportional chambers and data-acquisition equipment in spectrometry of medium-energy particles

Abstract: Multiwire proportional chambers with an operating area of 120 × 120 and 380 × 380 mm2, and with a positional resolution of 1.4 mm are described. They are intended for work at a high pulse loading. Chamber components were made from the epoxy compound according to the vacuum casting technique. The information coding method was applied to the system of data acquisition, which made it possible to substantially reduce the number of electronic channels and to provide cyclic storage of the information on wire states in a time interval of 640 ns with a resolution of 40 ns in the intermediate memory. © 1996 MAHK Hayka/Interperiodica Publishing.

Authors: Ivanov V.V., Knyazev A.K., Kutsenko A.V., Matsveiko A.A., Mikhailov Yu.A., Osetrov V.P., Popov A.I., Sklizkov G.V., Starodub A.N.
