Authors: Hachigo A., Richie S.M., Malocha D.C.
Title: Characteristics of ZnO/diamond/Si SAW resonators
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual IEEE International Frequency Control Symposium
Affiliations: Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hachigo, A., Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States; Richie, S.M., Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States; Malocha, D.C., Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States
Abstract: The surface acoustic wave (SAW) resonator response of ZnO/diamond/Si layered structures are calculated and discussed including velocity dispersion. Smith's second equivalent circuit including energy storage effects is used to calculate the resonator response. The effect of velocity dispersion appears for the shift of resonant frequency to the expected center frequency, and appears for the band width of resonator becomes narrower than that of non dispersive case. The coupling of modes equation is modified for the velocity dispersion to explain these effects. The reflection coefficients of gratings are calculated for velocity dispersive case and the non velocity dispersive case. These results agree with the response calculated by the equivalent circuit model. With assuming the deviation of velocity dispersive be small neighboring the resonance area, the effect of velocity dispersion is explained in theoretically. The ZnO/diamond/Si SAW resonators provide high frequency operation and the high quality factor (Q) SAW resonators due to the velocity dispersion.
Index Keywords: Acoustic wave reflection; Acoustic wave velocity; Equivalent circuits; Natural frequencies; Resonators; Semiconducting diamonds; Semiconducting silicon; Semiconducting zinc compounds; Zinc oxide; Coupling of modes equation; Reflection coefficients; Velocity dispersion; Acoustic surface wave devices

Authors: Yi Ouyang, Xu Fudong, Xie Xishun, Zhu Donghua
Title: Hopping current and charge storage in polymer electret
Affiliations: Southeast Univ, Jiangshu, China
Authors with affiliations: Yi, Ouyang, Southeast Univ, Jiangshu, China; Xu, Fudong, Southeast Univ, Jiangshu, China; Xie, Xishun, Southeast Univ, Jiangshu, China; Zhu, Donghua, Southeast Univ, Jiangshu, China
Abstract: In this paper, the formulas of hopping current in polymer and polymer electret are derived. By these formulas, a theoretical discharge equation of polymer electret can be derived. The step-size of hopping electrons, calculated from the isothermal decay data of electrets, are about 10-8m. The average size of crystalline region in polymers are also 10-8m in order. This supports the above equations experimentally. All the facts and points in this paper support the suggestion that firmly stored charges are almost trapped in the bands of crystalline regions of electret.
Index Keywords: Band structure; Calculations; Crystal defects; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electrons; Polymers; Hopping current; Isothermal decay; Polymer electret; Electrets

Authors: Goldstein Jonathan R., Koretz Binyamin, Harats Yehuda
Title: Field test of the Electric FuelTM zinc-air refuelable battery system for electric vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electric Fuel Ltd, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Goldstein, Jonathan R., Electric Fuel Ltd, Jerusalem, Israel; Koretz, Binyamin, Electric Fuel Ltd, Jerusalem, Israel; Harats, Yehuda, Electric Fuel Ltd, Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: The Electric Fuel Limited (EFL) zinc-air refuelable battery system will be tested over the next two years in a number of electric vehicle demonstration projects, the largest of which is an $18-million, 64-vehicle, two-year test sponsored chiefly by Deutsche Post AG (the German Post Corporation). The German field test is the largest-ever EV fleet test of a single advanced-battery technology. It also represents a marked departure from other EV test and demonstration programs, in that it is being sponsored not by government or electric utility interests, but by large fleet operators committed to shifting significant proportions of their vehicles to electric over the next 5-10 years. The Electric Fuel battery has specific energy of 200 Wh/kg, an achievement that allows electric vehicles to go as far on a charge as conventionally fueled vehicles go on a tank of gasoline. Fast, convenient refueling eliminates the need for lengthy electrical recharging, and clean, centralized zinc regeneration plants ensure the most efficient and environment-friendly use of energy resources.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Equipment testing; Storage battery vehicles; Electric Fuel Limited (EFL) zinc air batteries; Refuelable batteries; Specific energy; Secondary batteries

Authors: Schempp Ellery, Jackson William D.
Title: Systems considerations in capacitive energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Cryo Energy Systems, Inc, Medford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schempp, Ellery, Cryo Energy Systems, Inc, Medford, United States; Jackson, William D., Cryo Energy Systems, Inc, Medford, United States
Abstract: Capacitive energy storage systems are being developed as an alternative to SMES for utility power quality applications and to supplement batteries in electric vehicles. Systems considerations show that the low voltages of `ultra-capacitors' impose a high penalty in terms of increased component count, greater complexity in the power electronics used for charging and discharging, and large IR voltage drops. The consequent dissipation and reductions in efficiency exacerbate thermal management and stresses on the power electronics. Alternative strategies using ceramic hyper-capacitors in the 800-1500 V range will be discussed in terms of system cost and performance. A system analysis indicates that hypercapacitors at 12 Wh/kg have higher effective energy density than ultra-capacitors at 20 Wh/kg when useable/recoverable energy, packing density, and system issues are taken into account. The power quality delivered to the load, the cost, weight, and volume of the power converters used in discharging and recharging are shown to be essential considerations. Cryogenic operation appears to offer numerous attractive performance benefits.
Index Keywords: Ceramic capacitors; Charging (batteries); Electric batteries; Electric vehicles; Low temperature operations; Power converters; Power electronics; Systems analysis; Thermal stress; Voltage control; Ceramic hypercapacitors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Dermott Jeff C., DeGruson James A., Miller Lee E.
Title: Large capacity NiH2 battery cells for advanced, high-power spacecraft applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dermott, Jeff C., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States; DeGruson, James A., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States; Miller, Lee E., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States
Abstract: With space based communications requiring large amounts requiring large amounts of power and high reliability, the nickel-hydrogen battery with its long cycle life is a very desirable power supply. To meet the demands of the aerospace community, Eagle-Picher has continued to improve on the battery's specific energy while producing a lower cost unit. At Eagle-Picher's commercial aerospace battery plant in Joplin, Missouri, a 120 ampere-hour nickel-hydrogen battery cell is in production. This cell combines a number of design improvements which result in a lower unit cost and a higher specific energy without sacrificing the battery system's high reliability. In achieving a twenty-five percent cost reduction in the cell, a number of issues have been considered. To maintain the nickel-hydrogen reliability heritage, all changes have been tested, evaluated and proven to have no degrading effects. The success of this program in producing a large diameter nickel-hydrogen cell lends the availability of the technology to be applied to larger and more powerful cells. This paper details the development and production of the 4.5 inch (155 mm) diameter nickel-hydrogen cell technology and discusses the suitability of this design being applied to larger cells (e.g. up to 300 ampere-hours in this common diameter).
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Nickel compounds; Product design; Space applications; Spacecraft power supplies; Nickel hydrogen batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Hafele Wolf
Title: Concept of an International Monitored Retrievable Storage System
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institute
Authors with affiliations: Hafele, Wolf
Abstract: The International Monitored Retrievable Storage System (IMRSS) was created to provide in an international format monitored retrievable storage for irradiated fuel elements from nuclear power reactors and for plutonium from civilian sources as well as from demilitarized armament. The establishment of worldwide facilities with common design standards that permit the physical protection and management of these materials and which facilitate efficient international safeguards is proposed. The commercial operation is to be supervised by an appropriate political body in close connection with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). Scientists from weapons laboratories in Russia and the USA are currently elaborating the concept of IMRSS.
Index Keywords: Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Energy policy; Nuclear fuel elements; Nuclear materials safeguards; Nuclear reactors; Plutonium; Spent fuels; International monitored retrievable storage system (IMRSS); Nuclear materials storage; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Morimura Hiroki, Shibata Nobutaro
Title: 1-V 1-Mb SRAM for portable equipment
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: NTT LSI Lab, Kanagawa-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morimura, Hiroki, NTT LSI Lab, Kanagawa-ken, Japan; Shibata, Nobutaro, NTT LSI Lab, Kanagawa-ken, Japan
Abstract: Low-power and high-speed circuit techniques are described for 1-V battery operated SRAMs. A design concept is shown that uses two kinds of MOSFETs different in threshold voltages to reduce power dissipation due to the subthreshold leakage current in both standby and active modes. We propose a step-down boosted wordline scheme to reduce power dissipation in the memory array to 57% while accelerating the sensing speed. A novel bidirectional differential internal-bus architecture provides data transmission that is 45% faster than in the conventional architecture, yet without area or power penalty. A charge-recycling I/O buffer incorporating a data transition detector reduces the power dissipation of the I/O buffer by 30%. A 1-Mb SRAM designed using these techniques and 0.5-μm CMOS technology demonstrated 4.8-mW power dissipation and a 75-ns address access time with standby power of 1.2-μW at a 1-V power supply.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Current voltage characteristics; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electronic equipment manufacture; Energy dissipation; Leakage currents; MOSFET devices; Portable equipment; Power supply circuits; Data transition detector; Subthreshold leakage current; Threshold voltages; Random access storage

Authors: Wicks Frank, Martino John P.
Title: Design and analysis of a simpler DC to AC power transfer circuit for residential size photovoltaic panels
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Union Coll, Schenectady, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wicks, Frank, Union Coll, Schenectady, United States; Martino, John P., Union Coll, Schenectady, United States
Abstract: The evolution of photovoltaic (PV) based power generation systems for residential applications has been hindered by the high cost required to operate in a non-isolated mode with respect to the electric power grid. The inverter type circuits used by some utilities to interface photovoltaic energy with the AC power grid are prohibitively expensive for residential use. Thus, in residential applications, the energy conversion potential and cost savings potential of the PV are never fully realized. The storage of PV energy in batteries is a step toward enhanced utilization of the PV but is still an isolated mode operation. The basic power transfer circuit described in this paper will provide a simple, cost effective means of interfacing PV panels with the electric utility in relatively low power residential applications. The residential PV panel will therefore operate in a non-isolated mode and function as a generator on the electric grid which will result in a decrease in net power consumption and a corresponding reduction in electric utility costs. Non-isolated operation of the residential PV energy conversion system through the use of a power transfer circuit will result in a reduction in system payback time as well as decreased use of finite supply fossil fuels and the harmful emissions resulting from their combustion.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric network analysis; Photovoltaic cells; Solar power generation; Transformer magnetic circuits; Electric power grids; Photovoltaic panels; Power transfer circuits; Power converters

Authors: Rose M.F., Merryman S.A.
Title: Electrochemical capacitor technology for actuator applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rose, M.F., Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States; Merryman, S.A., Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Abstract: Chemical Double Layer (CDL) and pseudocapacitor are supercapacitor technologies applied to electric propulsion and electric actuation in terms of energy density, power density, availability and cost. The development of CDL capacitors was brought about by the interface between a conductor and a liquid electrolyte. The key parameters for the double layer as an energy storage media are the value of the dielectric constant with the region in which the charge is stored, the thickness of the layer and the voltage at which the layer fails.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Capacitance; Electric energy storage; Permittivity; Chemical double layer (CDL) capacitors; Electric actuation; Electrochemical capacitor technology; Pseudocapacitors; Relative dielectric constants; Ruthenium oxides; Capacitors

Authors: Dickens James C., Bridges John, Kristiansen M.
Title: Compact modulator using inductive energy storage and a solid state opening switch
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dickens, James C., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Bridges, John, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Kristiansen, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Abstract: A compact modulator system using inductive energy storage and a diode as an opening switch was investigated. The system was designed around a Russian diode that has characteristics similar to those of a step-recovery diode except that the reverse current density is 10-100 times larger than in U.S. manufactured diodes. The main goal of this investigation was to characterize the Russian diode and develop an understanding of its operation for possible improvement and integration into nanosecond pulse generators. The basic modulator circuit designed uses IGBT's in the forward pumping circuit and is capable of delivering 5 kV at 400 A into the diode. Using this forward pumping circuit, diode voltage and current measurements were made at several input power levels. In addition, data obtained using this test stand was used to produce a computer simulation model of the diode for a more thorough circuit analysis.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Computer simulation; Electric current measurement; Electric energy storage; Semiconductor diodes; Semiconductor switches; Voltage measurement; Forward pumping circuits; Inductive energy storage; Insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT); Russian diodes; Solid state opening switches; Modulators

Authors: Nerbun William J.
Title: Battery energy storage systems as a solution for premium power quality
Affiliations: AC Battery Corp, East Troy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nerbun, William J., AC Battery Corp, East Troy, United States
Abstract: Voltage sags and power outages pose serious problems for many commercial and industrial power consumers with sensitive microprocessor controlled equipment. Recent studies have indicated that 95% of all power problems occur when power is 'disrupted' for 5 seconds or less. For those customers who normally have a 1 or 2 MVA service, a conventional uninterruptable power supply (UPS) can be an inappropriate solution. As an alternative, AC Battery Corporation has developed a 2 MVA/10 Second Power Quality System designed to eliminate power disturbances. The PQ2000 provides immediate response capacity appropriate for short duration, high-energy discharges. The PQ2000 Power Quality System dynamically disconnects critical loads from the utility and seamlessly transfers the load to battery power within approximately 1/4 cycle. The PQ2000 Power Quality System shown in Figure 1 draws from existing technologies and products that are commercially available today. The system combines mature battery energy storage technology with advanced power switching and sophisticated power conversion techniques to produce a new category of power quality protection devices for large industrial and commercial power consumers. Markets targeted for distribution include semiconductor manufacturers, hospitals, chemical processing plants, automated manufacturing facilities, biotechnology firms, data centers and other communications facilities with critical or sensitive transactions.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric fault currents; Electric lines; Electric power system protection; Industrial applications; Performance; Short circuit currents; Transients; Battery energy storage systems; Power disturbance protection; Electric batteries

Authors: Hirano S.
Title: Effective heat utilization of diurnal range of atmospheric temperature
Affiliations: Natl Inst for Resources and, Environment, Tukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirano, S., Natl Inst for Resources and, Environment, Tukuba, Japan
Abstract: Behavior of a heat utilization system using the diurnal range of atmospheric temperature in the summer is characterized by numerical simulation. The system consists of a radiator, a thermal energy storage tank, a fan-coil cooler, and an electric cooler. Conditions for the calculation are assumed from the actual weather and characteristics of appliances. Total consumption of electric power is used for evaluating the system performance. The larger the volume of the storage tank becomes, the smaller the consumption becomes, which relates with quantity of the liquid circulating between the tank and the radiator. The consumption is smaller in case the radiator is operated for a period of some limited hours than in case through the night. To decrease the consumption, there are also the most suitable values in the flow rate of the radiator pump and in the operating temperature of the fan-coil cooler. This system has a possibility to reduce demand for electricity or shift the demand to off-peak hours.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric temperature; Computer simulation; Energy utilization; Heat storage; Heating equipment; Diurnal range; Heat utilization system; Space heating

Authors: Gengenbach T.R., Li S., Chatelier R.C., Griesser H.J.
Title: Compositional changes on storage of polymeric biomaterial surfaces prepared by RF glow discharges
Source title: Transactions of the Annual Meeting of the Society for Biomaterials in conjunction with the International Biomaterials Symposium
Affiliations: CSIRO, Clayton, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gengenbach, T.R., CSIRO, Clayton, Australia; Li, S., CSIRO, Clayton, Australia; Chatelier, R.C., CSIRO, Clayton, Australia; Griesser, H.J., CSIRO, Clayton, Australia
Abstract: The long-term changes in the composition of polymeric biomaterial surfaces were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy in order to characterize the chemical and physical processes that affect the storage of surface layers after modification by RF glow discharge. The oxygen content of n-heptylamine polymers increased with storage time while the N 1s binding energy shifted from a position characteristic of amines to one that is characteristic of amides. Amide and carbonyl groups were detected in the samples. Moreover, surface reorientations that transport polar groups away from the air interface were detected in XPS analyses. These compositional changes are expected to affect protein adsorption and cell colonization.
Index Keywords: Polymeric biomaterial surfaces; Binding energy; Contact angle; Glow discharges; Oxidation; Surface structure; Surface treatment; Wetting; Biopolymers

Authors: Wolfe Philip R.
Title: Photovoltaics: built-in power generation
Affiliations: Intersolar Group, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wolfe, Philip R., Intersolar Group, United Kingdom
Abstract: Photovoltaics is the technology that converts light into energy. This technology does away with all those low-tech wires and cable and generate electricity on site using solid state technology. The power is controlled and supplied to the load as needed allowing for the individual climatic conditions at site - and usually incorporating power storage for use during darkness or in periods of low light levels. Each system is designed individually using computer-aided design and computer databases of past experience to create the individual system design. Photovoltaics can be seen in every solar calculator. The major breakthrough for the incorporation of PV into product designs came in the early 1990's with the commercial production of thin film solar cells.
Index Keywords: Built in power generation; Photovoltaics; Plasma deposition; Thin film silicon solar cells; Chemical vapor deposition; Photoelectricity; Plasma applications; Product design; Semiconducting glass; Silicon solar cells; Thin film devices; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Amjadi Houman
Title: Charge storage in double layers of silicon dioxide and silicon nitride
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Amjadi, Houman, Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Silicon dioxide has long been studied for applications as electret layer in micromachined devices. However it could already be demonstrated that double layers of silicon dioxide and silicon nitride possess higher charge stability than well investigated single layers [1]. In this contribution experimental results for double layers of SiO2 and Si3N4 with different compositions will be reported and discussed. The investigated layers were prepared by thermal oxidation of silicon substrate (SiO2) and APCVD (Si3N4). The samples were charged by the point-to-grid corona method. The charge decay was observed by measuring the surface potential under different environmental conditions (elevated temperature and humidity) which will be described briefly. Besides results from TSC measurements will be presented and compared to those of a corresponding single layer of SiO2. In addition to improved electret properties the internal stress in the investigated double layers can be adjusted by a proper thickness ratio of oxide layer to nitride layers. Therefore double layers of silicon dioxide and nitride seem to be promising electrets for fabrication of integrated sensors and actuators.
Index Keywords: Chemical vapor deposition; Dielectric films; Dielectric properties; Electrets; Electric charge; Electric current measurement; Residual stresses; Silica; Silicon nitride; Thermodynamic stability; Thermooxidation; Atmospheric pressure chemical vapor deposition; Charge decay; Double layers; Point to grid corona method; Thermally stimulated current; Electric energy storage

Authors: Li Ming, Xi ShiGuang
Title: Investigation on the efficiency of thermal energy storage for the steam accumulator
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and Environment, ICEE
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Tongji, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Ming, Tongji Univ, Tongji, China; Xi, ShiGuang, Tongji Univ, Tongji, China
Abstract: In order to determine the ability of thermal energy storage of the steam accumulator, a new parameter, the volume-efficiency (VE), is proposed to determine the optimum design of the inner structure of the steam accumulator. This paper gives the definition of VE. The values of VE for series of inner structure sizes are obtained based on the temperature-field and the pressure in the steam accumulator. Thus the relation between VE and the diameter of tubular guide is obtained. The tendency of VE vs. the height of nozzles can also be available. An equation of VE is presented as function of diameter of the tubular guide as well as the height of the nozzles. From this equation, the optimum design of the 100 m3 vertical steam accumulator is gained. The VE value for the real one standing in Shanghai Mineral Water Plant is obtained. The result has good agreement with its operation.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Nozzles; Vertical steam accumulator; Volume efficiency parameter; Steam accumulators

Authors: Zhai QingGuo, Lu ZhongWu, Cai JiuJu
Title: Optimal gas scheduling in an iron and steel plant
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy and Environment, ICEE
Affiliations: Fushun Petroleum Inst, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhai, QingGuo, Fushun Petroleum Inst, China; Lu, ZhongWu, Fushun Petroleum Inst, China; Cai, JiuJu, Fushun Petroleum Inst, China
Abstract: A goal programming model is developed for the optimal scheduling of gas in an iron and steel plant. In the model the gas stored in the gas holder is divided into three parts. Each part is given a different price in order to make the gas stored in the gas holder keep at a reasonable level. The model can give the optimal gas allocation scheme whenever the gas is abundant or in shortage. Numerous simulation computations of the model prove that it is feasible and effective.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Energy conservation; Gas fuel storage; Gas holders; Iron and steel plants; Mathematical models; Mathematical programming; Optimal gas allocation; Gas supply

Authors: Clark Robert A., Smith Richard N., Jensen Michael K.
Title: Experimental study of waste heat recovery from a residential refrigerator
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, Robert A., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States; Smith, Richard N., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States; Jensen, Michael K., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States
Abstract: The design, construction and testing of an integrated heat recovery system for the enhancement of the performance of a residential refrigerator and provide preheated water for an electric water heater is discussed. A retrofitted commercial, indirect-heated hot water tank serves as a water cooled condenser which operates in parallel with the air-cooled condenser tubing, either one active during refrigerator operation. A 35 °C temperature rise in the storage tank in about 100 hours was observed for the `no water usage' case, while simulations on the `with water usage' case indicated 18-20% energy saving over long period operation, sub-marginal for residential applications, but significant for commercial scale refrigeration.
Index Keywords: Condensers (liquefiers); Energy conservation; Equipment testing; Machine design; Refrigerators; Water heaters; Residential refrigerators; Waste heat utilization

Authors: Abele M., Bauer H., Buck R., Tamme R., Woerner A.
Title: Design and test results of a receiver-reactor for solar methane reforming
Affiliations: Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Abele, M., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany; Bauer, H., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany; Buck, R., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany; Tamme, R., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany; Woerner, A., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt fuer, Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR), Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: The paper reports on results of the first test series with a volumetric receiver-reactor (SCR), performing solar CO2-reforming of methane in a closed thermochemical loop. Between August 1994 and May 1995 the receiver was operated in the closed loop system at the solar tower facility of Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel, in series with a methanator to release the stored energy. During these tests the receiver design data were successfully demonstrated. Methane conversion levels were up to 84% of the content in the methanator exit. Methane contents in the receiver exit went down to 2%. The absorbed power peaked at 286 kW, with a receiver operating pressure of about 3.5 barabs. During the tests some problems occurred with the window due to deposits. After the replacement of a window tests were continued without further problems. A second test period is foreseen for late 1995 with an improved absorber insert.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Equipment testing; Reforming reactions; Solar absorbers; Closed thermochemical loop; Solar tower; Volumetric receiver reactor (SCR); Solar collectors

Authors: LaBel Kenneth A., Moran Amy K., Hawkins Donald K., Sanders Anthony B., Seidleck Christina M., Kim Hak S., Forney James E., Stassinopoulos E.G., Marshall Paul, Dale Cheryl, Kinnison James, Carkhuff Bliss
Title: Current single event effect test results for candidate spacecraft electronics

Authors: Rodder Mark, Hwang Jeong-Mo, Chen Ih-Chin
Title: Scalability of conventional and sidewall-sealed LOCOS technology for 256-Mbit DRAM array and periphery isolation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, TX,, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodder, Mark, Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, TX,, USA, United States; Hwang, Jeong-Mo, Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, TX,, USA, United States; Chen, Ih-Chin, Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, TX,, USA, United States
Abstract: LOCOS technology is being investigated for applicability to 256 Mbit DRAM applications in the memory array (with active region pitch < 0.6 μm) as well as the periphery. In this paper, LOCOS isolation is demonstrated for array n --n - spacing < 0.2 μm for 256 Mbit DRAM array and for n +-n + (and p +-p +) spacing < 0.35 μm for DRAM periphery. Array nMOSFETs with small active width of 0.2 μm are demonstrated with I off < lfA/μm (V B = IV) at L o = 0.2 μm while maintaining low V T (<V T spec = 1.5 V at V B = 4 V) at L o = 0.3 μm in accordance with DRAM pass transistor design. These key results are obtained with appropriate LDD dose and energy, sidewall sealed LOCOS isolation, and 1100°C field oxidation to reduce both field oxide thinning and active width encroachment. MOSFETs with sidewall sealed LOCOS show small narrow width effect, ΔV T/ΔW, and no sub-V T `double-hump'. In contrast, conventional LOCOS results in high ΔV T/ΔW for MOSFETs with active width < 0.4 μm while recessed LOCOS causes sub- V T `double-hump' for large active width MOSFETs.
Index Keywords: DRAM; LOCOS technology; Design; MOSFET devices; Oxidation; Technology; Random access storage

Authors: Malaspina F.P.
Title: Lithium-ion rechargeable batteries and the portable communications user's expectations
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Technical Conference - Society of Vacuum Coaters
Affiliations: Motorola, Lawrenceville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malaspina, F.P., Motorola, Lawrenceville, United States
Abstract: The impact of energy storage technology on the vacuum coating industry is discussed. The classical electrochemical system had little to do with vacuum coating. However, as progress moved toward a shape change in the electronics industry, a fundamental change began in energy storage devices. The battery industry is now becoming akin to making coated polymer films rather than pasting battery plates. The technological forecasts from the battery industry do not include any major breakthroughs after lithium-ion in the 1990s, but there is hope that they can accelerate the rate of improvement to existing technology.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electrolytic cells; Lithium batteries; Mobile telecommunication systems; Secondary batteries; Substrates; Thin films; Electrolytic thin films; Lithium ion rechargeable batteries; Vacuum deposited coatings

Authors: Mohapatra G.R., Zayegh A., Kalam A., Coulter R.J.
Title: Issues of concern in a distribution network with non-conventional energy sources, energy storage and power electronic devices
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Save Energy Research Group, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Mohapatra, G.R., Save Energy Research Group, Australia; Zayegh, A., Save Energy Research Group, Australia; Kalam, A., Save Energy Research Group, Australia; Coulter, R.J., Save Energy Research Group, Australia
Abstract: Distribution networks must be carefully controlled in order to maintain an acceptable power supply quality. Advances in power electronics and control technology have introduced powerful tools to power utilities, and more recently the concept of custom power has evolved. The impact of renewable energy installations and energy storage connected to the utility grid is an important issue concerning the technical and economic viability of harnessing these emerging energy source. Connecting dispersed source of generation and storage battery through power electronics combined with solid state circuit breakers, static condenser and dynamic voltage regulators with utility has several technical complications for the operation and control aspects of the whole system. This paper discusses the issues of concern and advantages of such a system to manage the generation, storage and distribution of power.
Index Keywords: Custom power concept; Electric power utility grid; Nonconventional energy sources; Renewable energy installations; Static condenser (Statcon); Control theory; Electric batteries; Electric circuit breakers; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric power transmission networks; Electric power utilization; Electric utilities; Energy conservation; Power electronics; Renewable energy resources; Voltage regulators; Electric power distribution

Authors: Ghetti Andrea, Selmi Luca, Bez Roberto, Sangiorgi Enrico
Title: Monte Carlo simulation of low voltage hot carrier effects in non volatile memory cells
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Univ of Bologna, Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Ghetti, Andrea, Univ of Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Selmi, Luca, Univ of Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Bez, Roberto, Univ of Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Sangiorgi, Enrico, Univ of Bologna, Bologna, Italy
Abstract: Recent experiments on MOSFETs and non-volatile memory cells [1] indicated a non-trivial bias and temperature dependence of substrate (IB) and gate (IG) currents whenever the drain voltage (VDS) becomes comparable to the critical values corresponding to the band gap, and the Si-SiO2 barrier energies. In this paper, the experiments of [1] are analyzed by means of detailed Monte Carlo simulations. The role held by electron-electron scattering (EES), impact ionization feedback (IIF), band gap variations with temperature (ΔEG) and tunneling through the barrier in explaining the experimental results is pointed out.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electron scattering; Electron tunneling; Energy gap; Hot carriers; Ionization; Monte Carlo methods; MOSFET devices; Silica; Silicon; Floating gate transistors; Impact ionization feedback; Nonvolatile memory cells; Random access storage

Authors: James David
Title: Advanced series compensator using power electronic switches
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: James, David, Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper investigates the possibility of using a voltage sourced inverter (VSI) as a series compensation (Sercom) scheme for use on electricity transmission lines. The studies indicate that the scheme is more flexible than traditional methods of series compensation and has the ability to respond quickly to fluctuations in demand. This is because the gate turn off (GTO) thyristors in the inverter allow a continuously variable voltage across the capacitive energy store.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric inverters; Electric switchgear; Power electronics; Thyristors; Voltage control; Advance series compensator; Power electronic switches; Series compensation scheme; Voltage sourced inverters (VSI); Electric power transmission

Authors: Ponce M., Arau J.
Title: Fluorescent lamp electronic ballast for photovoltaic applications using the class E amplifier
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Centro Nacional de Investigacion y, Desarrollo Tecnologico CENIDET, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Ponce, M., Centro Nacional de Investigacion y, Desarrollo Tecnologico CENIDET, Mexico; Arau, J., Centro Nacional de Investigacion y, Desarrollo Tecnologico CENIDET, Mexico
Abstract: In this paper, the design and construction of an electronic ballast for instant start fluorescent lamps supplied from 12 V and based on class E amplifier is presented. The use of class E amplifiers in ballast for fluorescent lamps presents large advantages as for example: high power density, simple structure (uses only one transistor), high efficiency and optimum driving of the lamp. However, its application is limited to low voltage and power. One of the application that complies with these characteristics are the fluorescent lamps used in the photovoltaic systems, since in these systems, the solar energy is stored in batteries of 12 V and the used lamps are of 20 to 38 W. The design process has been simplified with the aid of graphics and mathematical programs. The electronic ballast designed, drives a lamp of 21 W and works at a frequency of 400 kHz. Dimming is very easy to accomplish varying the switching frequency; during the almost all variation range.
Index Keywords: Amplifiers (electronic); Computer aided design; Dimming (lamps); Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Energy conversion; Fluorescent lamps; Mathematical programming; Photovoltaic cells; Class E amplifiers; High power density; Optimum lamp driving; Ballasts (lamp)

Authors: Wyczalek Floyd A.
Title: Hybrid electric vehicles (EVS-13 Osaka)
Affiliations: FW Lilly Inc, Bloomfield Hills, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, Floyd A., FW Lilly Inc, Bloomfield Hills, United States
Abstract: A comparative analysis of the key features of hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) is presented. The comparisons show that the focus is on series-type hybrid systems, with the exception of the parallel Subaru and Suzuki HEV. Also, two major manufacturers are turning to the hybrid concept in their search for solutions to two key EV issues: limited driving range and, heating and air conditioning, associated with the low energy density characteristic of batteries.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Electric batteries; Electric motor generator sets; Electric propulsion; Heating; Traction motors; Hybrid electric vehicles (HEV); Series type hybrid systems; Storage battery vehicles

Authors: Spyker R.L., Nelms R.M.
Title: Optimization of double layer capacitor arrays
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spyker, R.L., Auburn Univ, United States; Nelms, R.M., Auburn Univ, United States
Abstract: The double layer capacitor was developed in the late 1960's by SOHIO Corporation, with further development continued by NEC and Matsushita in Japan. In 1978 a commercial product was introduced by Matsushita, the Panasonic Gold capacitor. This recent technological advancement has mainly been applied in computer memory back-up systems, but with recent increases in double layer capacitor energy storage levels higher power applications have become a real possibility. This paper examines the design of a capacitor bank interfaced to a constant power load though a DC-DC converter. A numerical procedure has been implemented in a program which determines the dependence of run time, efficiency and energy utilization on the capacitor array dimensions, given the empirically determined capacitor parameters as well as a specified converter output power. Capacitor bank design calculations made using this numerical procedure have been verified using a commercial DC-DC converter.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electrodes; Energy utilization; Optimization; Power converters; DC DC converter; Double layer capacitor; Equivalent series resistance; Capacitors

Authors: Choi Y.D., Kim S.G.
Title: Viscoelastic properties of electrorheological fluids
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Applied Mechanics Division, AMD
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical Eng., Korea 3rd Military Academy, P.O. Box#9, Youngchun City, Kyungpook, 771-849, South Korea; Korea Institute of Energy Research, 72-2, Jang-dong, Yusung-ku, Taejon, 305-343, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, Y.D., Dept. of Mechanical Eng., Korea 3rd Military Academy, P.O. Box#9, Youngchun City, Kyungpook, 771-849, South Korea; Kim, S.G., Korea Institute of Energy Research, 72-2, Jang-dong, Yusung-ku, Taejon, 305-343, South Korea
Abstract: Electrorheological (ER) fluid's storage shear modulus (G') and loss factor(η) have been directly measured using small amplitude forced oscillating rheometer as a function of oscillating frequency, strain amplitude and applied electric field. Two types of experiment were performed; (a) frequency sweep and (b) amplitude sweep. Two kinds of sample were employed for this experiment; cornstarch in corn oil and zeolite particles in silicone oil. The storage shear modulus(G') was a strong function of driving frequency. Generally, G' increased with driving frequency. On the other hand, the loss factor(η) was not well behaved as storage modulus, but as the driving frequency increases η slightly decreases was the trend of the material's characteristics. Also G' was a strong function of strain amplitude. Generally, G' decreased with increasing strain, but η increases slightly with increasing strain amplitude. For G', cornstarch in corn oil ER fluid has higher values than zeolite based fluid as we increased the applied electric field. On the other hand, zeolite based fluid has higher values for η. There is a reasonable agreement between theory and experiment.
Index Keywords: Electric field effects; Energy dissipation; Frequency response; Rheology; Shear stress; Strain; Viscoelasticity; Electrorheology; Suspensions (fluids)

Authors: Roesel Jr. John F., Morash Richard T.
Title: Advancement of power technology using written-pole motors and generators - an overview
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roesel Jr., John F., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States; Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: Written-pole machine technology uses a method to change the magnetic polarity of the rotor field in a rotating machine, while the machine is operating. This effectively changes the number of poles and can produce a constant frequency - variable speed machine. There are numerous applications where this feature can be put to good use, and a few have been successfully developed. Two of these are important in improving power quality and in helping to reduce manufacturing costs for a variety of products. The paper will introduce a written-pole uninterruptible power system that uses flywheel energy storage instead of electrochemical batteries. This system protects computers and other sensitive electronics. The paper will also introduce a written-pole motor that rides through power blackouts of 10 to 20 seconds while delivering useful load. This is important to maintain critical processes such as conveyors, pumps and combustion air flow. Some written-pole machines are commercially available now, and this overview will discuss those as well as plans for future applications for motors and generators.
Index Keywords: Electric generators; Electric motors; Electronic equipment; Flywheels; Rotating machinery; Rotors (windings); Technological forecasting; Flywheel energy storage; Magnetic polarity; Variable speed machine; Written pole machines; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Lu Tingji
Title: Charge storage in Teflon AF films
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Tingji, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The behavior of charge storage in corona charged and electron-beam irradiated Teflon AF films is investigated. Teflon AF film of 2 to 4 μm thickness were prepared on glass substrates with Al and graphite electrodes by spin coating. Details of the experimental results are reported and discussed. For example, the measuring result of the laser-induced pressure pulse method shows that the velocity of the pressure pulse is 1.4 km/s. The maximum surface density depends mostly on the dielectric strength of the film, and the maximum potential of the free surface on the sample is directly proportional to the film thickness. The application of heat before, during or after charging can effectively improve the charge stability.
Index Keywords: Dielectric properties; Electric charge; Electric current measurement; Electrodes; Film preparation; Irradiation; Polytetrafluoroethylenes; Substrates; Thin films; Corona charging method; Electron beam charging method; Isothermal surface voltage decay; Open circuit thermally stimulated current; Spin coating; Electric energy storage

Authors: Perrone David E., Klekotka Matt, Di Stefano Salvador
Title: Effect of cell design and storage conditions on the cycle life performance silver-zinc cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perrone, David E., Jet Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, United States; Klekotka, Matt, Jet Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, United States; Di Stefano, Salvador, Jet Propulsion Lab, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: The Mars Pathfinder spacecraft is expected to utilize a single eighteen cell, forty ampere-hour, silver-zinc battery. The calendar life clock for the battery begins with the addition of KOH electrolyte to the constituent cells by the vendor. A period of battery inactivity begins with shipment of the battery to JPL and then on to Florida. This inactivity continues while the battery is inverted for four months prior to launch. Following launch, the battery will be inactive for 7 months except for several shallow discharges associated with trajectory correction maneuvers. The battery is expected to deliver forty ampere-hours during entry, descent and landing at Mars. Thirty shallow depth of discharge cycles are planned during Mars surface operations. A study was undertaken to examine the impact of various cell design and storage conditions on the cycle life performance of silver-zinc cells. Eight 4 cell groups were assembled and tested. Variations in the number of separator layers, operating temperature, and state of charge were examined. As expected, a greater number of separator layers, lower states of charge, and lower temperatures tend to yield better cycle life performance following eleven months of inactivity. This study was undertaken with `off the shelf' cells purchased from Eagle Picher Inc., of Joplin, Missouri.
Index Keywords: Electric charge; Electric energy storage; Interplanetary spacecraft; Spacecraft power supplies; Thermal effects; Potassium hydroxides; Silver zinc battery; Secondary batteries

Authors: Rochow Richard F., Miles Barry J.
Title: Power generation considerations in a solar bimodal receiver
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NovaTech, Lynchburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rochow, Richard F., NovaTech, Lynchburg, United States; Miles, Barry J., NovaTech, Lynchburg, United States
Abstract: The Integrated Solar Upper Stage (ISUS), or solar bimodal stage provides both propulsive thrust for efficient orbital transfer(s) and electrical power generation for the spacecraft. The combined propulsive and power systems allow the solar bimodal system to effectively compete for a variety of missions. Once on station, thermionic converters are used to supply continuous electrical power to the satellite, even during periods when the spacecraft is in the Earth's shadow. The key to continuous power supply is thermal energy storage. The ISUS propulsion system also benefits through the use of thermal storage. By utilizing a graphite receiver, large amounts of sensible heat can be stored for later power generation. Waste heat is radiated to space through the use of heat pipes. Clearly, the graphite mass must minimized sacrificing electrical power capability. Voltage and current characteristics are carefully designed to operate within acceptable ranges. The detailed design of the receiver/absorber/converter (RAC) power system must meet these requirements with as little impact to the remainder of the bimodal system as possible. This paper addresses the key design considerations of a solar bimodal receiver as a power plant. Factors including the thermal storage and heat transfer from the graphite receiver to the thermionic converters, the support structures, electrical insulation and converter string design will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Orbiting solar power plants; Power converters; Solar absorbers; Solar collectors; Solar power generation; Spacecraft propulsion; Thermionic power generation; Converter string design; Graphite receiver; Integrated solar upper stage (ISUS); Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Brown Donald W.
Title: Geothermal analog of pumped storage for electrical demand load following
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, Donald W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The behavior of the Fenton Hill Hot Dry Rock (HDR) reservoir in response to a demand for increased power production was studied in a load-following experiment at the HDR test site in New Mexico. It was verified that the HDR geothermal reservoir is capable of increasing its thermal power output upon demand. A 65% increase in the output was achieved as the HDR reservoir was made to operate as a fluid capacitor, being discharged for 4 hours and then slowly recharged during the subsequent 20 hours of baseload operation. This mode of operation does not require an increase in the size of the reservoir or number of wells for a considerable amount of peaking power production for a few hours each day.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric utilities; Energy conversion; Energy utilization; Geothermal power plants; Geothermal wells; Hot dry rock systems; Pressurization; Load following experiment; Geothermal energy

Authors: Dagarin B.P., Taenaka R.K., Stofel E.J.
Title: Galileo Probe battery system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Space and Communications Co, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dagarin, B.P., Hughes Space and Communications Co, Los Angeles, United States; Taenaka, R.K., Hughes Space and Communications Co, Los Angeles, United States; Stofel, E.J., Hughes Space and Communications Co, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: This past year, the Galileo Probe successfully completed its ambitious mission - descending into Jupiter's atmosphere to measure its gaseous properties. This brought to fruition work that had been in progress for 18 years, the last 6 of which were required just for the long transit from Earth to Jupiter. The Probe's electrical source was a primary Li-SO2 battery, supplemented with thermally activated batteries. The batteries remained dormant during most of the interplanetary travel time, being activated only as the planet was approached. The battery system worked flawlessly. Energy density, storage life, and ability to turn on suddenly were important factors in applying this battery system. Its success was aided by the extensive testing that occurred before and after launch, as described in this paper.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Interplanetary flight; Lithium batteries; Space probes; Galileo space probe; Thermally activated batteries; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Dave B.C., Akbarian F., Dunn B., Zink J.I.
Title: Photochemical studies using organic-inorganic sol-gel materials
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dave, B.C., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States; Akbarian, F., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States; Dunn, B., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States; Zink, J.I., Univ of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: The flexible solution chemistry of the sol-gel process has been used to encapsulate a wide variety of organic, organometallic, and biomolecules in inorganic solids. This paper reviews different types of photochemical reactions which we have used to produce specific products or to generate oxygen within sol-gel matrices. By controlling synthesis conditions, the molecules can be made to exhibit desired reactivities when trapped in the sol-gel matrix. Three different examples of photochemical reactions are presented in this paper. An organometallic gold precursor compound, dimethyl (hexafluoroacetylacetonato)gold, dissolved in a silicate sol is used to produce gold nanoparticles of desired sizes. The second example is based on sol-gel encapsulated photochromic (and thermochromic) spiropyran, that converts to a colored form using thermal energy or UV radiation. The synthesis strategies for selectively isolating the colored or the colorless form in sol-gel materials are presented. Materials of these types may be useful in write-once-read-many (WORM) optical data storage applications. The third example involves sol-gel matrices doped with a biosystem, the green plant photosystem II (PS II). The resulting aged gels and xerogels are photoactive and are capable of photooxidizing water. Oxygen illumination was measured under white light and there is an indication that PS II particles are stabilized by the encapsulation process.
Index Keywords: Encapsulation; Gold compounds; Organometallics; Photochemical reactions; Synthesis (chemical); Organic inorganic sol gel materials; Xerogels; Sol-gels

Authors: Barker Greg, Hale Mary Jane
Title: Performance data network for solar process heat systems
Affiliations: Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barker, Greg, Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Hale, Mary Jane, Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Abstract: A solar process heat (SPH) data network has been developed to collect performance data from SPH systems used in industries or from systems using technologies that show promise for industrial applications. The collected data in the system include energy delivered and site meteorological conditions. Each SPH system in the data network is outfitted with a monitoring equipment and a datalogger. At present, two parabolic trough systems and a flat-plate system are being monitored and archived under the SPH data network. The two trough systems both heat water for kitchen operations, laundry, and for personal hygiene for prisons. The flat plate system heats water for meat processing at a slaughter house.
Index Keywords: Computer networks; Data acquisition; Data handling; Data recording; Heat storage; Solar collectors; Flat plate systems; Parabolic trough systems; Solar process heat (SPH) data network; Solar heating

Authors: Randolf G., Frais-Koelbl H., Hauser H.
Title: Dielectric energy storage by prepolarized, polymer embedded ferroelectric particles
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Technische Universitaet Wien, Wien, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Randolf, G., Technische Universitaet Wien, Wien, Austria; Frais-Koelbl, H., Technische Universitaet Wien, Wien, Austria; Hauser, H., Technische Universitaet Wien, Wien, Austria
Abstract: In order to maximize the dielectric energy density, the knee of the polarization curve P(E) should coincide with the dielectric strength Es of the material. On the other hand, the efficiency of an energy storage device is also an important parameter. Therefore, hysteresis losses should be small. Two successful possibilities for material optimization have been investigated: Embedding the ferroelectric powder in polymers allows to adjust the permittivity εr and the polarization curve by modifying the powder/polymer concentration. The polarization curve is modified and the coercivity EC is minimized by prepolarizing the sample in a bias field EBias, which is acting parallel to the sample plane during the solidification process. The aligned dipoles are then rotated (against the crystal energy) in the direction of the applied field E, which is acting perpendicular to the dielectric plate. In this way the energy density can be increased up to W = 106-107 J/m3 to make capacitors replace electrochemical batteries for ultra quick charging/discharging applications.
Index Keywords: Dielectric properties of solids; Electric energy storage; Electric field effects; Energy gap; Ferroelectricity; Optimization; Polarization; Polymers; Solidification; Strength of materials; Dielectric energy density; Polymer embedded ferroelectric particles; Ferroelectric materials

Authors: Pokryvailo A., Kanter M., Shaked N.
Title: Two-stage opening switch for inductive energy storage systems
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Propulsion Physics Lab, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pokryvailo, A., Propulsion Physics Lab, Yavne, Israel; Kanter, M., Propulsion Physics Lab, Yavne, Israel; Shaked, N., Propulsion Physics Lab, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: A two-stage opening switch comprises of a vacuum circuit breaker (VS) as a first stage and a high voltage fuse (HVF) in series with an SCR as a second stage. The switch offers low resistance of 20 μΩ during charge intervals of several hundred milliseconds, controlled time to opening, minimal fuse size and a relatively fast opening of 0.25-0.7 ms. It serves as a closing switch as well. In a series of experiments, the current of 30-40 kA was commutated routinely from a 130 μH inductor into the resistive load at a voltage of 3 kV. Various quenching media were examined. The liquids were found to yield maximum inductively generated voltage and transfer efficiency. A strong correlation exists between the fuse performance and the pressure generated in the fuse. It was found that a two-three millisecond HVF conduction time suffices for the recovery of the VS. A PSpice circuit simulation using an action-dependent fuse model gave good agreement with the experimental results.
Index Keywords: Electric circuit breakers; Electric energy storage; Electric fuses; Electric resistance; Thyristors; High voltage fuse (HVF); Inductive energy storage systems; Two stage opening switches; Vacuum circuit breakers (VS); Electric switches

Authors: Bass Robert
Title: Anti-gravity implies infinite free energy
Authors with affiliations: Bass, Robert
Abstract: If the empirical Podkletnov Effect (Journal of New Energy, vol 2, no 2, ref 4, p 136) is confirmed to be physically valid as described, then it will be simple to produce unlimited free energy from some hitherto untapped renewable source. Indeed, the device described loc.cit. [cf. also Business Week, Sept. 30, 1996, p 42] produces a constant reduction in the measured weight of an arbitrary test mass when run in steady-state at constant power. But this means that the total energy input grows linearly with time, whereas the total energy output stored in a vertically-arrayed flywheel (driven by the torque producible from asymmetric weight-reduction and consequent unbalanced unidirectional torque generated as each successive portion of the flywheel's rim becomes tangent to the Podkletnov beam) grows quadratically with time. The announced result follows at once.
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Calculations; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Flywheels; Rotating machinery; Torque; Angular momentum; Rotational kinetic energy; Free energy

Authors: Berman A., Levitan R., Epstein M., Levy M.
Title: Ruthenium methanation and reforming catalysts for solar chemical heat pipe
Affiliations: Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Berman, A., Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Levitan, R., Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Epstein, M., Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Levy, M., Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: Ruthenium metal on an alumina support was found to be suitable catalyst for reforming of methane with CO2 or steam and reverse reaction, methanation of synthesis gas. These reactions are under study for the development of a Solar Chemical Heat Pipe, for storage and transport of solar energy. The catalysts containing 1-4% Ru were tested for activity, selectivity. and stability under simulated solar conditions of varying energy input. Long term testing of the catalysts was carried out and the kinetics of methanation and reforming processes on Ru catalysts was investigated. The kinetic models for CO+H2 methanation and reforming of methane with CO2 were developed.
Index Keywords: Alumina; Carbon dioxide; Catalyst selectivity; Heat pipes; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Methanation; Photochemical reactions; Reaction kinetics; Ruthenium; Solar energy; Synthesis (chemical); Reversible reactions; Solar chemical heat pipes; Solar energy distribution; Solar collectors

Authors: Paul J.C.
Title: Dielectric relaxation under the influence of cross magnetic field
Affiliations: Tripura Engineering Coll, Tripura, India
Authors with affiliations: Paul, J.C., Tripura Engineering Coll, Tripura, India
Abstract: Polarization phenomena including charge storage, transport, relaxation and conduction & breakdown mechanism of dielectric/electrets materials have been the subject of considerable study and research for the long time. But almost all works which have been carried out are under the influence of electric field only. In this paper dielectric relaxation under the influence of cross magnetic field has been presented which has not been reported so far. A mathematical equation for activation energy in presence of cross magnetic field has been developed and its influence on relaxation time has been predicted. It has been proved further mathematically that microscopic (molecular) relaxation time will be greater when a cross magnetic field is applied to a dielectric/electret materials.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Electrets; Electric conductivity; Electric field effects; Magnetic field effects; Mathematical techniques; Molecules; Permittivity; Polarization; Refractive index; Viscosity; Cross magnetic field; Dielectric loss; Mathematical equation; Relaxation time; Dielectric relaxation

Authors: Yamagishi Yasushi, Sugeno Tomohisa, Ishige Takashi, Takeuchi Hiromi, Pyatenko Alexander T.
Title: Evaluation of microencapsulated PCM for use in cold energy transportation medium
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamagishi, Yasushi, Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan; Sugeno, Tomohisa, Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan; Ishige, Takashi, Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan; Takeuchi, Hiromi, Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan; Pyatenko, Alexander T., Daido Hoxan Inc, Chitose, Japan
Abstract: For cold energy applications, the feasibility of micro-encapsulated phase change material (PCM) and their slurry have been investigated experimentally; thermal properties, theological properties and the structural integrity of PCM microcapsules (MCs) have been evaluated. The paraffins of two types, n-Tetradecane and n-Dodecane (melting point 5.5, -13.5 °C), were microencapsulated as PCMs. MCs samples of four different size-distributions ranging from 5 μm to 1000 μm were prepared for this work. The supercooling of microencapsulated PCM induced by the smallness of MCs was detected through differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and the heating / cooling temperature variations of slurry. Structural stability of the MCs had a dependence on their diameters. Smaller size MCs withstood the stress from the slurry flow and the volumetric expansion of phase change. Slurry which contained a high concentration of small size MCs had high apparent viscosity. Ionic surfactants were effective additives to reduce viscosity. The large reduction of slurry friction due to the turbulent drag reduction was observed during pressure drop measurements.
Index Keywords: Differential scanning calorimetry; Low temperature properties; Paraffins; Phase composition; Pressure drop; Pressure measurement; Rheology; Slurries; Surface active agents; Thermal effects; Thermodynamic properties; Viscosity; Cold energy applications; Ionic surfactants; Microencapsulated phase change materials; Slurry friction; Heat storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proceedings of the 1996 21st Annual Symposium of the Uranium Institute
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institute
Abstract: The proceedings contains 26 papers about uranium and nuclear energy presented at the Twenty First Annual Symposium of the Uranium Institute, at London in September 1996. Topics discussed include: nuclear energy; energy policy; energy utilization; uranium; plutonium; nuclear fuel reprocessing and recycling; mixed oxide (MOX) fuels; nuclear reactors and power plants; radiation protection; radioactive waste transportation; nuclear materials safeguards; and prospects for world nuclear industries.

Authors: MacGregor S.J., Turnbull S.M., Tuema F.A., Harrower J.
Title: Performance of a simple PFN Marx generator
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Univ of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: MacGregor, S.J., Univ of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Turnbull, S.M., Univ of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Tuema, F.A., Univ of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Harrower, J., Univ of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The performance of a 5-stage pulse forming network (PFN) Marx generator is described. Each stage of the generator was constructed from HV co-axial cable instead of discrete inductors and HV capacitors. The output voltage pulse from the generator is rectangular in profile, with a risetime of approximately 30 ns and a duration of approximately 100 ns. The maximum output voltage is 200 kV and the output impedance is 125 Ω. Due to the relatively small amount of energy stored in the device (approximately 10 J), it may be operated at pulse repetition frequencies of approximately 100 Hz.
Index Keywords: Coaxial cables; Electric energy storage; Electric impedance; Marx generators; Pulse forming networks (PFN); Pulse generators

Authors: Martínez J.A., Frühbeck G.
Title: Regulation of energy balance and adiposity: A model with new approaches
Affiliations: Depto. de Fisiol. y Nutrición, Universidad de Navarra, 31008 Pamplona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Martínez, J.A., Depto. de Fisiol. y Nutrición, Universidad de Navarra, 31008 Pamplona, Spain; Frühbeck, G., Depto. de Fisiol. y Nutrición, Universidad de Navarra, 31008 Pamplona, Spain
Abstract: Obesity etiology and treatment have been fraught with disappointment for researchers, because the mechanisms regulating fuel homeostasis and adiposity are incompletely understood. It can now be hypothesized in the light of new evidences that the control of body weight and composition depends upon an axis with three interrelated and self-controlled components: 1) food intake; 2) nutrient turnover and thermogenesis and 3) body fat stores, all of which underly complex feedback mechanisms. This approach considers two of the most relevant recent findings in the field (leptin and β3-adrenoceptors), adding new views to previous metabolic models of obesity. This perspective supplies some additional clues to the understanding of body composition regulation as well as the potential involvement of genetic and hypothalamic disorders in the onset of obesity.
Author Keywords: β3 adrenergic agonists; Food intake (appetite); Leptin; Nutrient turnover; Obesity; Thermogenesis

Title: SiC electronics

Affiliations: Northrop Grumman Science &, Technology Cent, Pittsburgh, United States

Abstract: Silicon Carbide (SiC) is an emerging semiconductor material which has been widely predicted to be superior to both Si and GaAs in the areas of microwave power devices, power electronic switching devices, high temperature analog and digital electronics, non-volatile memories and UV sensors. This paper presents an overview of SiC electronic properties, current status of the bulk and epitaxial material growth, and characteristics of the recently fabricated devices in some of the above device categories. The first application of silicon carbide in high power pulsed amplifiers at UHF and S-Band frequencies is described.

Title: A parametric study of the effects of soil properties on seismic response of buried vaults

Abstract: This paper examines the effects of soil properties on the seismic response of buried vault structures similar to the tanks located in many Department of Energy facilities for containing high-level radioactive wastes. The study was pursued through a parametric analysis using the computer program SASSI. Both uniform and layered soil properties were included in the investigation. The response parameters of a buried vault to a seismic motion were analyzed for different soil properties to quantify their potential effects. The results of the study are presented in this paper.

Authors: Miller N.W., Zrebiec R.S., Delmerico R.W., Hunt G.
Title: Design and commissioning of a 5 MVA, 2.5 MWH battery energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, N.W., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Zrebiec, R.S., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Delmerico, R.W., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Hunt, G., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States
Abstract: Momentary and sustained power interruptions are some of the most difficult and important power quality problems facing many industrial and commercial users. Battery energy storage systems (BESS) have the potential to provide versatile solutions to this problem for utility, industrial and commercial applications. This paper describes the design and commissioning of a 5 MVA, 2.5 MWh BESS which is now in operation at the GNB Battery Recycling Plant in Vernon, California. The BESS at Vernon provides the required power combined with both voltage and frequency control to allow the plant to tolerate disconnection from the utility grid without suffering unacceptable impacts on critical loads.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric frequency control; Electric load management; Electric utilities; Power converters; Voltage control; Battery energy storage systems; Electric energy storage

Abstract: It is not desirable to use electric machines with high inertia rotors for servo drives, ultra-high-speed non-energy-storage drives, and drives with frequent starts and stops. This paper introduces the design considerations of low-inertia, composite or light metal, axial-gap, permanent-magnet motor and its control. Tests were conducted on a composite-rotor prototype motor.

Authors: Bose Bimal K., Kim Min-Huei, Kankam David M.
Title: Power and energy storage devices for next generation hybrid electric vehicle
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bose, Bimal K., Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States; Kim, Min-Huei, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States; Kankam, David M., Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Abstract: Fuel conservation and environmental pollution control are the principal motivating factors that are urging at present widespread research and development activities for electric and hybrid vehicles throughout the world. The paper describes different possible energy storage devices, such as battery, flywheel and ultra capacitor, and power sources, such as gasoline engine, diesel engine, gas turbine and fuel cell for next generation hybrid electric vehicle. The technology trend and comparison in energy storage and power devices indicate that battery and gasoline engine, respectively, will remain the most viable devices for hybrid vehicle at least in the near future.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Flywheels; Fuel cells; Fuel economy; Pollution control; Secondary batteries; Hybrid electric vehicles; Storage battery vehicles

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, Floyd A., FW Lilly Inc, Bloomfield Hills, United States
Abstract: A comparative analysis of the key features of hybrid electric vehicles (HEV) is presented. The technology is observed to be focusing on series-type hybrid systems, with the exception of the parallel Subaru and Suzuki HEV. Major manufacturers, on the other hand, are turning to the hybrid concept to overcome two key EV issues: limited driving range, and heating and air conditioning, associated with the low energy density characteristic of the batteries.
