Authors: Bass Edward A., Rodriguez Greg, Hall Wilhelm, Johnston Ralph, Gottberg Ingemar, Hunt Brian, Ishizuka Atseturu
Title: Short and long term energy source technologies for electrically-heated catalysts
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bass, Edward A., Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Rodriguez, Greg, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Hall, Wilhelm, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Johnston, Ralph, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Gottberg, Ingemar, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Hunt, Brian, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States; Ishizuka, Atseturu, Southwest Research Inst, San Antonio, United States
Abstract: Alternative electric power supplies for electrically heated catalysts (EHCs) were investigated. Production starting, lighting and ignition (SLI) batteries were evaluated, along with lead-acid electric vehicle batteries, nickel-cadmium aircraft batteries, prototype ultracapacitors and a modified alternator. Discharge energy and peak power tests revealed the potential of some electric vehicle batteries for EHC/SLI applications. Ultracapacitors, which demonstrated the best low-temperature performance, were the least affected by power versus energy trade-offs. They are costly, however, and have high self-discharge rate. A vehicle demonstration of alternator power for EHCs revealed linear dependence between engine speed and EHC load.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Secondary batteries; Synchronous generators; Electrically heated catalysts (EHC); Lead acid batteries; Self discharge rate; Starting, lighting and ignition (SLI) batteries; Ultracapacitors; Storage battery vehicles

Authors: Jay Benny E.
Title: Horizon valve-regulated lead acid battery - reengineering the lead acid battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrosource, Inc, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jay, Benny E., Electrosource, Inc, Austin, United States
Abstract: Lead acid batteries originally consisted of sheet lead electrodes immersed in a jar of sulfuric acid. Today, electrode designs are consist of open lattice lead alloy castings filled with high-surface-area lead oxide active material precursors. With increased efficiencies and specific performance, such design simplified cell manufacture and reduced cost. These were used successfully as the primary power source to propel vehicles but considered too expensive to compete with internal combustion engine propulsion technology. This led to the development of an affordable, high performance rechargeable battery called Horizon valve-regulated lead acid battery.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric propulsion; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrochemistry; Energy storage; Voltage control; Lead acid batteries; Lead oxide; Secondary batteries

Authors: Lamp Thomas R., Reinhard Kitt C., Colozza Anthony J.
Title: Performance analysis for solar-powered unmanned aerial vehicles
Affiliations: Wright Lab, Wright Patterson AFB, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lamp, Thomas R., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson AFB, United States; Reinhard, Kitt C., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson AFB, United States; Colozza, Anthony J., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson AFB, United States
Abstract: An analysis was performed to determine the impact of various power system components and mission requirements on the size of solar-powered high altitude long endurance (HALE)-type aircraft. The HALE unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) has good potential for use in many military and civil applications. The primary power system components considered in this study were photovoltaic (PV) modules for power generation and regenerative fuel cells for energy storage. The impact of relevant component performance on UAV size and capability were considered; including PV module efficiency and mass, power electronics efficiency, and fuel cell specific energy. Mission parameters such as time of year, flight altitude, flight latitude, and payload mass and power were also varied to determine impact on UAV size. The aircraft analysis method used determines the required aircraft wing aspect ratio, wing area, and total mass based on maximum endurance or minimum required power calculations. The results indicate that the capacity of the energy storage system employed, fuel cells in our analysis, greatly impacts aircraft size, whereas the impact of PV module efficiency and mass is much less important. It was concluded that an energy storage specific energy (total system) of 250-500 Whr/kg is required to enable most useful missions, and that PV cells with efficiencies greater than approximately 12% are suitable for use.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Fuel cells; Photovoltaic cells; Power electronics; High altitude long endurance type aircraft; Photovoltaic modules; Regenerative fuel cells; Solar powered unmanned aerial vehicles; Solar equipment

Abstract: Over the last decades, significant increases in passively insulated electronic's reliability have been achieved through a combination of advanced manufacturing techniques, new materials, and diagnostic methodologies to provide requisite life-cycle reliability for high power applications. This is particularly true for advanced capacitors for filtering and energy storage applications. Recent innovations in analysis of aging under near-inservice conditions and frequencies are applied to predicting, from fundamental principles and for the first time, both microscale and at-scale passive component performance and fault tolerance. In addition, voltage scaling issues that may drive overvoltage performance will be described in some detail.

Abstract: This paper investigates the effect of kinematic interaction on the seismic responses of underground structures through a parametric study. A buried concrete cylindrical tank, typical of those found in the Department of Energy's High-Level Waste sites, was analyzed for the seismic response using the computer program SASSI. The key response parameters were evaluated to identify the potential effects of kinematic interaction. The results of the study are presented in this paper.

Authors: Nelson P.A.
Title: Fuel cell systems for first lunar outpost - reactant storage options
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, P.A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: A Lunar Surface Power Working Group was formed to review candidate systems for providing power to the First Lunar Outpost habitat. The working group met for five days in the fall of 1992 and concluded that the most attractive candidate included a photovoltaic unit, a fuel cell, a regenerator to recycle the reactants, and storage of oxygen and hydrogen gases. Most of the volume (97%) and weight (64%) are taken up by the reactants and their storage tanks. The large volume is difficult to accommodate, and therefore, the working group explored ways of reducing the volume. An alternative approach to providing separate high pressure storage tanks is to use two of the descent stage propellant storage tanks, which would have to be wrapped with graphite fibers to increase their pressure capability. This saves 90% of the volume required for storage of fuel cell reactants. Another approach is to use the descent storage propellant tanks for storage of the fuel cell reactants as cryogenic liquids, but this requires a gas liquefaction system, increases the solar array by 40%, and increases the heat rejection rate by 170% compared with storage of reactants as high pressure gases. For a high power system (>20 kW) the larger energy storage requirement would probably favor the cryogenic storage option.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic liquids; Cryogenics; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Graphite fibers; Hydrogen; Liquid propellants; Oxygen; Photovoltaic cells; Pressure vessels; Solar cell arrays; Lunar outpost; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Saitoh Takeo S., Hoshi Akira
Title: Experimental investigation on combined close-contact and natural convection melting in horizontal cylindrical and spherical capsules
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo S., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Hoshi, Akira, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Melting and solidification of phase change materials (PCM) in a capsule is important in latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) systems which are useful for leveling of electricity demand and for energy conservation. Two heat transfer modes occur during melting namely, the close-contact melting mode between solid bulk and capsule and the natural convection heat transfer in the liquid region. Experimental results are presented on combined-close contact and natural convection melting in both horizontal cylindrical and spherical capsules at high temperatures. The melting shape and complete melting time at different ambient temperatures together with the effect of inner wall temperature variations and molten mass fraction were investigated.

Authors: Kowalski G.J.
Title: Improving turbine performance by cooling inlet air using a waste heat powered ejector refrigerator
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Dept. Mech., Indust. and Mfg. Eng., Northeastern University, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kowalski, G.J., Dept. Mech., Indust. and Mfg. Eng., Northeastern University, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: Stationary turbines are used to produce electricity in many areas of the world. Their performance is adversely affected by high ambient temperatures. Several means of reducing the turbine inlet temperature (off peak water chiller and ice storage and absorption refrigeration systems) are being proposed as a means of increasing turbine output. In the present investigation the feasibility of increasing turbine output power by using its exhaust gases to power an ejector refrigeration system is demonstrated. The advantages of the ejector refrigeration are: it operates on a non-CFC fluid, its small number of moving parts and its small size. The analysis focuses on United Technologies FT4 turbine with a base load output of 21.6 MW. It is demonstrated that the proposed system can decrease the turbine inlet temperature from 296.2 K to 277.6 K which increases the turbine output by 12.8% during periods of high ambient temperature and improves yearly averaged power output by 5.5% in a temperate climate. It is shown that the energy in the turbine exhaust has the potential of producing additional cooling beyond that required to reduce the inlet temperature.
Index Keywords: Air; Calculations; Power generation; Refrigerators; Steam turbines; Waste heat; Cooling inlet air; Ejector refrigerator; Waste heat utilization

Authors: Crosa G., Pittaluga F., Trucco Martinengo A., Beltrami F., Torelli A., Traverso F.
Title: Heavy-duty gas turbine plant aerothermodynamic simulation using Simulink
Affiliations: Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Crosa, G., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy; Pittaluga, F., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy; Trucco Martinengo, A., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy; Beltrami, F., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy; Torelli, A., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy; Traverso, F., Universita' di Genova, Genova, Italy
Abstract: This paper presents a physical simulator for predicting the off-design and dynamic behaviour of a single shaft heavy-duty gas turbine plant, suitable for gas-steam combined cycles. The mathematical model, which is non linear and based on the lumped parameter approach, is described by a set of first-order differential and algebraic equations. The plant components are described adding to their steady state characteristics the dynamic equations of mass, momentum and energy balances. The state variables are mass flow rates, static pressures, static temperatures of the fluid, wall temperatures and shaft rotational speed. The analysis has been applied to a 65 MW heavy-duty gas turbine plant with two off-board silo-type combustion chambers. To model the compressor, equipped with variable inlet guide vanes, a subdivision into five partial compressors is adopted, in serial arrangement, separated by dynamic blocks. The turbine is described using a one dimensional row by row mathematical model, that takes into account both the air bleed cooling effect and the mass storage among the stages. The simulation model considers also the air bleed transformations from the compressor down to the turbine. Both combustion chambers have been modelled utilizing a sequence of several sub-volumes, to simulate primary and secondary zones in presence of three hybrid burners. A code has been created in Simulink environment. Some dynamic responses of the simulated plant, equipped with a proportional-integral speed regulator, are presented.
Index Keywords: Combined cycle power plants; Combustion chambers; Computer simulation; Differential equations; Mass transfer; Mathematical models; Pressure effects; Thermal effects; Heavy duty gas turbine plants; Software package simulink; Gas turbine power plants

Authors: Oka M.
Title: Direct contact melting process on heating wall of an arbitrary axi-symmetric shape
Affiliations: Fuji - Electric Corporate Research, and Development Ltd, Yokosuka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oka, M., Fuji - Electric Corporate Research, and Development Ltd, Yokosuka, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a theoretical study of direct contact melting process in a capsule with an axisymmetric heating wall shape. One of the important applications of this system is that of thermal storage system. Latent heat energy is used in this system effectively. Phase change material (PCM) is stored in a small capsule. Heating wall of this system is not simple, but sometime complicated. In recent researches, this process is solved for only several limited simple wall shapes. In each cases, governing equations were solved using approximated methods or numerical method. In this paper, governing equations system with heat convection terms is solved analytically. It is shown that the governing equation can be transformed into ordinary differential equations system by a similarity transformation. It is also shown that there exists an exact solution, that is obtained without using any approximate method. This solution is valid for whole range of Stefan number.
Index Keywords: Container closures; Heat convection; Heating; Numerical methods; Walls (structural partitions); Contact melting; Exact solution; Theoretical analysis; Thermal energy storage; Melting

Abstract: Latent heat storage including cool storage is of great importance in many energy systems, such as solar hot water system, air conditioning system and waste heat utilization system. In this paper, a simplified model for analyzing the performance of a cool storage tank filled with rectangular enclosures containing phase change material used in an air conditioning system is presented, with which the effect of the operational factors such as chilling flow rate, supercooling of the PCM etc. during a cool charge process can be calculated. The calculation results agree well with the experiments in ref.[1].

Authors: Guo Lingjie, Leobandung Effendi, Chou Stephen Y.
Title: Si single-electron MOS memory with nanoscale floating-gate and narrow channel
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Lingjie, Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; Leobandung, Effendi, Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; Chou, Stephen Y., Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the first single-electron MOS memories (SEMMs) having a narrow crystalline Si channel and a nanoscale poly-Si floating gate of a well controlled dimension. It reports that the behavior of the device can be explained by the single electron charging effect. First, since there is little oxide between the channel and the floating gate, the charging voltage primarily drops between the control gate and the floating gate. The capacitance for the 7 nm × 7 nm floating gate and a 40 nm control oxide is 4 × 10-20 F, giving single electron charging voltage of 4V. Second, the shift in the SEMM's threshold voltage due to one electron stored into the floating gate, estimated from single-electron Debye screen length, 51 mV. And third, the self-limiting charging process comes from (a) raising of potential in the floating gate sue to single electron charging, (b) a large Coulomb energy level spacing, and (c) a thin barrier layer. All these estimations are consistent with the experiments.

Authors: Lawless W.N., Clark Jr. C.F.
Title: Energy storage at 77 K in multilayer ceramic capacitors
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: CeramPhysics, Inc, Westerville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lawless, W.N., CeramPhysics, Inc, Westerville, United States; Clark Jr., C.F., CeramPhysics, Inc, Westerville, United States
Abstract: A ceramic material having a large dielectric constant at 77 K, ε = 8000-12000, has been developed for capacitive energy storage at this temperature. A large matrix of multilayer ceramic capacitors were fabricated using conventional tape-casting methods to optimize the dielectric breakdown strength at 77 K, and measured energy storage values on these capacitors range up to 6 J/cm3 at 77 K. An unfused bank of these capacitors was voltage-cycled 105 times at 77 K without failure, and the heating effects during cycling were immeasurably small (i.e., nitrogen boiloff was monitored). An electrocaloric effect on discharge (ΔT approximately 1 K) contributes to the thermal stability. Measurements of the frequency dependence of the dielectric properties of the ceramic at 77 K indicate a fundamental limit of about 8 μs for the switching repetition rate. Improved capacitor-manufacturing methods are discussed which can increase the energy density to the 20-30 J/cm3 range.
Index Keywords: Ceramic capacitors; Electric breakdown of solids; Electric frequency measurement; Low temperature operations; Permittivity; Thermal effects; Thermodynamic stability; Electrocaloric effects; Multilayer ceramic capacitors; Tape casting methods; Capacitor storage

Authors: Chu Chung-tse, Zheng Haixing
Title: Sol-gel technology and advanced electrochemical energy storage materials
Affiliations: Chemat Technology, Inc, Northridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chu, Chung-tse, Chemat Technology, Inc, Northridge, United States; Zheng, Haixing, Chemat Technology, Inc, Northridge, United States
Abstract: Advanced materials play an important role in the development of electrochemical energy devices such as batteries, fuel cells, and electrochemical capacitors. Sol-gel process is a versatile solution technique used in the fabrication of ceramic materials with tailored stoichiometry, microstructure, and properties. This processing technique is particularly useful in producing porous materials with high surface area and low density, which are two of the most desirable characteristics for electrode materials. In addition, the porous surface of gels can be modified chemically to create tailored surface properties, and inorganic/organic microcomposites can be prepared for improved material performance and device fabrications. Applications of several sol-gel derived electrode materials in different energy storage devices are illustrated in this paper. V2O5 gels are shown to be a promising cathode material for solid state lithium batteries. Carbon aerogels, amorphous RuO2 gels, and sol-gel derived hafnium compounds have been studied as electrode materials for high energy density and high power density electrochemical capacitors.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Current density; Density (specific gravity); Electric energy storage; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrochemistry; Electrolytic capacitors; Lithium batteries; Porous materials; Ruthenium compounds; Sol-gels; Vanadium compounds; Electrochemical energy storage; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Rychkov A.A., Boitzov V.G., Shvetz V.V.
Title: Energy distribution of surface traps for elongated in the water and corona charged PTFE films
Affiliations: Russian State Pedagogical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Rychkov, A.A., Russian State Pedagogical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Boitzov, V.G., Russian State Pedagogical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Shvetz, V.V., Russian State Pedagogical Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The influence of combined treatment (cyclic elongation in the water prior to charging) on positive homocharge storage and transport has been studied by thermally-stimulated surface potential relaxation measurement of PTFE films charged by corona discharge. Using experimental data and appropriate model, based on Simmons and Tam's analysis, we determine the energy distribution of the surface traps. It has been found that the new specific group of traps appears in the surface density of localized states, as a result of treatment. Those new traps have the broad peak located at about E*s = 1,8eV and them attempt frequency ω-s$/ equals 9.·1013 s-1. Conversely, for untreated samples we estimate the trap parameters to be about E*s = 1,2eV and ω-s$/ = 4 1013 s-1. The chemistry of the PTFE surface have been examined before and after combined treatment by means of ESCA method. The different trap distributions can be explained by surface composition changes.

Authors: Chen C., Chou J.W., Lur W., Sun S.W.
Title: Novel 0.25 μm shallow trench isolation technology
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: United Microelectronics Corp, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C., United Microelectronics Corp, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Chou, J.W., United Microelectronics Corp, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Lur, W., United Microelectronics Corp, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Sun, S.W., United Microelectronics Corp, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan
Abstract: A novel shallow trench isolation technology has been proposed for 0.25 μm CMOS VLSI applications. The gate oxide and a thin poly layer are processed first, followed by the shallow trench isolation, channel implants, and high-energy well implants. The anomalous subthreshold conduction of the shallow trench isolated MOSFET's, as so called 'kink effect' due to field crowding at active edge, has been successfully eliminated. No inverse narrow width effect is observed. The inter-well isolation, N+/P+ spacing, is shrinkable down to 0.8 μm for 0.25 μm CMOS technology. Well behaved 0.25 μm MOSFET's with off-state leakage less than 1 pA/μm, were obtained at 2.5 V supply voltage. This isolation technology has also been integrated into 0.25 μm high-performance logic and high-density SRAM circuits.

Authors: Oman Henry
Title: Batteries vs alternatives for storing energy
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Authors with affiliations: Oman, Henry
Abstract: Electric utilities need quickly-available sources of power for supplying expected and unexpected peak loads. Among useful sources have been the energy stored in water by pumping it to elevated storage reservoirs, in air compressed into underground chambers, and in batteries. A new power source, tBase-load nuclear and coal-fired steam plants generate off-peak energy for recharging the depleted storage facility. The aero-derived gas turbine, challenges the economics of these traditional energy-storage means. These turbines have been designed for aircraft where quick startup, rapid change in output power, and high reliability are essential. With a 1426 °C (2600 °F) turbine inlet temperature the available efficiencies are 42 percent in simple-cycle operation and 60 percent in a combined-cycle power plant. A recent 84-MW natural-gas-burning peak-power plant cost $204 per kW. Pacific Gas and Electric's Helmes River pumped-hydro plant had cost $656 a kW. The combined-cycle gas turbine plants, with their low manpower requirements, are producing power that costs less than power from nuclear power plants. We examine the performance and economics available from these new power sources.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric batteries; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Electric utilities; Energy efficiency; Gas turbines; Nuclear power plants; Reliability; Steam power plants; Aero derived gas turbines; Peak loads; Electric energy storage

Authors: Horie Hiroshi, Imai Masahiko, Itoh Akio, Arimoto Yoshihiro
Title: Novel high aspect ratio aluminum plug for logic/DRAM LSIs using polysilicon-aluminum substitute (PAS)

Abstract: This paper describes a polysilicon-aluminum substitute (PAS) technique for single-crystalline aluminum plugs with aspect ratios of over 7 used for subquartermicron logic/DRAM LSIs. A via hole was filled with polysilicon by CVD, and aluminum was deposited on the planarized polysilicon plug. An aluminum plug was substituted for the polysilicon by annealing. We filled via holes having a minimum diameter of 0.175 μm and a depth of 1.7 μm (as aspect ratio of about 10) with aluminum.

Authors: Leroueil S., Marques M.E.S.
Title: Importance of strain rate and temperature effects in geotechnical engineering
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Laval University, Quebec City, Que. G1K 7P4, Canada; Coordenacao Programas Pos-G. E., Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Laval University, Québec, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Leroueil, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Laval University, Quebec City, Que. G1K 7P4, Canada; Marques, M.E.S., Coordenacao Programas Pos-G. E., Univ. Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Laval University, Québec, Canada
Abstract: This paper examines the importance of strain rate and temperature effects in geotechnical engineering. The first part considers the effects on the main characteristics of soil behavior. It emerges that compressibility of soils is controlled by an effective stress-strain-strain rate-temperature relationship; viscous effects on the limit state curve, the undrained shear strength and the preconsolidation pressure of clays are important, on the order of 10% per logarithm cycle of strain rate or a temperature change of about 12°C; viscous effects on the critical state and residual strength envelopes are extremely small or non existent; the shear modulus at small strains is strain rate dependent, but the viscous effects are smaller in cohesionless materials than in cohesive soils and have a tendency to decrease at very small strains. Creep and relaxation phenomena are also examined. The influence of viscosity on soil testing, both in laboratory and in situ, is then considered in the second part. Finally, implications of viscosity for several practical problems (embankments on soft clays; foundations; preloading of clay deposits by heating; energy storage; radioactive waste disposal; movements in slopes) are discussed.
Index Keywords: Compressibility; Consolidation; Creep; Pressure effects; Shear strength; Soil testing; Strain rate; Stress analysis; Stress relaxation; Thermal effects; Viscosity; Geotechnical engineering; Preconsolidation pressure; Soil mechanics

Authors: Hafen Douglas P., Armantrout Jon D.
Title: Nickel-hydrogen voltage efficiency model
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space, Sunnyvale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hafen, Douglas P., Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space, Sunnyvale, United States; Armantrout, Jon D., Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space, Sunnyvale, United States
Abstract: A model has been developed to determine voltage vs. current relationships and coulombic efficiency of nickel-hydrogen batteries. The model may be used as a subprogram of a dynamic electrical system performance model operating in the time domain. Parameters of the model were determined by Marquardt algorithm and the data fit of electrical characterization test results. Test performance data which covered a wide domain of independent variables such as temperature, current, and state-of-charge, produced a well-behaved model.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Electric current measurement; Electric energy storage; Mathematical models; Nickel compounds; Spacecraft power supplies; System stability; Voltage measurement; Butler Volmer equations; Coulombic efficiency; Marquardt algorithm; Nerstian terms; Nickel hydrogen batteries; Tafel relationship; Secondary batteries

Authors: Reinhardt Kitt C., Lamp Thomas R., Geis Jack W., Colozza Anthony J.
Title: Solar-powered unmanned aerial vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Wright Lab, Wright Patterson Air Force Base, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reinhardt, Kitt C., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson Air Force Base, United States; Lamp, Thomas R., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson Air Force Base, United States; Geis, Jack W., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson Air Force Base, United States; Colozza, Anthony J., Wright Lab, Wright Patterson Air Force Base, United States
Abstract: An analysis was performed to determine the impact of various power system components and mission requirements on the size of solar-powered high altitude long endurance (HALE)-type aircraft. The HALE unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) has good potential for use in many military and civil applications. The primary power system components considered in this study were photovoltaic (PV) modules for power generation and regenerative fuel cells for energy storage. The impact of relevant component performance on UAV size and capability were considered; including PV module efficiency and mass, power electronics efficiency, and fuel cell specific energy. Mission parameters such as time of year, flight altitude, flight latitude, and payload mass and power were also varied to determine impact on UAV size. The aircraft analysis method used determines the required aircraft wing aspect ratio, wing area, and total mass based on maximum endurance or minimum required power calculations. The results indicate that the capacity of the energy storage system employed, fuel cells in our analysis, greatly impacts aircraft size, whereas the impact of PV module efficiency and mass is much less important. It was concluded that an energy storage specific energy (total system) of 250-500 Whr/kg is required to enable most useful missions, and that PV cells with efficiencies greater than approximately 12% are suitable for use.
Index Keywords: Aspect ratio; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Photovoltaic cells; Power electronics; Solar power generation; Wings; High altitude long endurance (HALE) aircrafts; Solar powered unmanned aerial vehicles; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Tsai Fu-Sheng, Markowski Peter, Whitcomb Eugene
Title: Off-line flyback converter with input harmonic current correction
Affiliations: Computer Products, Inc, South Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tsai, Fu-Sheng, Computer Products, Inc, South Boston, United States; Markowski, Peter, Computer Products, Inc, South Boston, United States; Whitcomb, Eugene, Computer Products, Inc, South Boston, United States
Abstract: An off-line flyback converter employing coupled primary transformer windings to achieve input harmonic current correction is introduced. By controlling the turn-ratio of the windings, the input current harmonic contents can be reduced to comply with EN61000-3-2 limits while boosting only slightly the bulk capacitor voltage. Such topology allows use of commercially available electrolytic capacitors for energy storage and introduces minimum cost penalty. Basic operation of the converter is discussed and hardware results from a prototype circuit presented.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric network topology; Electrolytic capacitors; Transformer windings; Input harmonic current correction; Offline flyback converter; Electric converters

Authors: Hockney Richard L., LeBlanc Peter L.

Affiliations: SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hockney, Richard L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States; LeBlanc, Peter L., SatCon Technology Corp, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: The flywheel energy storage system (FESS) is a `plug for plug' replacement for batteries in telecommunications remote powering applications. SatCon Technology Corporation's FESS is a 2.0 kWHr telecommunication flywheel that includes a composite rim, magnetic bearings, a bi-directional inverter, and a motor/generator.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric motor generator sets; Magnetic bearings; Monitoring; Reliability; Standby power systems; Telephone systems; Flywheel energy storage systems (FESS); Remote node locations; Flywheels

Authors: Horner Roger E., Proud Neil J.
Title: Key factors in the design and construction of advanced Flywheel Energy Storage Systems and their application to improve telecommunication power back-up
Affiliations: Int Energy Systems, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Horner, Roger E., Int Energy Systems, England, United Kingdom; Proud, Neil J., Int Energy Systems, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper develops a Flywheel Energy Storage System from first principles and illustrates this with a design for PirouetteTM by International Energy Systems. The performance of PirouetteTM is reported together with a discussion on its application to telecommunications. The features of this technology that are beneficial to the operator are identified.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Optimization; Standby power systems; Telecommunication systems; Flywheel energy storage systems (FESS); Flywheels

Authors: Jaeger Calvin D., Duggan Ruth A., Tolk Keith M.
Title: Non-proliferation issues for the disposition of fissile materials using reactor alternatives
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME/JSME International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, ICONE
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaeger, Calvin D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Duggan, Ruth A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Tolk, Keith M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) is analyzing long-term storage and disposition options for excess weapons-usable fissile materials. A number of the disposition alternatives are being considered which involve the use of reactors. All of these alternatives and their variants must be evaluated with respect to non-proliferation resistance. This paper focuses on how the non-proliferation objective of reducing security risks and strengthening arms reduction will be accomplished and what some of the non-proliferation issues are for the reactor alternatives. Proliferation risk has been defined in terms of material form, physical environment, and the level of security and safeguards that is applied to the material. Metrics have been developed for each of these factors. The reactor alternatives will be evaluated with respect to these proliferation risk factors at each of the unit process locations in the alternative.
Index Keywords: Fabrication; Light water reactors; Mixed oxide fuels; Nuclear materials safeguards; Nuclear reactors; Plutonium; Risks; Safety factor; Spent fuels; Canadian deuterium uranium reactors; Disposition; Fissile materials; Nonproliferation resistance; Fission products

Authors: Rose M.Frank
Title: Space power technology
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rose, M.Frank, Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Abstract: The trends today are toward smaller satellites with increased capability. These two trends place enormous demands on the technology used to power space systems. Typical power sources are nuclear, photovoltaic, and chemical. As the power available on a typical satellite decreases, the use of long pulsed sources becomes more attractive. Technologies such as electrochemical capacitors, pulsed batteries, and flywheels offer the possibility of employing high power subsystems for limited times without undue burden on the spacecraft power train. The state of the art in each of the pulsed storage devices will be discussed and preliminary experiments described which use an electrochemical power source to power a spacecraft propulsion unit such as an arc-jet or Hall effect thruster.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Power electronics; Electrochemical power source; Space power technology; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Farrell Robert E., Fisher Kenneth J., Johnson David H.
Title: Rotational mold system having energy storage and recovery
Affiliations: Penn State Erie - The Behrend Coll, Erie, United States
Authors with affiliations: Farrell, Robert E., Penn State Erie - The Behrend Coll, Erie, United States; Fisher, Kenneth J., Penn State Erie - The Behrend Coll, Erie, United States; Johnson, David H., Penn State Erie - The Behrend Coll, Erie, United States
Abstract: The preliminary design of an energy storage and recovery rotational molder system is described. The design allows recovery of process energy during mold cool down, storage of the recovered energy, and subsequent reuse during mold heating. A recirculating heat transfer fluid is used in conjunction with multiple storage tanks at varying temperature to offer efficiency improvement over present conventional hot air rotational mold systems. Total process cycle time obtained by the energy recovery system is required to equal that of present mold systems. Advantages of the design are identified to include cost reductions associated with energy conservation and reductions in scale of the physical size of the overall system. Obstacles encountered during the design process are discussed and include unique fluid delivery issues associated with the use of heat transfer fluids, heat transfer issues related to maintaining process cycle time requirements, and safety concerns. The development of the molder system is supported by a consortium of industrial sponsors and is intended to result in the fabrication of a system prototype.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Tanks (containers); Energy recovery system; Hot air rotational mold systems; Rotational molding

Authors: Mayes J.R., Carey W.J., Nunnally W.C.
Title: Experimental multiple frequency injection-wave generator
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mayes, J.R., Univ of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States; Carey, W.J., Univ of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States; Nunnally, W.C., Univ of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, United States
Abstract: The design of an optically activated multiple frequency injection-wave generator is presented. This generator naturally lends itself as a suitable microwave source for large phased arrays. The system consists of an output transmission line and static energy storage segments spatially placed with half wavelength separation. Each segment is isolated from the output line by a bulk GaAs switch. The injection-wave generator is initiated when the switches simultaneously are closed. The static electrical energy is then injected into the output transmission line, as defined by the spatial arrangement. The system is driven by a single 35 ps laser source whose output is divided by a fiber bundle for delivery to the individual switches. The versatility of the generator is demonstrated by the production of multiple frequencies. Experimental results are compared with simulation models.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconductor switches; Optically activated multiple frequency injection wave generators; Static electric energy; Radar systems

Authors: Bayasan R., Lobanov A., Parfentiev M.
Title: Use of two phase heat pipes in the energy saving technologies
Affiliations: CSP ″Heat-Pipe″ of JV, ″Inter- Top″, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Bayasan, R., CSP ″Heat-Pipe″ of JV, ″Inter- Top″, Moscow, Russian Federation; Lobanov, A., CSP ″Heat-Pipe″ of JV, ″Inter- Top″, Moscow, Russian Federation; Parfentiev, M., CSP ″Heat-Pipe″ of JV, ″Inter- Top″, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The paper describes double-phase heat pipes as the element of energy-saving technology can be used in different sectors of industry, civil engineering, agriculture, etc. The heat pipes (HP's) can be operated both on artificial and renewed natural resources of heat energy. A few small diameter HP's have been applied during the construction and use of the objects of working out, assembling, arrangement and transportation of natural gas in the Northern regions of Russia (including gas extraction places). It is used for stabilization by means of cooling and freezing of permafrost ground during the installation and application of different objects on the North. Besides, to apply the HP's in agriculture, we offer concretely the following: to provide a storage of agricultural production by means of creation of light weight short-time installed multi-sectioned module units.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Ecology; Energy conservation; Industrial applications; Technology; Energy saving technologies; Heat energy; Two phase heat pipes; Heat pipes

Authors: Hua Chihchiang, Lin Jong Rong
Title: DSP-based controller application in battery storage of photovoltaic system
Affiliations: Natl Yunlin Inst of Technology, Touliu City, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hua, Chihchiang, Natl Yunlin Inst of Technology, Touliu City, Taiwan; Lin, Jong Rong, Natl Yunlin Inst of Technology, Touliu City, Taiwan
Abstract: Photovoltaic power systems normally use a maximum power point tracking (MPPT) to continuously deliver the highest possible power to the load when changes in insolation and temperature occur. It overcomes the problem of mismatch between the solar cells and the given load. The solar array is treated as a voltage source usually, but it is treated as a current source in this paper. A simple method of tracking the maximum power point (MPP) and forcing the system to operate near this point is also presented. The effect of the negative impedance of converter to the MPPT process is also considered. As to the system equivalent circuit model, the principle of energy conservation is used to develop the large- and small-signal model and transfer function. By using this model, the drawbacks of state-space-averaging method can be overcome. The TI320C25 digital signal processor (DSP) was used to implement the proposed MPPT controller, simulations and experimental results show excellent performance.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control systems; Current voltage characteristics; Digital signal processing; Electric batteries; Electric loads; Equivalent circuits; Mathematical models; Photovoltaic cells; Solar cells; State space methods; Transfer functions; Maximum power point tracking; Photovoltaic power systems; Saturation current; State space averaging method; Electric power systems

Authors: Ichiya Mitsuo, Lewiner Jacques
Title: Long-term charge stability of silicon dioxide electrets
Affiliations: Matsushita Electric Works Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ichiya, Mitsuo, Matsushita Electric Works Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Lewiner, Jacques, Matsushita Electric Works Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, we report the investigation of silicon dioxide electrets by using plasma chemical vapor deposition (PCVD) and thermal oxidation process. It is shown that by using a proper process, long-term charge stability can be obtained, even at elevated temperatures. Physical studies will be described, in which the charge stability is correlated to Thermally Stimulated Current (TSC) measurements and to Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) analysis. Some intrinsic differences have been observed between materials with different long-term charge stability.
Index Keywords: Chemical vapor deposition; Electrets; Electric current measurement; Electric energy storage; Electron spin resonance spectroscopy; Silica; Thermodynamic stability; Thermooxidation; Long term charge stability; Plasma chemical vapor deposition; Silicon dioxide electrets; Thermally stimulated current measurement; Electric charge

Authors: Morash Richard T.
Title: Written-pole motor rides through momentary power interruptions
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: Momentary Power Interruptions (MPIs) account for about 99% of unplanned electric motor shutdowns. The Written-pole motor has the ability to ride through these MPIs for 10 or 20 seconds while continuing to deliver useful power to the load. This feature could allow system designers to eliminate some expensive devices such as battery powered UPSs to maintain power on motors driving critical loads. It can also improve industrial production by eliminating costly shutdowns of critical processes. The ride-through is accomplished by use of a very high inertia rotor in the written-pole motor, and by use of a unique control technology for the magnetic field in the rotor. The rotor inertia acts as a flywheel energy storage system. The written-pole machine can easily start and run inertia which is 50 or 100 times greater than conventional motors. The written-pole technology can also restart the motor instantaneously after an MPI. All this is done across-the-line, and the motor is synchronous, with unity power factor (or leading pF if desired), and very high efficiency.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric power factor; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Flywheels; Magnetic fields; Magnetic variables control; Rotors (windings); Momentary power interruptions; Written pole motor; Electric motors

Authors: Takano T., Yamada T., Shutoh K., Kanekawa N.
Title: In-orbit experiment on the fault-tolerant space computer aboard the satellite hiten
Affiliations: Inst. Space and Astronautical Sci., 3-1-1 Yoshinodai, Sagamihara-city Kanagawa 229, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takano, T., Inst. Space and Astronautical Sci., 3-1-1 Yoshinodai, Sagamihara-city Kanagawa 229, Japan; Yamada, T., Inst. Space and Astronautical Sci., 3-1-1 Yoshinodai, Sagamihara-city Kanagawa 229, Japan; Kanekawa, N., Inst. Space and Astronautical Sci., 3-1-1 Yoshinodai, Sagamihara-city Kanagawa 229, Japan
Abstract: Summary & Conclusions -This paper presents field data from the Hiten onboard computer (OBC) which was launched on 1990 January 24, and completed its mission on 1993 April 10. The components in the OBC experienced 655 single-event upsets (SEU) caused by cosmic rays; the bursts of SEU were observed after 9 major solar flares. In spite of these SEU, the OBC worked correctly during the mission time, due to the fault tolerance technique, Stepwise Negotiating Voting. The field data reveal a statistical correlation between SEU and solar activities. ©1996 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fault-tolerance; Field data; Onboard space computer; Single-event upset; Solar flare
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computer system recovery; Controllability; Correlation methods; Error correction; Probability; Random access storage; Reliability; Remote control; Satellites; Solar energy; Telemetering; Fault masking; Onboard space computer; Single event upset; Solar flare; Stepwise negotiating voting; Fault tolerant computer systems

Authors: Tomiyama Hiroyuki, Yasuura Hiroto
Title: Size-constrained code placement for cache miss rate reduction
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on System Synthesis
Affiliations: Kyushu Univ, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomiyama, Hiroyuki, Kyushu Univ, Fukuoka, Japan; Yasuura, Hiroto, Kyushu Univ, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: In design of an embedded system with a cache, it is important to minimize the cache miss rate to reduce the power consumption as well as to improve the performance of the system. We have previously proposed a code placement method which minimizes miss rates of instruction caches [10], but it makes code size larger. In most cases, code size is a tight design constraint. In this paper, we propose a size-constrained code placement method which minimizes cache miss rates under constraint on code size given by system designers. Experimental results show that the size-constrained code placement method achieves 36% decrease in cache misses with only 1.6% increase in code size compared with a naive placement, while the previous method proposed in [10] decreases 36% of cache misses with 25% increase in code size.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computer software; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy utilization; Linear programming; Optimization; Random access storage; Systems analysis; Cache miss rate reduction; Code placement method; Integer linear programming; Buffer storage

Authors: Fanney A.Hunter, Dougherty Brian P.
Title: Photovoltaic solar water heating system
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fanney, A.Hunter, Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Dougherty, Brian P., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Abstract: A novel solar water heating system, patented in 1994 is studied. This system uses photovoltaic cells to generate electrical energy which is subsequently dissipated in multiple electric resistive heating elements. A microprocessor controller continually selects the appropriate heating elements so that, the resistive load would cause the photovoltaic array to operate at or near maximum power. A photovoltaic solar hot water system eliminates the components most often associated with the failures of solar thermal hot water systems. Although currently more expensive than a solar thermal hot water system, the continuing decline of photovoltaic cell prices makes this system competitive with solar thermal hot water systems.
Index Keywords: Computer control; Cost effectiveness; Direct energy conversion; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Electric resistance; Hot water heating; Photovoltaic cells; Solar energy; Microprocessor controllers; Solar water heaters

Authors: Sandoval Juan A., Goodell Philip C., Swift Andrew
Title: Methodology for the quantitative exploration for sites for salinity-gradient solar ponds
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sandoval, Juan A., Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, United States; Goodell, Philip C., Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, United States; Swift, Andrew, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, United States
Abstract: Salinity-gradient solar pond (SGSP) energy production is one of the proven solar energy technologies in terms of electricity generation, water desalination, medium grade industrial heat production, and hydrometallurgy. A methodology has been developed to provide a rational basis for the selection of new SGSP sites. This methodology has been applied to over 100 sites in West Texas and eastern New Mexico where distance to potential energy user is of great importance, aside from site distance to nuclear waste storage facilities where salt is a waste product.
Index Keywords: Costs; Electric power generation; Industrial heating; Location; Site selection; Solar energy; Solar heating; Waste heat utilization; Multitudinous variables; Salinity gradient solar pond (SGSP); Solar ponds

Authors: Davidson J.S., Sazawal V.K., Hornstra D.J., Clément G.

Authors with affiliations: Davidson, J.S., Lockheed Martin Energy Systems, Building 3047, MS-6023, P. O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6023, United States; Sazawal, V.K., NUMATEC, Inc., 7401 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, MD 20814-3416, United States; Hornstra, D.J., Performance Development Corporation, 109 Jefferson Avenue, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Clément, G., SGN, 1, rue des Hérons, St Quentin en Yvelines 78182 Cedex, France
Abstract: The LR56 cask system is licensed for use in France under Certificate of Compliance F/309/B(U)F for transport of 4,000-liter volumes of radioactive liquids. Three LR56 cask systems (with modifications for use at Department of Energy [DOE] sites) have been purchased for delivery at the Hanford Site, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), and Savannah River Site (SRS). The LR56 cask systems will be used for on-site transfers of Type B quantities of radioactive liquid waste. The ORNL unit will also be used as a Type A packaging for transfers of radioactive liquids between DOE sites. This paper discusses LR56 operating features and the use of the cask system at the three DOE sites.
Index Keywords: Laws and legislation; Packaging; Radioactive materials; Radioactive waste storage; Cask system; Radioactive liquid; Radioactive waste transportation

Authors: T-Raissi Ali, Banerjee Arundhati, Sheinkopf Kenneth
Title: Metal hydride storage requirements for transportation applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cocoa, United States
Authors with affiliations: T-Raissi, Ali, Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cocoa, United States; Banerjee, Arundhati, Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cocoa, United States; Sheinkopf, Kenneth, Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cocoa, United States
Abstract: Vehicular application of hydrogen requires a lightweight, compact, safe and economic containment method. However, no single storage technology satisfies all the criteria for on-board hydrogen storage and only three systems for on-board hydrogen storage appear close to commercialization: compressed gas at high pressure, liquid hydrogen and low temperature metal hydrides. The design goals for hydride storage systems for future fuel cell vehicle applications are defined.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fuel cells; Hydrides; Hydrogen fuels; Locomotives; Metal hydride storage; Fuel storage

Authors: Chun Wongee, Lee Yoon Joon, Lee Jae Young, Chen Kuan, Kim Hyung Taek, Lee Tai Kyu
Title: Application of the thermal diode concept for the utilization of solar energy
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Chun, Wongee, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea; Lee, Yoon Joon, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea; Lee, Jae Young, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea; Chen, Kuan, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea; Kim, Hyung Taek, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea; Lee, Tai Kyu, Cheju Natl Univ, Cheju-Shi, South Korea
Abstract: This paper introduces a number of numerical and experimental investigations to harness the sun's energy using the thermal diode concept. Three different types of thermal diodes are constructed and tested following the numerical simulation to verify their actual performance and adaptability (feasibility). Of these, the first model is a simple thermal diode consisting of a number of rectangular loops whose direction of heat transfer can be easily manipulated either manually or automatically. The second model consists of a rectangular fluid reservoir, a vertical cavity and an inclined channel connecting the reservoir and cavity. This design is easy to construct and very effective in transporting and storing heat for space heating in winter. The concept employed in the second model could be further extended to build a solar water heating system with a tubeless flat plate collector. An antifreeze solution is circulated through the system by natural convection extracting heat from the solar energy to heat the water contained in a separate storage tank.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Diodes; Heat storage; Natural convection; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Solar water heaters; Thermal diodes; Tubeless flat plate collector; Solar heating

Authors: Davies T.S., Jefferson C.M., Larsen N., Nouri H.
Title: DC-DC power conversion for supercapacitor energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S., Faculty of Engineering, Bristol, United Kingdom; Jefferson, C.M., Faculty of Engineering, Bristol, United Kingdom; Larsen, N., Faculty of Engineering, Bristol, United Kingdom; Nouri, H., Faculty of Engineering, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes a versatile bi-directional DC to DC converter, for the control of the power flow in either direction in a supercapacitor energy storage system for hybrid vehicle application. The results from computer simulation are compared with those obtained experimentally.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Electric automobiles; Electric batteries; Electric loads; Hybrid vehicle; Supercapacitor; Ultracapacitor; Power converters

Authors: Singh Bhim, Chandra Ambrish, Al-Haddad Kamal
Title: Improved single phase active power filter with optimum DC capacitor
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Singh, Bhim, Indian Inst of Technology, New Delhi, India; Chandra, Ambrish, Indian Inst of Technology, New Delhi, India; Al-Haddad, Kamal, Indian Inst of Technology, New Delhi, India
Abstract: Solid state control of ac power using diodes, thyristors and triacs injects the harmonics into the ac mains. These injected harmonics cause low efficiency in the supply system, poor power factor and EMI problems. Active filters have been considered a potential candidate to reduce these problems. This paper deals with an active power-filter (APF) based on simple control with optimum selection of energy storage capacitor. A voltage source inverter with hysteresis current control is employed to form the APF, which uses minimum measured variables to make it cost effective. A diode rectifier feeding capacitive-resistive load is considered a nonlinear load on ac mains for the elimination of harmonics by the proposed APF. A detailed dynamic model of the scheme is simulated and effect of different parameters is studied.
Index Keywords: Active filters; Capacitor storage; Electric current control; Harmonic analysis; Hysteresis; Power control; Problem solving; Semiconductor device models; Semiconductor diodes; Solid state rectifiers; Thyristors; Diode rectifier feeding capacitive resistive load; Energy storage capacitor; Hysteresis current control; Voltage source inverter; Power converters

Authors: Christakis D., Psofogiannakis M.
Title: Reduction of electricity cost by pump-storage unit in Crete Island
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: WEL/TEI of Heraklion Crete, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Christakis, D., WEL/TEI of Heraklion Crete, Greece; Psofogiannakis, M., WEL/TEI of Heraklion Crete, Greece
Abstract: The electricity production system of the island of Crete is far from optimum; a considerable pert of the energy produced originates from inefficient units burning expensive Diesel oil. Due to large seasonal and daily variations of power demand, future expansion of the production system cannot be realized by cost effective base load units, as these should stop and start on a daily basis. In this paper, the effect of the addition of Pump Storage Systems (PSSs) on the electricity production cost is examined. The PSSs pump water from a low level reservoir by using power produced during the nights from the base load units of the system, which burn inexpensive H.F.O.. Water from the high level reservoir will be exploited by the PSS to produce low cost energy during the peak demand hours, thus replacing operation of diesel oil burning units.
Index Keywords: Crete Island electricity production; Electricity production cost; Cost effectiveness; Diesel fuels; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Energy utilization; Pumped storage power plants; Reservoirs (water); Hydroelectric generators

Authors: George Betzios
Title: Potential and perspectives for R.E.S. exploitation in autonomous grids
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: PPC/DEME, Greece
Authors with affiliations: George, Betzios, PPC/DEME, Greece
Abstract: The peculiarities of the autonomous Island electricity grids and especially the large daily and seasonal electricity load fluctuations, in connection with the grid stability problems abound in these mainly weak grids, limit to a large extent the widespread use of WEC's for electricity production in autonomous grids. The development of appropriate hybrid systems for the optimum cooperation between the existing Autonomous Diesel Power Stations (ADPS) and Renewable Energy Source (RES) and the securing of intermediate short time energy storage, open up excellent perspective for the solution of these problems and consequently for the increase of RES penetration in these autonomous grids. In the case of the pilot plant of Kythnos such a hybrid system (wind - battery - diesel) is presented, through which RES penetration of approximately 60% on an annual basis is expected, while during periods with good wind conditions and low demand up to 765 kW the RES penetration is expected to reach 100%.
Index Keywords: Diesel electric power plants; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Energy conversion; Power converters; Autonomous diesel power stations (ADPS); Autonomous island electricity grids; Wind power

Authors: Grasselli Umberto

Authors with affiliations: Grasselli, Umberto, Univ of Rome `La Sapienza', Rome, Italy
Abstract: Photovoltaic systems is gradually expanding to assume an ever increasing role in the electric power technology, and at current industrial production technological levels it could provide a viable solution to the problem of producing electricity for users located far away from power distribution systems. This paper concentrates on the criteria for optimizing the sizes of PV peak power and energy storage of a power supplying, in function of the availability level of a determinate power (or energy) objective value, using stand-alone photovoltaic systems.

Title: The DT-19 container design, impact testing and analysis

Abstract: Containers used by the Department of Energy (DOE) for the transport of radioactive material components, including components and special assemblies, are required to meet certain impact and thermal requirements that are demonstrated by performance or compliance testing, analytical procedures or a combination of both. The Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 49, Section 173.7(d) stipulates that, 'Packages (containers) made by or under direction of the U.S. DOE may be used for the transportation of radioactive materials when evaluated, approved, and certified by the DOE against packaging standards equivalent to those specified in 10 CFR Part 71.' This paper describes the details of the design, analysis and testing efforts undertaken to improve the overall structural and thermal integrity of the DC-19 shipping container.

Abstract: A computer system for on-line analysis of RHEED images is described and a program specially developed for this purpose is presented. It has been used to control MBE-growth processes of CdTe and ZnTe layers. Examples of recorded diffraction patterns are shown. Intensity oscillations of diffraction spots as well as growth and desorption rates of a ZnTe layer, calculated from the period of these oscillations, are presented.

Authors: Aceves S.M., Smith J.R.
Title: A desiccant dehumidifier for electric vehicle heating
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, 7000 East Ave, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aceves, S.M., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, 7000 East Ave, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Smith, J.R., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, 7000 East Ave, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: Vehicle heating requires a substantial amount of energy. Electric vehicles (EVs) generate little waste heat, and using battery energy for heating may consume a substantial fraction of the energy storage capacity, reducing the vehicle range, which is one of the most important parameters in determining EV acceptability. This paper analyzes the applicability of a desiccant dehumidifier for providing comfort heating in an EV with reduced energy consumption. A dehumidifier can reduce the heating load in a vehicle because it adsorbs the water vapor generated by the passengers, thereby avoiding water condensation on the windows without requiring a high external air ventilation rate or a high window temperature. The results indicate that the desiccant dehumidifier can reduce the steady-state heating load by 60% or more under typical conditions. The reduction in heating load is such that waste heat may be enough to provide the required heating under most ambient conditions. Dehumidifier dimensions and weight appear reasonable for packaging inside an EV.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Electric vehicles; Heat transfer coefficients; Humidity control; Mass transfer; Plate metal; Specific heat; Thermal conductivity; Vapors; Water; Desiccant dehumidifiers; Electric vehicle acceptability; Electric vehicle heating; Heating load; Electric heating

Authors: Johnson G., Hunt M.E., Determan W.R., HoSang P.A., Ivanenok J., Schuller M.
Title: Design and integration of a solar AMTEC power system with an advanced global positioning satellite
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, G., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States; Hunt, M.E., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States; Determan, W.R., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States; HoSang, P.A., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States; Ivanenok, J., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States; Schuller, M., Rockwell Aerospace/Rocketdyne, Canoga Park, United States
Abstract: A 1,200-W solar AMTEC (alkali metal thermal-to-electric conversion) power system concept was developed and integrated with an advanced global positioning system (GPS) satellite. The critical integration issues for the SAMTEC with the GPS subsystems included (1) packaging within the Delta II launch vehicle envelope, (2) deployment and start-up operations for the SAMTEC, (3) SAMTEC operation during all mission phases, (4) satellite field of view restrictions with satellite operations, and (5) effect of the SAMTEC requirements on other satellite subsystems. The SAMTEC power system was compared with a conventional planar solar array/battery power system to assess the differences in system weight, size, and operations. Features of the design include the use of an advanced multitube, vapor anode AMTEC cell design with 24% conversion efficiency, and a direct solar insolation receiver design with integral LiF salt canisters for energy storage to generate power during the maximum solar eclipse cycle. The modular generator design consists of an array of multitube AMTEC cells arranged into a parallel/series electrical network with built-in cell redundancy. Our preliminary assessment indicates that the solar generator design is scaleable over a 500 to 2,500-W range. No battery power is required during the operational phase of the GPS mission. SAMTEC specific power levels greater than 5 We/kg and 160 We/m2 are anticipated for a mission duration of 10 to 12 yr in orbits with high natural radiation backgrounds.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Global positioning system; Solar cell arrays; Solar power generation; Thermoelectric energy conversion; Lithium fluoride salt canisters; Modular generators; Multitube vapor anode cells; Solar alkali metal thermal to electric conversion power system; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Feng Wei, Xia Jinghua, Tu Demin
Title: SF6, O2, air glow discharge improve the electret property of biaxially oriented polypropylene film

Abstract: SF6, O2, air cold plasma are used for surface modification of the biaxially oriented polypropylene(BOPP) films. The effect of surface grafting on electret property is investigated. Surface potential is characterized as a parameter to evaluate charge storage capacity, and half value temperature(T1/2) of thermal stimulated charge decay(TSCD) is an indicator of charge storage stability. The experiment result show that surface grafting increase the charge storage capacity 50% and T1/2 raise 25°C. IR spectrum gives some detail information about the chemical structure change taking place during treatment, especially introduction of polar groups C=0, C-F etc. Finally the relationship between chemical component and trap density and modification effect are discussed.

Abstract: This paper presents the Bidirectional power conditioner with the solar photovoltaic panel and storage battery bank. The power processing system implementation incorporating the multi-functional control strategy introduced as switching mode schemes between stand-alone and utility-interactive operations is also discussed. Furthermore, the experimental results tested through a 3kVA prototype power conditioner using the solar photovoltaic generating systems and their effectiveness are illustrated and evaluated in experiment.

Abstract: In this paper, the dynamic behavior of gas-hydrate formation, especially for those mixed gas-hydrate formed by refrigerant blends, is investigated. The transient properties of the gas-hydrate formation process with energy charge and discharge are studied experimentally, and the heat and mass transfer in the process are analyzed. The factors affecting the mixed-gas-hydrate formation, such as temperature, pressure, composition, phase dispersion, and surfactant, are discussed.

Abstract: This paper describes the process integration technologies for low voltage BiCMOS SRAM operation, including a low collector resistance process, a high energy ion implanted p-type isolation, a symmetrical cell layout design and an optimized gate oxide thickness for a boost circuit. These technologies were successfully implemented using 0.3 μm BiCMOS devices where an address access time of 6 ns was demonstrated at 1.5 V for a 4 Mb BiCMOS SRAM.

Abstract: In this paper, we present theoretical approach of mechanism of charge storage and transport caused by high electric field polarization or electron beam bombardment in SiO2 grown thermally on Si wafer subtracts. The dominant mechanism of charge storage in SiO2 electrets is suggested to be the trapping and drift of injected charges from the upper surface to the bulk oxide. The influence of charge trapping on the surface of SiO2 and Si-SiO2 interface has also been discussed.

Authors: Yamauchi Hiroyuki, Iwata Toru, Akamatsu Hironori, Matsuzawa Akira
Title: 0.5V/100MHz over-Vcc grounded data storage (OVGS) SRAM cell architecture with boosted bit-line and offset source over-driving schemes
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamauchi, Hiroyuki, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Iwata, Toru, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Akamatsu, Hironori, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Matsuzawa, Akira, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a 0.5V/100MHz/sub-5mW-operated 1-Mbit SRAM cell architecture which uses an over-Vcc grounded data storage (OVGS) scheme. The key target of OVGS is to minimize the charge amount supplied from the embedded charge pump circuits, which are required to boost the effective gate to source voltage (VO=VGS-VT) up to 0.8V necessary to achieve 100MHz-operation even at 0.5V single power-supply. Thus, the key low-power strategy of OVGS is 'putting the right (higher efficiency) boosted power-supply from charge pump circuit into the right position (less power consumed transistor) in a SRAM cell'. This paper is focused on why OVGS can realize a greater savings of the charge amount supplied from the boosted power-line and can reduce the power dissipation to ≤ 1/30.4 and ≤ 1/3.9 compared to the previously reported negative source drive (NSD) scheme and negative word-line drive (NWD) scheme, respectively, while achieving a 0.5V/100MHz-operation.
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Electric charge; Electric lines; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy dissipation; Power supply circuits; Charge pump circuits; Negative source driving scheme; Offset source driving scheme; Random access storage

Authors: Tzartzanis Nestoras, Athas William C.
Title: Energy recovery for the design of high-speed, low-power static RAMs
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: Univ of Southern California, Marina del Rey, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tzartzanis, Nestoras, Univ of Southern California, Marina del Rey, United States; Athas, William C., Univ of Southern California, Marina del Rey, United States
Abstract: We present a low-power SRAM design based on the theory of energy recovery that reduces the dissipation associated with write operations while operating at high speed. The energy-recovery SRAM was evaluated through SPICE simulations and compared with a standard design. Simulation results of a 256×256 memory configuration indicate that, for successive write operations, energy savings for the different SRAM functions vary from 59% to 76% at 200 MHz operating frequency compared to the conventional design.

Authors: Baez Anastacio N., Lebron-Velilla Ramon C., Mackin Michael, Iler Theodore
Title: Small spacecraft technology initiative Photovoltaic Regulator Kit Experiment (PRKE)
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baez, Anastacio N., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Lebron-Velilla, Ramon C., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Mackin, Michael, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Iler, Theodore, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The Photovoltaic Regulator Kit (PVRK) concept provides spacecraft system integrators a low cost alternative to a custom design electric power management and distribution system. The PVRK uses a series connected booster architecture (SCBA) to provide spacecraft energy storage control. This architecture offers higher efficiency and lower parts count than conventional series and shunt regulators. The SCBA is capable of performing solar array peak power tracking and regulated payload bus operation. This approach is modular and scales to cover a wide range of power system requirements to meet a variety of spacecraft's mission profiles.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Power control; Solar cell arrays; Photovoltaic regulator kit (PVRK); Series connected booster architecture (SCBA); Solar array peak power tracking; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Pullen K.R., Etemad M.R., Fenocchi A.
Title: High speed axial flux disc generator - unlocking the potential of the automotive gas turbine
Affiliations: Imperial Coll of Science, Technology & Medicine, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pullen, K.R., Imperial Coll of Science, Technology & Medicine, London, United Kingdom; Etemad, M.R., Imperial Coll of Science, Technology & Medicine, London, United Kingdom; Fenocchi, A., Imperial Coll of Science, Technology & Medicine, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: To enable an electric traction vehicle to have acceptable performance and range, a hybrid approach must be adopted whereby electrical power is generated on board by means of a combustion engine and generator in addition to the energy storage device. One approach is to couple a spark ignition or diesel engine to a conventional generator but an alternative solution of a gas turbine driving a high speed generator, denoted a turbogenerator, is considered superior for the following reasons; The power plant has a much lower weight and volume. Toxic emissions are much lower due to steady flow combustion in the gas turbine. Noise and vibration are reduced. Multifuel capability is inherent with the gas turbine. The most favored design for the high speed generator is a permanent magnet synchronous machine but this may either have the disc or drum topology. The disc topology offers the following advantages over drum type machines. The magnet containment structure is not in the magnetic circuit. Iron hysteresis and eddy currents are eliminated. The rotor has better rotor dynamics characteristics suitable for high speed operation. The design lends itself to air cooling.
Index Keywords: Electric traction; Electric vehicles; Energy storage; Gas turbines; High speed axial flux disc generator; Hybrid traction system; Electric generators

Abstract: A preliminary study of the response of viable neonatal mouse tibia tissue to microscale cyclic and near instantaneous mechanical stimulation was conducted, so as to develop a system for studying the relationship between mechanical stimulation and growth factors. Results show that the storage modulus increases with increasing excitation frequency. Labels of tibia imply that both loaded and unloaded tibiae were viable after one hour of testing. One important conclusion is that the established techniques may provide a unique way of establishing the correlations between the hysteresis loss energy and loss modulus, and the tangent modulus and storage modulus.
