Authors: Saitoh Takeo S., Yamaguchi Akinori
Title: Efficient borehole energy storage system for high-story buildings
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo S., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Yamaguchi, Akinori, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a seasonal solar energy storage system using boreholes which can be applicable to large facilities including high-story buildings was proposed. The proposed system provides space heating/cooling energy for the high-story buildings. The three-dimensional computer simulations were carried out for this borehole system in which vertical boreholes as deep as 100 meters are drilled in the ground. The system recovers the heat generated by the space cooling and refrigeration counters utilized in the summer season. During the summer months, this excess heat is used for charging a heat store (borehole unit), and during the winter season, the heat extracted from the borehole unit and solar thermal energy collected by the solar collector are used to heat the high-story buildings. Then, the winter cold energy is stored and utilized as cold energy source in the summer. The thermal performance including transient isotherms in the borehole unit, long-term variation of average temperature of the unit for charging and discharging processes was clarified in detail. Moreover, effects of CO2 reduction by the proposed system on urban warming were suggested.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Solar refrigeration; Space heating; Tall buildings; Waste heat utilization; Carbon dioxide reduction; Transient isotherms; Energy storage

Authors: Muljadi Eduard, Drouilhet Stephen, Holz Richard, Gevorgian Vahan
Title: Analysis of permanent magnet generator for wind power battery charging
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Natl Wind Technology Cent, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muljadi, Eduard, Natl Wind Technology Cent, Golden, United States; Drouilhet, Stephen, Natl Wind Technology Cent, Golden, United States; Holz, Richard, Natl Wind Technology Cent, Golden, United States; Gevorgian, Vahan, Natl Wind Technology Cent, Golden, United States
Abstract: One type of wind-powered battery charging will be explored in this paper. It consists of a wind turbine driving a permanent magnet alternator and operates at variable speed. The alternator is connected to a battery bank via a rectifier. The characteristic of the system depends on the wind turbine, the alternator, and the system configuration. If the electrical load does no match the wind turbine, the performance of the system will be degraded. By matching the electrical load to the wind turbine, the system can be improved significantly. This paper analyzes properties of the system components. The effects of parameter variation and the system configuration on the system performance are investigated. Two basic methods of shaping the torque-speed characteristic of the generator are presented. The uncompensated as well as the compensated systems will be discussed. Control strategies to improve the system performance will be explored. Finally, a summary of the paper will be presented in the last section.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Control systems; Electric batteries; Electric loads; Electric rectifiers; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Permanent magnets; Torque control; Wind power; Wind turbines; Wind powered battery charging; Turbogenerators

Authors: Schumm Jr. Brooke
Title: Rechargeable zinc/manganese dioxide alkaline cells response to electric vehicle type testing
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Eagle-Cliffs, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schumm Jr., Brooke, Eagle-Cliffs, Inc, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The purpose of our recent studies has been to demonstrate that alkaline zinc manganese dioxide cells might be useful in medium range electric vehicles. These alkaline cells in the typical round cell format are being persistently improved in performance as exemplified by the Rayovac Renewal cells available to consumers. Our latest testing has focused on finding an attractive balance between a peak load energy sharing unit and a main energy battery unit. It is assumed for the present that the tubular construction of the cylindrical cells will provide the greatest cycle life and that the tubes could be made much longer for larger battery assemblies. Results to date indicate that, without optimization, the system can provide 60 watts per kilogram and 40 watt-hours per kilogram power density and energy density respectively. For systems such as electric vehicles where relatively cheap and environmentally friendly designs are very critical for commercial success, the alkaline zinc manganese dioxide chemistry continues to offer promise of the capability of competing with the better known lead acid battery for large size portable battery power units.
Index Keywords: Alkaline earth metal alloys; Automobile testing; Electric energy storage; Electrodes; Energy conversion; Energy utilization; Optimization; Storage battery vehicles; Alkaline zinc manganese dioxide cells; Rayovac Renewal cells; Secondary batteries

Authors: Shaltens Richard K., Mason Lee S.
Title: 500 Hours of operational experience from a solar dynamic power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaltens, Richard K., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States; Mason, Lee S., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: Testing has been conducted on a 2 kWe Solar Dynamic system in a large thermal/vacuum facility with a simulated Sun at the NASA Lewis Research Center. The solar dynamic system includes a Brayton conversion unit integrated with a heat receiver which includes thermal energy storage for continuous power generation throughout a typical low-Earth orbit sun/eclipse cycle. System testing to date has accumulated over 500 hrs of power generation, ranging from 400 watts to over 2.0 kWe, including nearly 300 simulated orbits (249 producing power), 23 ambient starts and 3 hot restarts in a relevant environment. This paper will review the test program, including both operational and performance data. Data will be shown for an orbital startup and both transient and steady state orbital operation. System performance sensitivities are also discussed. The system testing is providing the experience and confidence for using solar dynamic technologies for future space power applications.
Index Keywords: Brayton cycle; Heat storage; Solar power generation; Solar dynamic power system; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Chen Jeng-Hong, Wang C.Y.
Title: Practical automatic feedback system for polyphoto CD control
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Co., Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Jeng-Hong, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Co., Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Taiwan; Wang, C.Y., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Co., Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Taiwan
Abstract: A practical automatic feedback system of exposure energy is proposed to improve the polygate photo critical dimension (CD) control. By the curve of Δ (CD) versus Δ (exposure energy), we can give the right exposure energy to the current lot by the preceding 5 (or 3) lots' CD, measured by CD SEM. To be easily used, the curve is approached as a linear function. Two months experiment of exposure energy feedback system is carried out on actual 0.5 micrometer i- line SRAM process. The capability index (C pk) of polygate photo CD has been dramatically improved.
Index Keywords: Feedback systems; Polyphoto critical dimension control; SRAM; Automation; Process control; Random access storage; Integrated circuit manufacture

Authors: Palomino Ernie, Stevens John, Wiles John
Title: Control system for improved battery utilization in a PV-powered peak-shaving system
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Salt River Project, Phoenix, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palomino, Ernie, Salt River Project, Phoenix, United States; Stevens, John, Salt River Project, Phoenix, United States; Wiles, John, Salt River Project, Phoenix, United States
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) power systems offer the prospect of allowing a utility company to meet part of the daily peak system load using a renewable resource. Unfortunately, some utilities have peak system-load periods that do not match the peak production hours of a PV system. Adding a battery energy storage system to a grid-connected PV power system will allow dispatching the stored solar energy to the grid at the desired times. Batteries, however, pose system limitations in terms of energy efficiency, maintenance, and cycle life. A new control system has been developed, based on available PV equipment and a data acquisition system, that seeks to minimize the limitations imposed by the battery system while maximizing the use of PV energy. Maintenance requirements for the flooded batteries are reduced, cycle life is maximized, and the battery is operated over an efficient range of states of charge. This paper presents design details and initial performance results on one of the first installed control systems of this type.

Authors: Sappok Manfred, Bounin Dieter
Title: Fracture mechanics aspects in the safe design of ductile iron shipping and storage containers
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME/JSME International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, ICONE

Authors with affiliations: Sappok, Manfred, Siempelkamp Giesserei, Krefeld, Germany; Bounin, Dieter, Siempelkamp Giesserei, Krefeld, Germany
Abstract: Containers made of ductile cast iron provide a safe method for transport of radioactive material. Contrary to widespread opinion ductile cast iron is a very tough material and can be manufactured in heavy sections. The containers are designed to withstand the very high impact loads of accidents like free drops onto unyielding targets. The design is based on postulated undetected crack-like flaws at the highest stressed location. Design must show that applied stress intensities are smaller than fracture toughness and no crack initiation and therefore also no crack propagation can occur. The design procedure followed in this paper is given in a new guideline still being drafted by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Cast iron; Codes (standards); Containers; Ductility; Fracture mechanics; Fracture toughness; Loads (forces); Radioactive waste storage; Stresses; Ductile cast iron containers; Radioactive waste transportation

Abstract: The generalized structure and control problem of a multilevel current source inverter using a generalized current multilevel cell introduced in [1] are presented in this paper. The necessary control laws are established and the control problem of the seven-level and nine-level structures is studied. Optimizing the step width of the inverter output current ensures current harmonic reduction and even current distribution among the switches of the cell. The output harmonic contents can be reduced without frequency modulation, which is imperative in high power applications such as interconnecting a Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) to a power system.

Authors: MacKenzie James J., Avery William H.
Title: Ammonia fuel: The key to hydrogen-based transportation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: World Resources Inst, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacKenzie, James J., World Resources Inst, Washington, United States; Avery, William H., World Resources Inst, Washington, United States
Abstract: Ammonia (NH3) is a high octane fuel (110) that can replace CO2 producing fuels in automobile transportation. It shares with hydrogen the virtue of yielding only water and nitrogen as combustion products when burned in internal combustion engines but avoids the packaging, safety and logistic problems of using hydrogen fuels in motor vehicles. Ammonia can be stored under moderate pressure at ambient temperatures. (Its physical properties are closely similar to those of liquid propane.) It can be packaged in a volume compatible with present automobiles. It is used as a fertilizer in quantities of over 100 million tons per year so that facilities for its storage, safe handling, transportation and distribution are available worldwide. It could be an economical replacement for gasoline if the foreseen costs of air pollution and global warming caused by fossil fuels are included in the economic evaluation.
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Environmental protection; Gas fuels; Hydrogen fuels; Motor transportation; Renewable energy resources; High octane fuels; Automotive fuels

Abstract: This paper describes reduction methods for false-outlines, overload edge noise and flicker based on optimal templates design including motion detection by multi-level Discrete Time Cellular Neural Network(DTCNN). The templates are designed by the minimization of Lyapunov-energy function to minimize the least-square distortion for digital still and moving images. High quality of the digital images was demonstrated by using Canon Ferroelectric Liquid Crystal Display (FLCD) which is the first commercial display device with bilevel for each Red, Green, Blue or White.

Abstract: This paper presents a synchronous reluctance machine design for high-speed high-power applications, such as the motor/alternator for a flywheel energy storage system. The rotor consists of alternating layers of ferromagnetic and nonmagnetic steel that are joined together by a process known as explosion bonding. Analytical expressions for the direct and quadrature inductances of the machine are presented, and are then used to optimize machine design. These expressions compare well with results obtained from finite element analysis. Structural and electrical analyses of a 60kW, 48,000 r.p.m. machine indicate that the design will be appropriate for flywheel systems. Current work involves construction and testing of the above design.

Abstract: The charge storage and transport behaviour of 100 μm thick pure and 0.1 wt % anthracene doped poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) foils has been investigated by absorption current, isothermal surface charge decay and thermally stimulated discharge current (TSDC) measurement techniques over a temperature range of 298 to 393 K, with fields ranging from 8 to 50 kV/cm.

Authors: Bist Anurag, Sriram Parthasarathy
Title: Constrained trellis based rate control scheme for low bit rate video coding

Authors with affiliations: Bist, Anurag, Rockwell Int Corp, Newport Beach, United States; Sriram, Parthasarathy, Rockwell Int Corp, Newport Beach, United States
Abstract: We propose a new technique of rate control for very low bit rate video coding aimed for purposes of visual telephony. The scheme is optimized for a video coder conforming to the H.263 standard and outperforms the linear rate control scheme used in the test model in terms of visual performance and frame jerkiness at the output. The rate control scheme is designed for a variable bit-rate and variable framerate coder. We address the rate allocation problem as a constrained optimization problem and exploit the syntax of H.263 to use a constrained trellis to perform the optimization. Furthermore, we reduce the computations in the trellis search by modeling the rate distortion functions. The resulting bit allocation yields a higher signal to noise ratio, and a better correlation between the quantization step size and the block energies, with respect to the linear rate control scheme for the same number of bits assigned for a particular frame.

Abstract: In this paper, we establish the nonlinear model of a single machine-infinite bus power systems with SMES based on the Park's electric and mechanical equations and derive its linearized model with the structural uncertainties caused by the sinusoidal nonlinearities. Authors: Zimmels Y.
Title: Thermodynamics of electroquasistatic systems: The parallel plate capacitor
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Technion-Israel Inst. of Technology, Technion City, Haifa 32000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Zimmels, Y., Department of Civil Engineering, Technion-Israel Inst. of Technology, Technion City, Haifa 32000, Israel
Abstract: The thermodynamics of electroquasistatic systems is considered using the parallel plate capacitor. This simple system facilitates rigorous analysis of the field and is used to derive directly the dielectric chemical potential of dielectric materials which are subject to different constraints. The constraints are imposed on field and geometrical variables and on physical parameters of the contents of the capacitor. Different constraints yield different forms of the dielectric chemical potential depending on the energy exchange between the field and coupled current and mechanical sources. If the constraints impose an increase in the energy that is stored in the field as mass is added to it, then the dielectric chemical potential turns out to be positive. The reverse is also true. In an ideal lossless system, the stored energy can be retrieved electrically and mechanically. It is shown that the dielectric chemical potential of a dielectric which exists in one region of the capacitor can be a function of the properties of this region, as well as those of the rest of the capacitor. In this sense, isolation of regions in the capacitor, with respect to changes of energy due to addition of mass, may not be physically meaningful. Finally, the effect of the polarization energy stored in a dielectric ionized solution in the context of the electrochemical potential is considered. It is shown that the electrochemical potential consists of terms due to chemical, and primary and secondary field-charge interactions. The well-known electric potential energy density of single charges gives rise to the primary effect, whereas the dielectric energy density stored in a polarized ionic solution is the reason for the secondary effect.
Author Keywords: Electrochemical potential; Electroquasistatic systems; Energy; Helmholtz potential; Parallel plate capacitor; Thermodynamics
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Constraint theory; Dielectric materials; Electric charge; Electric energy storage; Polarization; Thermodynamic properties; Electric potential energy; Electroquasistatic systems; Parallel plate capacitors; Electrostatics

Title: Contact melting process on an arbitrary shape wall coated by porous layer
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Fuji Electric Corp, Yokosuka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oka, M., Fuji Electric Corp, Yokosuka, Japan; Hasegawa, E., Fuji Electric Corp, Yokosuka, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a theoretical study of direct contact melting process in a capsule with an arbitrary 2-dimensional heating wall. One of the important applications of this system is that of thermal storage system. Latent heat energy is used in this system effectively. Phase change material (PCM) is stored in a small capsule. Heating wall shape of the capsule in this system isn't simple. Sometime it is complicated. In recent researches, this process was solved for only several limited simple wall shapes. Governing equations were solved using approximated methods or numerical method. In this paper, we solve governing equations system with heat convection terms analytically. It is shown that the governing equations system can be transformed into ordinary differential equation's system by a similarity transformation. It is also shown that there exists an exact solution that is obtained without using any approximate method. This solution is valid for whole range of Stefan number.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Differential equations; Heat convection; Melting; Numerical methods; Phase composition; Porous materials; Thermodynamic properties; Arbitrary two dimensional heating wall; Latent heat energy; Phase change materials; Heat storage

Authors: Helmbold David P., Long Darrell D.E., Sherrod Bruce
Title: Dynamic disk spin-down technique for mobile computing
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking, MOBICOM
Affiliations: Univ of California, Santa Cruz, United States
Authors with affiliations: Helmbold, David P., Univ of California, Santa Cruz, United States; Long, Darrell D.E., Univ of California, Santa Cruz, United States; Sherrod, Bruce, Univ of California, Santa Cruz, United States
Abstract: We address the problem of deciding when to spin down the disk of a mobile computer in order to extend battery life. Since one of the most critical resources in mobile computing environments is battery life, good energy conservation methods can dramatically increase the utility of mobile systems. We use a simple and efficient algorithm based on machine learning techniques that has excellent performance in practice. Our experimental results are based on traces collected from HP C2474s disks. Using this data, the algorithm outperforms several algorithms that are theoretically optimal in under various worst-case assumptions, as well as the best fixed time-out strategy. In particular, the algorithm reduces the power consumption of the disk to about half (depending on the disk's properties) of the energy consumed by a one minute fixed time-out. Since the algorithm adapts to usage patterns, it uses as little as 88% of the energy consumed by the best fixed time-out computed in retrospect.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer networks; Data storage equipment; Energy conservation; Learning systems; Personal computers; Reliability; Secondary batteries; Dynamic disk spin down techniques; Mobile computing; Mobile telecommunication systems

Authors: Farshad M., Flüeler P.
Title: Arrest of rapid crack propagation in polymer pipes
Source title: Plastics, Rubber and Composites Processing and Applications
Affiliations: EMPA, Überlandstrasse 129, CH-8600 Dübendorf, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Farshad, M., EMPA, Überlandstrasse 129, CH-8600 Dübendorf, Switzerland; Flüeler, P., EMPA, Überlandstrasse 129, CH-8600 Dübendorf, Switzerland
Abstract: The aim of the development of a crack arrester has been the design, construction, and usage of a mechanism that would inhibit and arrest a dynamically growing crack and thus limit the degree of damage to a pipeline that might be caused by a running crack. The patented crack arresting systems are based on the concept of dynamic energy absorption via additional flexibility and energy storage in certain locations along the pipe. A number of 225 mm high density polyethylene pipe samples, standard dimensional ratio 11, were tested at 0°C with a small scale steady state pipe testing rig. The samples provided with crack arresters withstood internal pressures of 5 and 7 bar; the critical internal pressure of the same types of pipe without crack arresters had been previously found to be 1-75 bar. Upon interception of a running crack by these arresters, the crack energy was spent in inelastic deformation and hence the crack lost its energy and could not proceed. It was observed that the cracking mode at the crack tip changed from brittle to ductile. PRCPA/1256 © 1996 The Institute of Materials.
Index Keywords: Crack initiation; Crack propagation; Cracks; Polyethylenes; Pressure; Testing; High density polyethylene; Internal pressure; Rapid crack arresters; Rapid crack propagation; Pipe

Source title: Proceedings of the ASME/JSME International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, ICONE
Affiliations: Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumamaru, Hiroshige, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Ohtsu, Iwao, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Murata, Hideo, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Kukita, Yutaka, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Akiyama, Mamoru, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Ohashi, Hirotada, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Goto, Masaharu, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Tanaka, Nobukazu, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Ohkawa, Tomio, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Ono, Yuji, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Hatta, Toshiyuki, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan; Yoneyama, Kazuyuki, Japan Atomic Energy Research Inst, Ibaraki-ken, Japan
Abstract: A water/CO2-combination test facility, having a vertical shaft height of approx. 25 m and a shaft inner diameter of 0.2 m, has been constructed in simulating a water/air full-size CAES system, having a shaft height of approx. 1000 m and an inner diameter of approx. 3 m. Totally fifteen experiments have been performed in this test facility. In an experiment of CO2 high-concentration (approx. 0.4 MPa) and medium water injection velocity (approx. 0.5 m/s), the shaft void fraction during gas charging to a lower reservoir (i.e. during water injection to the shaft) became highest in all the experiment. This experiment may correspond to the severest situation in a full-size CAES system; however, the blowout did not occur in this experiment. In an experiment of CO2 high-concentration (approx. 0.4 MPa) and very-high injection velocity (approx. 2.5 m/s), after gas charging stopped, CO2-supersaturated water, remained in the shaft, formed bubbles vigorously, and thereafter the blowout occurred. However, the injection velocity of approx. 2.5 m/s corresponds to a velocity of approx. 100 m/s in a full-size CAES system and may be unreal.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Nuclear reactors; Pipe; Test facilities; Two phase flow; Water; Air bubbles; Champagne effect; Compressed air energy storage system; Gas charging; U tube; Void fraction; Water injection velocity; Energy storage

Title: Analysis of a Cool Storage System at a multipurpose convention center

Abstract: Cool Storage Systems (CSS) are becoming a popular demand side management tool for utilities because they help them avoid costly plant expansions and reduce summer-time peak electricity demand. This paper describes the cool storage system at a multi-purpose municipal facility which is owned and operated by a municipal utility. The paper presents measured performance results of the cool storage system taken over a two year period. The paper describes the problems encountered, remedial actions taken and actions recommended to improve the performance of the cool storage system.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric load management; Energy conservation; Cool storage systems (CSS); Energy storage

Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Willows, M., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Lefley, P., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Abstract: A portable integrated renewable energy system has been designed for areas where there are natural resources. The power inputs may be obtained from such renewable resources as small wind turbines, solar panels, and micro-hydro in any combination. The captured energy may be stored or directly transformed to provide a system output of high quality mains equivalent electricity of up to 1 kilowatt. A novel microcontroller based control system has been utilized to make the system flexible and self-adaptive, and remain stable during disturbances in the power flow.
Index Keywords: Adaptive control systems; Computer control; Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric variables control; Energy conversion; Mobile power plants; Renewable energy resources; Systems analysis; Portable integrated renewable energy system; Solar insolation; Standby power systems

Authors: Burrowes Gunilla, Hiskens Ian A., Kalam Akhtar
Title: Power flow modelling of battery energy storage systems connected to the electrical network
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Burrowes, Gunilla, Victoria Univ of Technology, Footscray, Australia; Hiskens, Ian A., Victoria Univ of Technology, Footscray, Australia; Kalam, Akhtar, Victoria Univ of Technology, Footscray, Australia
Abstract: Battery energy storage systems (BESSs) are gaining increasing interest by utilities and industry alike as a management tool to improve system stability and manage load variations. These BESS have the possibility of performing operational functions including: peak shaving; load levelling; voltage control; frequency control; and acting as spinning reserve. Economic factors such as deferral of costs for upgrade of transmission lines and construction of new generating facilities are also added benefits. However it is clear that many of the suggested applications have not yet been fully explored. This paper presents and analyses a BESS model of steady state operation and discusses its performance in conjunction with its limitations and control. The model is structured to allow incorporation into power flow techniques. The aim is to allow steady state analysis of electricity supply networks which contain BESSs. The power flow equations describing the BESS provide the interface between the internal state variables of the BESS and the network constraints. BESSs can operate in a number of different control modes. In general, different sets of constraints are required to describe the different control modes. The paper will establish the various modes and provide the appropriate sets of equations.
Index Keywords: Load levelling; Peak shaving; Spinning reserve; Steady state analysis; Charging (batteries); Cost effectiveness; Electric frequency control; Electric lines; Electric load management; Electric network analysis; System stability; Voltage control; Electric energy storage

Authors with affiliations: Koyanagi, Fumiko, Seikei Univ, Tokyo, Japan; Uriu, Yoshihisa, Seikei Univ, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper investigates the impact of electric vehicle demand defusing in the general market. Here we formulate the consuming rate of the electric demand in accordance with the mileage and the defusing rate of electric vehicle. Basically, the battery is recharged in the night hours. But we also estimate the increase of electric loads in daytime by quick charge. The authors conclude that the impact of the electric vehicle's load brings us additional peaks on daily load, especially by the daytime quick charge. Therefore, authors suggest the necessity of implying new regulation of charging time for load leveling.

Abstract: The fundamental results of the instantaneous power theory have been applied to optimize the power factor in three-phase systems with nonlinear loads. The results of a practical case, using these models, are included.

Authors: Falter Diedre D., Babcock Scott M., Burks Barry L., Lloyd Peter D., Randolph John D., Rutenber James E., Van Hoesen S.Dirk

Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Falter, Diedre D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Babcock, Scott M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Burks, Barry L., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Lloyd, Peter D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Randolph, John D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Rutenber, James E., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Van Hoesen, S.Dirk, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: As part of a Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act Treatability Study funded by the Department of Energy, the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) is preparing to demonstrate and evaluate two approaches for the remote retrieval of wastes in underground storage tanks. This work is being performed to identify the most cost-effective and efficient method of waste removal before full-scale remediation efforts begin in 1998. System requirements are based on the need to dislodge and remove sludge wastes ranging in consistency from broth to compacted clay from Gunite (Shotcrete) tanks that are approaching fifty years in age. Systems to be deployed must enter and exit through the existing 0.6 m (23.5 in.) risers and conduct retrieval operations without damaging the layered concrete walls of the tanks. Goals of this project include evaluation of confined sluicing techniques and successful demonstration of a telerobotic arm-based system for deployment of the sluicing system. As part of a sister project formed on the Old Hydrofracture Facility tanks at ORNL, vehicle-based tank remediation will also be evaluated.

Authors: Shaw J.L., Gray H.F.
Title: Prospects for reducing arc damage in RF-compatible FEAs
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Vacuum Microelectronics Conference, IVMC
Affiliations: Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, J.L., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States; Gray, H.F., Naval Research Lab, Washington, United States
Abstract: A primary failure and degradation mechanism in FEAs is arc damage. Our measurements show that arc damage is reduced by placing resistance in series with FEAs, but appears to remain the dominant failure mechanism. Once ignited, an arc can potentially dissipate most of the energy stored in the charged capacitance of the FEA, regardless of how well protected the FEA is. Simple calculations show that the energy stored in a state-of-the-art low capacitance FEA is more than enough to melt sufficient material to ruin a tip or form a short between a tip and the gate. In order to produce more uniform emission for display applications, resistances are typically incorporated into the array in series with each tip. Arc damage has been suppressed in these FEAs, allowing them to be used in poor vacuums. The resistance produces a significant RC time constant, limiting the frequency at which the gate-tip voltage can be modulated. However, the value of the resistance appropriate for display applications may be much larger than required to reduce arc damage. Similarly, the capacitance in series with the resistor can be made very small. Thus it may be possible to use integrated resistance to limit arc damage while maintaining RF modulation compatibility.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitor storage; Electric resistance; Energy dissipation; Gates (transistor); Resistors; Arc damage; Field emission arrays (FEA); Radio frequency (RF) modulation compatibility; Field emission cathodes

Authors: Chaney R., Estrera J., Sinor T., Passmore K.
Title: Gamma ray imaging using a cadmium zinc telluride crystal and micro-channel plates
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference

Authors with affiliations: Chaney, R., Univ of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, United States; Estrera, J., Univ of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, United States; Sinor, T., Univ of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, United States; Passmore, K., Univ of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, United States
Abstract: Cadmium zinc telluride has proven to be a useful crystal for detecting gamma rays. It shows great promise for filling the need for a high energy and spatial resolution detector for gamma ray imaging. One of the challenges for the use of this device is in the storage and readout of the charge produced by the gamma interaction. The current thrust has been to use techniques similar to those developed for infrared detectors, which use a preamplifier and a charge coupled device for each pixel element. We present an alternative readout approach, which activates the back surface of the crystal so that the charge can be liberated into a vacuum. This photo-cathode device can then be coupled to a micro-channel-plate readout system.
Index Keywords: Crystal counters; Gamma rays; High energy physics; Imaging systems; Photocathodes; Readout systems; Cadmium zinc telluride; Gamma ray imaging; Microchannel plates; Radiation detectors

Authors: Sequeira C.A.C., Araújo L.P.S., Pacheco A.M.G.
Title: Development of energy-storage devices for a cleaner environment
Source title: International Journal of Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Dept. Engenharia Química, Instituto Superior Técnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1096 Lisboa Codex, Portugal; Instituto Superior Técnico

Abstract: The estimated burdens of and foreseeable trends in major atmospheric pollutants after an era of fossil fuels consumption and the ever-rising importance of electrochemical power sources are briefly outlined. Experiments with PEGnMg(ClO4)2IPN (30% wt. IPN; n = 8, 12, 16, 24, 30) have been carried out, since these polymeric electrolytes are tentatively proposed as offering an alternative to lithium systems. Results of ac conductivity measurements performed on PEG16Mg(ClO4)2IPN in the temperature range 25 to 135°C are reported and discussed.

Authors: Wright Graham S.
Title: Optimal energy measurement for solar car race
Source title: Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wright, Graham S., Univ of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a solar car simulation and race strategy program developed for the University of Illinois Sunrayce 95 solar car race team. The goal is to complete the ten-day race course in the minimum total running time, using solar energy alone. In cloudy weather, even the most competitive cars can become energy-limited. The strategic choice in that case, is how fast to drive the car at any point. This can be posed as a global time-minimization problem over the entire race. By breaking up the course into twenty or so segments, the problem can be made tractable enough to solve on a (vintage 1995) portable computer in a few minutes. The parameters varied are the average speeds on each of the segments. A model of the car, information about the course, and weather forecasts all contribute to the calculation of the net drain on the car's storage batteries over each segment. The main constraints are the minimum and maximum battery charge. This article discusses the algorithms used, some of our strategic insights and expectations prior to the race, and how our plans fared in the competition.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Electric power measurement; Optimization; Personal computers; Solar cells; Solar energy; Speed control; Weather forecasting; Race strategies; Solar car simulation; Racing automobiles

Authors: Jones W.F., Reed J.H., Everman J.L., Young J.W., Seese R.D.
Title: Next generation PET data acquisition architectures
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones, W.F., CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States; Reed, J.H., CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States; Everman, J.L., CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States; Young, J.W., CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States; Seese, R.D., CTI PET Systems, Inc, Knoxville, United States
Abstract: New architectures for higher performance data acquisition in PET are proposed. Improvements are demanded primarily by three areas of advancing PET state of the art. First, larger detector arrays such as the Hammersmith ECAT EXACT HR++ exceed the addressing capacity of 32 bit coincidence event words. Second, better scintillators (LSO) make depth-of-interaction (DOI) and time-of-flight (TOF) operation more practical. Third, fully optimized single photon attenuation correction requires higher rates of data collection. New technologies which enable the proposed third generation Real Time Sorter (RTS III) include: 1) 80 M byte/sec Fibre Channel RAID disk systems, 2) PowerPC on both VMEbus and PCI Local bus, and 3) quadruple interleaved DRAM controller designs. Data acquisition flexibility is enhanced through a wider 64 bit coincidence event word. PET methodology support includes DOI (6 bits), TOF (6 bits), multiple energy windows (6 bits), 512×512 sinogram indexes (18 bits), and 256 crystal rings (16 bits). Throughput of 10 M events/sec is expected for list-mode data collection as well as both on-line and replay histogramming. Fully efficient list-mode storage for each PET application is provided by real-time bit packing of only the active event word bits. Real-time circuits provide DOI rebinning.
Index Keywords: Computer architecture; Data acquisition; Imaging systems; Online systems; Phosphors; Depth of interaction (DOI); Real time sorter operation; Time of flight (TOF) operation; Positron emission tomography

Authors: Brennan A.B., Plangsangmas L.
Title: Physical aging of polyetherimide
Source title: Technical Papers, Regional Technical Conference - Society of Plastics Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Florida, Gainesville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brennan, A.B., Univ of Florida, Gainesville, United States; Plangsangmas, L., Univ of Florida, Gainesville, United States
Abstract: Physical aging is a time-temperature dependent phenomenon that occurs in amorphous materials below the glass transition temperature, Tg. Physical aging is a thermo-reversible process which has a significant effect on the physical and mechanical properties of engineering resins. These properties include volume, enthalpy, yield strength, tensile modulus and fracture energy. The effect of physical aging on the mechanical properties of a high performance engineering resin, poly(arylene-etherimide) (PEI, was characterized as a function of annealing time and temperature below Tg. Annealing process was done for 1,000 and 10,000 minutes at temperatures ranging from Tg-20°C to Tg-140°C. Dynamic mechanical measurements exhibited increases in dynamic storage modulus and decreases in dynamic loss modulus as annealing time or temperature increases. The room temperature stress-elongation behavior exhibited a pronounced ductile to brittle transition i.e., increases in yield strength and decreases in elongation after annealing. Fracture toughness (KIC) of PEI was determined base on the size of different regions on fractured surface of unnotched samples failed under tension and fracture stress. Fracture toughness decreases after annealing as well. Both electron and optical micrographs of fractured surfaces confirmed that upon annealing below Tg PEI exhibits a ductile to brittle transition.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Amorphous materials; Annealing; Brittleness; Elastic moduli; Enthalpy; Fracture toughness; Glass transition; Yield stress; Fracture energy; Glass transition temperature; Physical aging; Polyetherimides

Authors: Wang Y.L., Roseman R.D., Buchanan R.C.
Title: Study of composite effects of functional ceramics and its potential applications

Abstract: Functional ceramics have come into a new era with the concept that materials may exhibit combined effects or various functional properties which can be composed together to form a new material, device or system. Several examples which are now being studied and developed are introduced. Ceramic damping and acoustic dumb devices through Piezoelectric+Electrostrictive; Optical memory devices developed by Photovoltaic+Ferroelectric; Pyroelectric transformers taking advantage of PTC+Pyroelectric; Pyroelectric energy converters obtained by induced phase transitions (FRL/FRH); Smart actuators by induce phase transition effects. Principles and experimental results are discussed.

Authors: Yamakawa K., Trolier-McKinstry S., Dougherty J.P.
Title: Electrical properties and phase transformations in antiferroelectric lead zirconate thin films
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Applications of Ferroelectrics
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yamakawa, K., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Trolier-McKinstry, S., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Dougherty, J.P., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Abstract: Field-induced phase transformations in antiferroelectric lead zirconate thin films were investigated at various temperatures. Films with (240) preferred orientations were prepared on Pt-coated Si substrates by a reactive magnetron co-sputtering method followed by rapid thermal annealing. Crystallization temperatures between 600 and 700 °C resulted in square double hysteresis loops with large values of the maximum polarization (up to 70 μC/cm2). These very large values of induced polarization make such films attractive for energy storage applications. The phase transformations between the orthorhombic antiferroelectric phase and a rhombohedral ferroelectric phase, as well as ferroelectric-ferroelectric transitions were observed by studying the dielectric properties and the polarization-electric field hysteresis as a function of temperature. The behavior of the films is largely similar to that observed in single crystals, although the antiferroelectric-paraelectric phase transition temperature was increased by approximately 20 °C. Work on the strain change accompanying the field-induced transformation will also be reported.

Authors: Mihalczo J.T., Pare V.K., Valentine T.E.
Title: Nuclear weapons identification system
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mihalczo, J.T., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Pare, V.K., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Valentine, T.E., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: A nuclear weapons identification system (NWIS) has been under development at the Oak Ridge Y-12 plant since 1984. NWlS employs active neutron interrogation to obtain a variety of time and frequency analysis signature to identify nuclear weapons in containers. Advantages of NWlS are (1) high sensitivity {small changes in configurations produce large changes in signatures}; (2) insensitivity of some signatures to background radiation, {useful for storage configurations or for tracking of secondaries through the first stage of dismantlement since the presence of the primary on the assembled system does not affect some signatures for the secondary}; (3) nonintrusive {does not reveal design information, which makes it useful for bilateral treaties or by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)}; and (4) very difficult to deceive.
Index Keywords: Identification (control systems); Ionization chambers; Neutron detectors; Nondestructive examination; Radioactive materials; Neutron interrogation; Nuclear weapon identification system (NWIS); Nuclear instrumentation

Authors: Schempf Hagen
Title: Houdini: site and locomotion analysis-driven design of an in-tank mobile cleanup robot
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schempf, Hagen, Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Abstract: This paper describes design and locomotion analysis efforts to develop a new reconfigurable and collapsible working machine, dubbed Houdini (see Figure 1), to remotely clean up hazardous-waste and petroleum storage tanks. The tethered robot system is designed to allow remote entry through man-way openings as small as 0.61m (24 inches) in diameter, after which it expands its locomotors and opens up its collapsible backhoe/manipulator and plow to subsequently perform waste or material handling operations. The design is optimized to meet stringent site and safety requirements, and represents a viable alternative to (i) the long-reach manipulation systems proposed for hazardous storage tank cleanup, and (ii) confined-entry manual cleanup approaches. The system development has been funded to provide waste mobilization and removal solutions for the hazardous waste storage tanks in the Department of Energy (DoE) Fernald and Oak Ridge complexes. Other potential applications areas are the cleanup of heavy-crude petroleum storage tanks. The Houdini concept has been submitted to the US Patent Office and a patent has been issued (Patent # pending). We have developed a fully operational prototype which is currently undergoing testing.
Index Keywords: Hazardous materials; Manipulators; Materials handling; Mobile robots; Remote control; Tanks (containers); Locomotion analysis; Manipulation; Robot design; Sluicing; Waste cleanup; Robotics

Authors with affiliations: Messina, N., DEES Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Pappalardo, A., DEES Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Anastasi, G., DEES Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Morgana, B., DEES Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy
Abstract: An electrical network is required to provide continually adequate power for the electricity consumption needs; that is an onerous task because of the load diagram variableness. A measure to reduce the diagram peaks, is that of imposing different tariffs during the day; the users would therefore be induced to concentrate their power consumption in the off-peak load hours, to realize accumulation systems or to look for self-production ways to satisfy their needs during the peak demand hours. Some automatic management methods could also be useful to smooth the load diagram. This paper deals with the study of an electricity plant design for a commercial user; the plant is fed by both the distribution network and a photovoltaic generator, and is equipped with an electrochemical storage system and an automatic control system.

Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) requires a three-dimensional, Topographical Mapping System (TMS) suitable for use in radiological environments. The intended application is the mapping of the interior of underground waste storage tanks as part of DOE's waste remediation efforts, to obtain both baseline data on the content of the storage tank interiors, as well as, changes in the tank contents and levels brought about by waste remediation steps. The Underground Storage Tanks are described in the Westinghouse Corporation documents WHC-EP-0352, Single Shell Tank Waste Retrieval Study, and WHC-SD-RE-TI-053, Riser Configuration Document for Single Shell Tanks. The TMS for Hazardous and Radiological Environments Statement of Work defines the performance specification of the TMS, and the environmental conditions under which the TMS must operate. The ideal TMS will be self-contained, compact, reconfigurable, and capable of providing rapid variable-resolution mapping information in poorly characterized workspaces with a minimum of operator intervention. The TMS is based on the design by Oak Ridge National Laboratory used to map the waste surfaces in the K-65 silos on the Fernald site. The development and manufacture of the TMS for radiological and hazardous environments has been contracted to Mechanical Technology, Inc. of Albany, New York.

Both as-implanted and annealed profiles were measured.

Abstract: We have investigated the important failure mechanism of resistance degradation for polycrystalline MOCVD (Ba, Sr)TiO3 thin films appropriate for use in DRAMs, as a function of voltage (field), thickness and temperature. At constant field, the measured degradation lifetime decreases with increasing film thickness, resulting from a decrease in the activation energy with respect to temperature for thicker films. Similarly, there are clear indications that thicker films are more field sensitive. Predicted resistance degradation lifetimes obtained from both temperature and voltage extrapolations for DRAM operating conditions of 85 °C and 1.6 V exceed the current benchmark of 10 years for all the films studied.

Abstract: Current production applications of MeV implantation will be reviewed focusing on CMOS memory (DRAM, SRAM and Flash) and CMOS logic (ASIC and Microprocessor) device manufacturing. Abstract: This paper presents some definitions and concepts of the Instantaneous Complex Power Theory which is a new approach for the Akagi's Instantaneous Reactive Power Theory. The powers received by an ideal inductor are interpreted and the knowledge of the actual nature of these powers may lead to changes of the conventional electrical power concepts.

Authors: Brown Kristen, Walther Steve, Jillson James
Title: Ion implanter testing and process results using low pressure, zeolite-based gas bottles in medium and high current ion implanters

Abstract: A new type of toxic gas storage and delivery system for ion implanters was introduced to selected users for evaluation in 1992. This new style gas bottle is filled with solid zeolite and is capable of storing hydrides (PH3 and AsH3) in their pure form. Even at slightly less than atmospheric pressure, the new bottle can deliver 300 to 500% and more PH3 and AsH3 than conventional bottles of equal size. Ion implanter end user acceptance has been rapid. The increased safety due to the virtual elimination of the possibility of catastrophic release is the basis for the system's popularity. Secondary popularity stems from the `energy purity' feature of the system due to the reduced gas flow needed and consequentially improved vacuum levels.
Index Keywords: Hydrides; Ion implantation; Safe handling; Vacuum; Zeolites; Arsine; Phosphine; Safe delivery sources (SDS); Toxic gas storage; Gas cylinders

Title: Filament would elastomeric matrix composites for flywheel energy storage systems

Abstract: A procedure for designing and filament winding thick glass and carbon fiber reinforced elastomeric matrix composite flywheels is presented. The manufacturing method uses solvent dilution to lower viscosity of the resin, followed by flashing of the solvent with heated air before the tow is placed on the mandrel. The material is continuously in-situ cured on the mandrel to enable the rapid manufacture of high quality rings to near net-shape. Radial deposition rates of up to 3.23 cm/hr have been achieved to-date. Measured mechanical properties are shown to satisfy requirements for the theoretical fail-safe flywheel rotor design defined in this investigation.
Index Keywords: Carbon fiber reinforced plastics; Curing; Deposition; Elastomers; Energy storage; Filament winding; Flywheels; Glass fiber reinforced plastics; Mechanical properties; Viscosity; Elastomeric matrix composite flywheels; Heated air flashing; Solvent dilution; Nonmetallic matrix composites

Authors: Johnson M.
Title: The bipolar spin transistor
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Abstract: A novel three-terminal switching device, fabricated only from metals, has recently been demonstrated. Somewhat similar to a semiconductor transistor, the physical principles of operation are quite different. It is an active device driven by a thermodynamic force associated with the effective Zeeman energy of the spin polarized electrons in the base. 'Bipolar' has a double meaning: there are two polarities of carriers, upspin and downspin electrons; and the output can be a positive or negative voltage (or current). The three-terminal device does not have power gain, but because it shows a memory effect it is natural to use it as a storage element in a nonvolatile memory array. Power gain can be achieved in a five-terminal embodiment, allowing fanout and the linking of devices in logic operations. Switching times faster than 1 ns can be expected. Because all the layers are metals and charge carrier densities are high, fabrication of the device at submicron scales is quite possible and operation at the nanometer scale is conceivable. Thus, the possibility of achieving high packing densities is very plausible, and is not obviated by problems common to semiconductors such as heat dissipation and low carrier density.
Index Keywords: Carrier concentration; Charge carriers; Electron transport properties; Electrons; Heat losses; Metals; Nanotechnology; Bipolar spin transistor; Spin polarized transport; Zeeman energy; Bipolar transistors

Abstract: In the 'New Sunshine Program' of AIST, the R & D of the technologies for distributed electric energy storage is going on, and the high energy density and long life types of lithium secondary batteries are being developed. One of issues of the lithium secondary batteries for distributed electric energy storage is estimation of the temperature rise concerning with battery performance, reliability and safety. Thermal simulation is useful and helpful not only for thermal design of the batteries but also for understanding thermal behaviors during charge and discharge of the batteries. A joint research on thermal simulation technology for the batteries between Electrotechnical Laboratory (ETL) and Lithium Battery Energy Storage Technology Research Association (LIBES) has been carried out since November, 1994. This paper describes the research results obtained in ETL and four commission companies to LIBES.

Abstract: A solution to the problem of variable demand for electricity is presented by proposing a new electric energy storage system which uses nuclear energy from a high-temperature-gas-cooled-reactor. Authors: Short Alvin, Bala Karanam, Glawischnig Hans
Title: Low dose ion implantation characterization for Vt control
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Ion Implantation Technology
Affiliations: IBM, Hopewell Junction, United States
Authors with affiliations: Short, Alvin, IBM, Hopewell Junction, United States; Bala, Karanam, IBM, Hopewell Junction, United States; Glawischnig, Hans, IBM, Hopewell Junction, United States
Abstract: Tight control of threshold voltages (Vt's) is required for DRAM, logic and analog designs. Process factors such as oxide thickness, implantation dose/energy, and substrate doping are critical to meet the product Vt targets and tolerances. The peak carrier densities of threshold voltage adjust implants used in DRAMs are located very close to the Si-SiO2 interface. In this paper, we apply an implant dose monitoring technique using Hg-gate MOS pulsed CV for optimization of low doses for control Vt's for N- and buried channel PFETs in quarter micron technology. This monitoring technique called Partial Implant Dose (PID) essentially measures a portion of the total implanted dose obtained by integrating the carrier concentration profile between two defined limits. PID measurements have been successfully applied to identify ion implanter tool problems. Tool stability, dose offsets and uniformity of different implanters were controlled by mapping PIDs for 200 mm wafers in a semi-manufacturing fab. Implant energies of 10-60 keV with a dose range of 1E12 to 7E12/cm2 were used through 7.5 to 15 nm screen oxides. Furnace and RTA activations were examined. Al-gate MOS capacitors fabricated by evaporation of Al-dots through a shadow mask were used for comparison with Hg-gate PID measurements. The Hg-gate measurements predict that a 5% variation in nominal implanted dose correlates with a 5% variation in PIDs. Day to day dose repeatability for B+ 10 keV 5.5E12/cm2 is about 1%. The in-line PID measurements are correlated with device Vt's.
Index Keywords: Capacitance measurement; Capacitors; Carrier concentration; Chemical activation; Dosimetry; Gates (transistor); Masks; MOS devices; Photoresists; Random access storage; Voltage control; Partial implant dose (PID) measurements; Ion implantation

Authors: Kanari K., Takano K., Saito Y.
Title: Thermal behavior and simulation of a lithium secondary battery
Source title: Denshi Gijutsu Sogo Kenkyusho Iho/Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Kanari, K.; Takano, K.; Saito, Y.
Abstract: In the 'New Sunshine Program' of AIST, the R & D under 'Distributed Battery Electric Energy Storage Technology' is going on, and the high energy density and long life types of lithium secondary batteries are being developed. One of the important issues of the lithium secondary batteries for distributed electric energy storage is estimation of the temperature change during battery operation. In this study, the temperature changes of an about 1 Ah scale lithium ion cell (a cylindrical type C/LiCoO2 cell) during charging and discharging for 0.2C to 2C have been experimentally investigated. We have also estimated the temperature changes of the lithium ion cell during charging and discharging by applying a two dimensional thermal conduction model, and compared them with the experimental results. In case of discharging mode, fairly good agreement between the estimated and measured temperatures is obtained.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Electric discharges; Secondary batteries; Simulation; Lithium secondary batteries; Lithium batteries

Title: Simple analysis of grating resonators by image parameter theory
