Authors: Levitskij E.A., Aristov Yu.I., Tokarev M.M., Parmon V.N.
Title: "Chemical Heat Accumulators": A new approach to accumulating low potential heat
Source title: Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells
Affiliations: Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Levitskij, E.A., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Aristov, Yu.I., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Tokarev, M.M., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation; Parmon, V.N., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation
Abstract: The first presentation of new composite Chemical Heat Accumulation materials based on granulated open-porous matrix filled with a hygroscopic substance is given. At storing heat, the materials operate in a reversible hydration/dehydration mode. When crystalline hydrates of simple salts are used as the hygroscopic substance, the new materials allow to reach the heat storing capacity up to 2000 kJ kg-1 even for accumulation of low temperature heat (of circa 20-40°C). The materials also possess improved properties for mass and heat transfer. All these make a serious advantage of these materials in comparison with those using a latent melting-solidification heat as well as with zeolites capable of reversible hydration/dehydration. The new materials can be widely used in energy efficient and freons-less air conditioning devices, for cooling the electronic units, fire-extinguishing and some other applications.

Title: Missions to the Sun

Abstract: The proceedings contain 29 papers. The topics discussed include: concept for a miniature solar magnetograph; tomography of the solar corona and the inner heliosphere: the solar imaging of coronal extended structures (SLICES); high-spectral-resolution x-ray measurements of solar flares and gama ray bursts on two new small satellites; problem of designing a solar stereoscopic observatory; conceptual design for a solar instrument on the proposed Spartan lite spacecraft; measuring storage and release of magnetic free-energy; online analysis and compression of spectra-spectroheliograms; compact particle detector for low-energy particle measurements; new high-thermal-conductivity composite material for high-precision space optics; time series restoration from ground-based solar observations; and enhancing the spatial resolution of solar coronagraph images using dynamic imaging.

Authors: Murphy G.A., Rust D.M., Strohbehn K., Eaton H.A.C., Keil S.L., Keller C.U., Wiborg P.
Title: Flare genesis experiment
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins Univ., Applied Physics Lab., United States; AFGL Phillips Lab., United States; National Optical Astronomy Observatories, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, G.A., Johns Hopkins Univ., Applied Physics Lab., United States; Rust, D.M., Johns Hopkins Univ., Applied Physics Lab., United States; Strohbehn, K., Johns Hopkins Univ., Applied Physics Lab., United States; Eaton, H.A.C., Johns Hopkins Univ., Applied Physics Lab., United States; Keil, S.L., AFGL Phillips Lab., United States; Keller, C.U., National Optical Astronomy Observatories, United States; Wiborg, P., AFGL Phillips Lab., United States
Abstract: In January 1996, the Flare Genesis Experiment was carried for 19 days by a 29.4 M cu. ft helium-filled balloon in the stratosphere above Antarctica, during which over 14000 images of the Sun were recorded. Long-duration ballooning provides a relatively inexpensive means to observe the Sun under near-space conditions and to develop instrumentation and techniques that will be used on future solar space missions. The purpose of the flight was to improve understanding of the mechanisms involved in many different types of solar activity, particularly flares and solar filament eruptions. Achieving this goal demanded the development of a platform for an 80-cm F/1.S optical telescope that would be stable to 10 arcseconds. In addition, we developed an image motion compensation system capable of holding the Sun's image to better than the system's 0.2 arcsecond diffraction limit Other key elements on board included a lithium-niobate Fabry-Perot etalon filter to provide a tuneable 0.016-nm bandpass over a wide wavelength range, a fast 1534 x 1024-pixel Kodak CCD camera, and 180 GBytes of on-board storage. There was also a system for sending commands and receiving telemetry and a high-speed downlink for sending images during periods when the payload was in line of sight of the ground station. On-board computers provided a command and control system capable of near-autonomous operation. During most of the flight, contact with the payload was sporadic, so operation was primarily under autonomous control. © 1996 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wang Z., Hahn U.
Title: Design analyses with XRAP for PETRA/HASYLAB beamline filters/windows
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Experimental Facilities Division, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL  60439, United States; Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrafle 85, Hamburg, D-22607, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Z., Argonne National Laboratory, Experimental Facilities Division, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL  60439, United States; Hahn, U., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrafle 85, Hamburg, D-22607, Germany
Abstract: The first synchrotron radiation beamline using a 4-m-long undulator at the 12 GeV storage ring PETRA delivers hard x-ray photons usable up to 300 keV. In order to reduce the low energy photon flux and the related thermal load on the beamline optics, graphite, beryllium, aluminum, copper, and iron filters or windows are installed. With a planned upgrade of the undulator, a deflection parameter of K = 2.59 will be reached. The total radiated power of the undulator will then reach (with closed gap) about 15 kW. The central power density will be about 107 W/mrad2. Therefore, the design of the filters and windows which interact directly with the white beam becomes a very challenging engineering problem. The heat transfer and thermal stress analyses of PETRA filters and windows are presented. Different filter or window thicknesses, sizes, at different deflection parameters of the undulator, are discussed. Improved filter or window designs are proposed. © 1996 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Recently, the suitability of inelastic X-ray scattering for the investigation of solid and fluid 4He has been demonstrated. For the test experiments an energy resolution of the order of 10-15 meV was used at the backscattering spectrometer INELAX at the storage ring DORIS of DESY, Hamburg. Lattice excitations were observed for momentum transfers along the c axis of h.c.p. helium crystals which were grown in situ at pressures of 54-63 MPa and at temperatures of 4.2-6.4 K. At 10 K above the melting point, energy-loss signals could also be detected from the liquid helium at equivalent momentum transfers.

Authors: Hofstaetter A., Scharmann A., Scheib S.
Title: EPR and ENDOR investigations on the X-ray storage phosphors BaSO4 and SrSO4
Affiliations: Physics Institute, University of Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, D-35392 Giessen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hofstaetter, A.; Scharmann, A.; Scheib, S., Physics Institute, University of Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, D-35392 Giessen, Germany
Abstract: X-ray storage phosphors are applied in many areas including medical diagnostics, crystallography or material inspection. The main advantage of this method compared to conventional X-ray films is the linearity of dose response over more than six orders of magnitude. The readout procedure by scanning with a laser, however, implies severe restrictions with respect to the decay time of the photostimulated luminescence. Therefore a need for fast phosphors exists. We found that BaSO4 and SrSO4 decay in the 10 ns range and therefore are very promising materials. Investigation of the thermally stimulated luminescence of these compounds after X-irradiation at room temperature and parallel of the photostimulability showed that a lot of X-ray energy is stored in centers not effective for the latter process. We therefore thoroughly investigated by EPR and ENDOR the radiation effects in the two sulfates and their thermal stability. Phosphate and F+-centers turned out to play an important role for this application. Since their decay contributes to a TL glow peak above 350°C, this system is also interesting with respect to dosimetric applications.X-ray storage phosphors are applied in many areas including medical diagnostics, crystallography or material inspection. Abstract: Results obtained for electron-irradiated oat, corn and wheat kernels are discussed. The applied irradiation doses were up to 160 kGy. For doses upto approx. 50 kGy the number of free radicals produced by the irradiation is linear with the absorbed dose; moreover, the decay at room temperature in the dark or in the presence of light is quite similar. These facts point to the possible use of these kernels as dosimeters. An analysis of the free radical decay as a function of time and temperature shows the contribution of at least three types of radicals, whose half-lifes, radiochemical yields and activation energies are given.Results obtained for electron-irradiated oat, corn and wheat kernels are discussed. These facts point to the possible use of these kernels as dosimeters. An analysis of the free radical decay as a function of time and temperature shows the contribution of at least three types of radicals, whose half-lifes, radiochemical yields and activation energies are given.

Authors: Kaptan I.N., Kilic A.
Title: A theoretical and experimental investigation of a novel built-in-storage solar water heater
Affiliations: Istanbul Technical University, Mechanical Engineering Faculty, 80191, Gumussuyu, Istanbul, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kaptan, I.N., Istanbul Technical University, Mechanical Engineering Faculty, 80191, Gumussuyu, Istanbul, Turkey; Kilic, A., Istanbul Technical University, Mechanical Engineering Faculty, 80191, Gumussuyu, Istanbul, Turkey
Abstract: In this work, a novel built-in-storage type solar water heater of about 871 capacity has been investigated theoretically and experimentally for the case of no draw-off. The solar water heater which performs the dual function of absorbing and storing hot water is made of 5 pipes, each of length 1.8 m and diameter 12 cm. A baffle plate is placed inside each pipe. The experiments have been performed inside the laboratory using an artificial Sun consisting of 27 lamps. The water temperatures have been measured at various locations in the system. In the theoretical study, transient performance of the system is predicted by solving the mathematical model consisting of energy balance equations written for each control volume comprising one length of pipe. The equations are converted to finite difference form and then solved by a personal computer. The experimental results have been compared with the numerical model and a good agreement has been found between the experimental results and the theoretical predictions.

Abstract: For a recording medium such as dichromated gelatin, a quasi-Fourier transform holographic memory is preferred over the exact Fourier transform. We proceed here with angular multiplexing and consider undesired reconstructed waves such as cross-talk noise, and show that the signal-to-noise ratio is 33 dB for 20 angular multiplexed elements in 25 μm thickness of the recording medium. We also study the energy coupling between gratings to standardize the diffraction efficiency of each multiplexed grating. Copyright © 1996 Elsevier Science Ltd.

Title: `Dakota Sun' the next generation solar powered racing vehicle
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine

Abstract: The goal of the South Dakota Solar Motion Team (SMT) has always been to build the fastest and most efficient solar vehicle possible. The major design changes evident from the original `Solar Rolar' vehicle are the result of an evolutionary design process that has produced the highly competitive `Dakota Sun' design. The Dakota Sun is a three wheeled vehicle with separate cab solar array. The design allows for improved aerodynamics, decreased weight, lower rolling resistance, and ease of manufacture compared to the four wheeled catamaran. However, this design sacrifices total enclosed wheel base area, additional room for components, and added power from side solar panels.

Abstract: At present, the building branch in Germany is undergoing recession. In line with this, every brickmaker is making great efforts to minimize production costs. This involves taking a very searching look at the running costs of existing plants and in addition to the investment costs for new plants. One of the new plants available is the Roxitherm RTZ from Lufttechnik Bayreuth. Title: Optical layout and resolution of the ASTRID plane folding mirror spherical grating monochromator
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment
Affiliations: ISA the Inst. of Phys. and Astron., University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Physics Department, Odense University, Campusvej 55, DK-5230 Odense M, Denmark; Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; MAX-Lab., University of Lund, Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden

Abstract: We present the optical layout, the theoretically expected and experimentally obtained resolution of a plane, folding mirror spherical grating monochromator at the ASTRID storage ring in Denmark. The monochromator has a plane mirror in front of the grating and uses a variable included angle on the grating to obtain a zero defocus term. The advantages of this design are a fixed exit slit position, which makes it easier to refocus behind the exit slit, and the possibility to optimize the resolution for the energy regions, using different ranges of included angles. The maximum resolving power E/ΔE for 10 μm slits with full vertical acceptance increases from about 5700 for the high-energy grating to about 14000 for the low-energy grating. The resolution has been tested using absorption features of helium, argon and nitrogen. A resolution of 68 meV was obtained at the N2 K edge around 400 eV. At the He double resonances at 65 eV the 17+ structure was observed. In second order, at the He 7+ double resonance, a resolution of 1.4 meV was obtained. The resolving power E/ΔE at this energy (32 eV) is around 23 000.
Index Keywords: Argon; Diffraction gratings; Helium; Light absorption; Mirrors; Nitrogen; Optical design; Optical resolving power; Storage rings; Spherical grating monochromators; Monochromators

Abstract: The US Department of Energy's (DOE's) Environmental Restoration (ER) program is responsible for remediating thousands of contaminated sites across the DOE complex. A major concern during remediation is the secondary waste generated as a result of ER site remediation. The treatment, storage and disposal (TSD) of secondary waste generated as a result of ER site remediation is the responsibility of the waste management (WM) program. In order to manage TSD operations on ER generated waste, WM needs accurate and consistent estimates of the volume of secondary waste generated. This paper discuss three remedial processes and presents estimates of waste volumes generated during these processes.

Authors: Calder I.R.
Title: Dependence of rainfall interception on drop size: 1. Development of the two-layer stochastic model
Affiliations: Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Calder, I.R., Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom
Abstract: The original stochastic interception model (Calder, 1986, J. Hydrol., 89: 65-71) showed, through the use of Poisson probability statistics, that the rate at which vegetation canopies are wetted is dependent on the volume of the individual raindrops; for the same depth of rain applied, a greater depth of water will be retained on the canopy when raindrop volumes are small. This paper recognizes that vegetation canopies are wetted through both the primary impact of raindrops to the top layer of the canopy and secondary impacts, from drops falling from the vegetation, to lower layers of the canopy. It shows how drop volumes of primary raindrops can be calculated from the Marshall-Palmer distribution and drop volumes of secondary drops can be calculated from the 'characteristic' volume appropriate to the particular vegetation species. A two-layer stochastic model is described which calculates the rate at which canopies are wetted in relation to both primary and secondary drops. The paper also shows that, in addition to the volume- dependent stochastic wetting effect, there is also another drop-size- dependent wetting effect, related to the kinetic energy of the raindrops, which influences the maximum storage that can be achieved on the canopy. The wetting functions predicted for canopies of different density are described and the application of the model for assessing interception loss from forests, in relation to vegetation, climate and possible climatic change, is discussed.
Index Keywords: Climate change; Mathematical models; Probability; Random processes; Statistical methods; Marshall Palmer distribution; Rainfall interception; Stochastic wetting effects; Water storage capacity; Rain; canopy; drop size; interception; stochastic model

Authors: Calder I.R., Hall R.L., Rosier P.T.W., Bastable H.G., Prasanna K.T.
Title: Dependence of rainfall interception on drop size: 2. Experimental determination of the wetting functions and two-layer stochastic model parameters for five tropical tree species
Affiliations: Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom; University of Agricultural Sciences, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Calder, I.R., Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom; Hall, R.L., Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom; Rosier, P.T.W., Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom; Bastable, H.G., Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford OX10 8BB, United Kingdom; Prasanna, K.T., University of Agricultural Sciences, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Studies using a rainfall simulator were carried out to test the stochastic hypothesis embedded in the original formulation of the stochastic interception model and to determine the vegetation-dependent stochastic model parameters. These studies showed that for all the species investigated: (a) the rate of wetting was greatest for small volume drops this is in agreement with the stochastic wetting hypothesis; (b) the maximum canopy storage that was achieved is not, as is conventionally assumed, constant, but is dependent on drop size. The reduction in maximum canopy storage with increasing drop size is attributed to a dependence on drop kinetic energy.
Index Keywords: Functions; Mathematical models; Random processes; Wetting; Rainfall interception; Stochastic interception model; Stochastic wetting effects; Water storage capacity; Wetting functions; Rain; drop size; interception; kinetic energy; stochastic model; tree species

Authors: Christensen D.C., Dinehart S.M., Yarbro S.L.
Title: Technical considerations and policy requirements for plutonium management
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Christensen, D.C., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Dinehart, S.M., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Yarbro, S.L., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States
Abstract: The goals for plutonium management have changed dramatically over the past few years. Today, the challenge is focused on isolating plutonium from the environment and preparing it for permanent disposition. In parallel, the requirements for managing plutonium are rapidly changing. For example, there is a significant increase in public awareness on how facilities operate, increased attention to environmental safety and health (ES&H) concerns, greater interest in minimizing waste, more emphasis on protecting material from theft, providing materials for international inspection, and a resurgence of interest in using plutonium as an energy source. Of highest concern, in the immediate future, is protecting plutonium from theft or diversion, while the national policy on disposition is debated. These expanded requirements are causing a broadening of responsibilities within the Department of Energy (DOE) to include at least seven organizations. An unavoidable consequence is the divergence in approach and short-term goals for managing similar materials within each organization. The technology base does exist, properly, safely, and cost effectively to extract plutonium from excess weapons, residues, waste, and contaminated equipment and facilities, and to properly stabilize it. Extracting the plutonium enables it to be easily inventoried, packaged, and managed to minimize the risk of theft and diversion. Discarding excess plutonium does not sufficiently reduce the risk of diversion, and as a result, long-term containment of plutonium from the environment may not be able to be proven to the satisfaction of the public.

Authors: Duchesne I., Nylinder M.
Title: Measurement of the bark/wood shear strength: Practical methods to evaluate debarking resistance of Norway spruce and scots pine pulpwood
Affiliations: Swed. Univ. of Agricultural Sciences, Dept. of Forest Prod., P.O. Box 7008, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Duchesne, I., Swed. Univ. of Agricultural Sciences, Dept. of Forest Prod., P.O. Box 7008, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden; Nylinder, M., Swed. Univ. of Agricultural Sciences, Dept. of Forest Prod., P.O. Box 7008, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to describe how the ability to debark can change due to log storage and to explore a practical method to measure the freshness of pulpwood when it is delivered with respect to its debarking resistance. Bark in pulp is undesirable because it increases the need to use chemicals for cooking and bleaching. Dry pulpwood increases energy consumption and wood loss when debarking, chipping, and refining. The bark/wood shear strength of 40 spruce and 40 pine pulpwood piles at 4 pulpmills in Sweden was studied. The piles measured 10 m3 and were evaluated over a 14- or 15-week storage period. The bark/wood shear strength did not change appreciably during the first 6 weeks of storage. After 6 weeks, an obvious increase in the shear strength was observed. Both bark/wood shear strength and green density were correlated (r2=0.75) with the moisture content of the sapwood. The variation within and between logs was high. Norway spruce had a higher shear strength than Scots pine. The models tested show relatively good promise for finding extremes (wood piles with a high shear strength), which can lead to unsatisfactory debarking.

Authors: Järvelä P., Shucai L., Järvelä P.
Title: Dynamic mechanical properties and morphology of polypropylene/maleated polypropylene blends
Affiliations: Tampere University of Technology, Institute of Plastics Technology, P.O. Box 589, 33101 Tampere, Finland; VTT Chemical Technology, Polymer and Fibre Technology, P.O. Box 1402, 33101 Tampere, Finland; Department of Chemical Engineering, TianJin Institute of Light Industry, TianJin 300222, China
Authors with affiliations: Järvelä, P., Tampere University of Technology, Institute of Plastics Technology, P.O. Box 589, 33101 Tampere, Finland; Shucai, L., Tampere University of Technology, Institute of Plastics Technology, P.O. Box 589, 33101 Tampere, Finland, Department of Chemical Engineering, TianJin Institute of Light Industry, TianJin 300222, China; Järvelä, P., VTT Chemical Technology, Polymer and Fibre Technology, P.O. Box 1402, 33101 Tampere, Finland
Abstract: The dynamic mechanical properties of both homopolypropylene (PPVC)/Maleated Polypropylene (PP-g-MA) and ethylene-propylene block copolymer (PPSC)/Maleated Polypropylene (PP-g-MA) blends have been studied by using a dynamic mechanical thermal analyzer (PL-DMTA MKII) over a wide temperature range, covering a frequency zone from 0.3 to 30 Hz. With increasing content of PP-g-MA, α relaxation of both blends gradually shift to a lower temperature and the apparent activation energy ΔEα increases. In PPVC/ PP-g-MA blends, β relaxation shifts to a higher temperature as the content of PP-g-MA increases from 0 to 20 wt % and then change unobviously for further varying content of PP-g-MA from 20 to 35 wt %. On the contrary, in the PPSC/PP-g-MA blends β1 relaxation, the apparent activation energy ΔEβ1 and β2 relaxation are almost unchanged with blend composition, while ΔEβ2 increases with an increase of PP-g-MA content. In the composition range studied, storage modulus E′ of both blends increases before α relaxation as content of PP-g-MA increases; however, the increment of E′ value for PPSC/PP-g-MA blends decreases progressively between β2 and α relaxation with increasing temperature, but in the region the increment for PPVC/PP-g-MA blends is independent of temperature. The flexural properties of PPVC/PP-g-MA blend show more obvious improvement on PP than one of PPSC/PP-g-MA blends. Scanning electron micrographs of fracture surfaces of the blends clearly demonstrate two-phase morphology, viz. the discrete particles homogeneously disperse in the continuous phase, the main difference in the morphology between both blends is that the interaction between the particles and the continuous phase is stronger for PPVC/PP-g-MA than for PPSC/PP-g-MA blend. By the correlation of the morphology with dynamic and mechanical properties of the blends, the variation of the relaxation behavior and mechanical properties with the component structure, blend composition, vibration frequency, and as well as the features observed in these variation are reasonably interpreted. © 1996 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Authors: Coelho R.D., Martin D.L., Chaudrhy F.H.
Title: Effect of LEPA irrigation on storage in implanted reservoirs
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; ASAE, United States; Dept. of Biological Systems Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, United States; Biological Systems Engineering Dept., University of Nebraska, Chase Hall, Lincoln, NE 68583-0726, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coelho, R.D., University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Martin, D.L., ASAE, United States, Dept. of Biological Systems Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, United States, Biological Systems Engineering Dept., University of Nebraska, Chase Hall, Lincoln, NE 68583-0726, United States; Chaudrhy, F.H., University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: Successful irrigation with a Low Energy Precision Application (LEPA) package on a center pivot depends on storing some water on the soil surface until it can infiltrate. Storage can be increased with basin or implanted reservoir tillage; however, persistence of storage throughout the irrigation season may be limiting. We developed a method to measure the cross-sectional profiles and the volume of storage in implanted reservoirs. We used these methods to measure the change of storage during the irrigation season on a silt loam soil (0.2% slope). We evaluated three configurations of the implement used to create the reservoirs and five water discharge rates with the LEPA devices. Surface storage can be divided into depression and detention storage. The average depression storage, water stored completely within a reservoir, varies from 5 to 8 L. For the spacing of reservoirs and LEPA devices we used, this would provide enough water for the evapotranspiration of mature corn for one day in the summer. The six-spoke configuration of the reservoir tillage implement produced the largest amount of depression storage. Depression storage increased during the irrigation season for most conditions indicating that subsidence within the reservoir is prominent. Detention storage, water that flows along the furrow above the reservoirs, was larger (18 to 22 L). The total dynamic storage (depression plus detention) was about the same for all implement configurations. Dynamic storage increased slightly during the season, but changes were only significant for the five-spoke configuration. The reservoir profiles changed shape during the season. The rate of water application affected the change of shape of the reservoirs. High discharge rates produced deeper zones of sedimentation at the bottom of the reservoir while intermediate application rates produced more erosion or subsidence within the reservoir.
Author Keywords: Center pivot; Implanted reservoirs; Runoff; Surface storage; Uniformity
Index Keywords: irrigation; reservoirs; soils; irrigation; LEPA; low energy precision application; soil water; water storage

Title: Science instrumentation for the student nitric oxide explorer
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO  80309-0590, United States; High Altitude Observatory, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder, CO  80307, United States

Abstract: The Student Nitric Oxide Explorer (SNOE) is a small satellite to be designed built and operated at the University of Colorado under the Student Explorer Demonstration Initiative (STEDI) from the Universities Space Research Association. The goal of the STEDI program is to demonstrate that low cost satellite missions can be done with large student involvement. The primary science goals of SNOE are to measure thermospheric nitric oxide (NO) and its variability over the lifeline of the mission. SNOE will also monitor the solar irradiance at soft X-ray wavelengths and the auroral energy deposition at high latitudes. Three science instruments are required to achieve the simultaneous measurements: An ultraviolet spectrometer for NO; a solar soft X-ray photometer; and a far ultraviolet photometer for studying the aurora. The instruments are designed to represent a minimum impact on the spacecraft, particularly in terms of data storage and interactions with the command and data handling system. The focus of this paper is the outline of the design of the science instruments. We discuss why these instruments are well suited for smaller, lower cost satellite missions. © 1996 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Full scale thermal storage tests were conducted in a room lined with PCM wallboard having latent heat storage capacity. The results were compared with those obtained from tests conducted in a similar room lined with ordinary wallboard. The research showed that PCM wallboard can function efficiently as a thermal storage medium which can be applied to peak load shifting, improved use of waste and solar heat as well as more efficient operation of heating and cooling equipment.

Authors: Zherlitsyn A.G., Kanaev G.G., Tsvetkov V.I.
Title: Intense microwave pulse production from vircators with inductive energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Box 25, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation; Tsvetkov, V.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics of Tomsk, Polytechnical University, P.O. Box 25, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation
Abstract: The high-voltage source has been developed for investigations of the vircator operation. It contains an inductive storage, electrically exploded opening switch, and separating spark gap. The inductive storage is made in the form of two inductively coupled coils; the primary coil provides fast current input from the pulsed current generator and the secondary coil, with the electrically exploded opening switch, forms the voltage pulse of parameters required for the microwave source operation.The microwave source is the vircator oftriode configuration. The results of the experiments performed are presented. At the primary voltage applied to the pulsed current generator of 40 kV and the stored energy of 12 kJ, the vircator voltage pulse is formed of 600 kV amplitude and 360 ns duration. The vircator current reaches the value of 13-14 kA. The stable microwave generation has been obtained in the S-band. The microwave power exceeds 300 MW and the microwave pulse duration is of 1 80-200 ns. © 1996 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Lee C.H., Saito H., Inoue T., Nojima S.
Title: Time-resolved small-angle x-ray scattering studies on the crystallization of poly(ethylene terephthalate)
Affiliations: Dept. of Organ. and Polymeric Mat., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan; JAIST, Tatsunokuchi, Ishikawa 923-12, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lee, C.H., Dept. of Organ. and Polymeric Mat., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan; Saito, H., Dept. of Organ. and Polymeric Mat., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan; Inoue, T., Dept. of Organ. and Polymeric Mat., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152, Japan; Nojima, S., JAIST, Tatsunokuchi, Ishikawa 923-12, Japan
Abstract: We investigated the isothermal crystallization of poly(ethylene terephthalate) by timeresolved small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) using synchrotron radiation. At the early stage, the SAXS intensity decreased monotonously with scattering angle (stage I). Then the SAXS profile showed a peak and the peak position progressively moved to a wider angle with crystallization time (stage II). Finally, the peak intensity rapidly increased, keeping the peak angle constant (stage III). The Guinier and the correlation function analyses suggested that crystalline domains of several tens of nanometers in diameter appear and they consist of the highly disordered lamellae (stage I). In stage II, the crystalline domains grow up to the larger domains in which stacking of lamellae is achieved by insertion of newly formed lamellae between the preformed lamellae. Then they develop to yield the spherulites by attaining a higher ordering of the lamellar stacks in stage III.

Authors: Duboc P., Marison I., Von Stockar U.
Title: Physiology of Saccharomyces cerevisiae during cell cycle oscillations
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical Engineering, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Duboc, P., Institute of Chemical Engineering, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Marison, I., Institute of Chemical Engineering, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Von Stockar, U., Institute of Chemical Engineering, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Synchronized populations of Saccharomyces cerevisiae CBS 426 were characterized by autonomous oscillation of carbon dioxide evolution rate, oxygen uptake rate and heat production rate. Application of simple mass balance principles for non-steady state systems indicated that oscillations were basically characterized by changes in biomass production rate. Cell component analysis showed that the changes in cellular fractions during oscillations were due to changes in production rates of proteins and carbohydrates. The growth process of the cell components was divided into two phenomena: the formation of new cells during mitosis with a low yield and the size increase of new born cells with high yield.Synchronized populations of Saccharomyces cerevisiae CBS 426 are characterized by autonomous oscillations of process variables. CO2 evolution rate, O2 uptake rate and heat production rate varied by a factor of 2 for a continuous culture grown at a dilution rate of 0.10 h-1. Elemental analysis showed that the carbon mass fraction of biomass did not change. Since the reactor is not at steady state, the elemental and energy balances were calculated on cumulated quantities, i.e. the integral of the reaction rates. It was possible to show that carbon, degree of reduction and energy balances matched. Application of simple mass balance principles for non-steady state systems indicated that oscillations were basically characterized by changes in biomass production rate. In addition, the amount of intermediates, e.g. ethanol or acetate, produced or consumed was negligible. Growth rate was low during the S-phase (0.075 h-1) and high during the G2, M and G1 phases (0.125 h-1) for a constant dilution rate of 0.10 h-1. However, nitrogen, ash, sulfur and potassium content showed systematic increases during the S-phase (bud initiation). Cell component analyses showed that changes in cellular fractions during oscillations (storage carbohydrate content decreased during the S-phase) were due to changes in production rates, particularly for protein and carbohydrates. Nevertheless, using the data evaluation techniques for dynamic systems presented here, it was shown that storage carbohydrates are not consumed during the S-phase. Only the synthesis rate of the different cell components changed depending on position in cell cycle. The growth process may be divided into two phenomena: the formation of new cells during mitosis with a low yield, and size increase of new born cells with high yield. Both kinetic and stoichiometric coefficients varied with the position in the oscillation: the results showed that biomass structure changed and that specific growth rate, as well as biomass yield, varied by ± 25% during the oscillation.
Author Keywords: Autonomous oscillation; Cell component; Cell cycle; Dynamic system; Growth rate; Mass balance

Authors: Brown E.R., Parker C.D.
Title: Resonant tunnel diodes as submillimetre-wave sources
Source title: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
Affiliations: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173-9108, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, E.R., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173-9108, United States; Parker, C.D., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173-9108, United States
Abstract: Resonant-tunnelling diodes (RTDS) are one of the only quantum-transport devices that operate effectively at room temperature, and are well known for their high-speed coherent generation and switching characteristics associated with the negative differ-ential resistance (NDR) region. This paper addresses their capability as high-frequency coherent sources. Two types of sources will be addressed here: (i) quasi-sinusoidal oscillators connected to a resonant circuit, and (ii) relaxation oscillators connected to a high-frequency energy-storage element, such as a length of transmission line. To date, the highest-frequency sinusoidal oscillator was a waveguide-mounted InAs-AlSb RTD that performed up to 712 GHz. Transmission-line relaxation oscillators have been demonstrated only at microwave frequencies but show promise as submillimetre-wave sources. Their output waveform consists of a sequence of pulses having a repetition rate determined by the electrical delay of the transmission line and a pulse width determined by the switching time of the diode. Because they do not require DC-bias stability in the NDR region, they are quite amenable to power-combining techniques, such as parallel arrays, and could behave in an analogous manner to the atomic species in a mode-locked laser.

Authors: McKerchar A.I., Pearson C.P., Moss M.E.
Title: Prediction of summer inflows to lakes in the Southern Alps, New Zealand, using the spring Southern Oscillation Index
Affiliations: Natl. Inst. of Water/Atmosph. R., P.O. Box 8602, Christchurch, New Zealand; Bayeswater, 6230 North Oasis Court, Tucson, AZ 85704, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKerchar, A.I., Natl. Inst. of Water/Atmosph. R., P.O. Box 8602, Christchurch, New Zealand; Pearson, C.P., Natl. Inst. of Water/Atmosph. R., P.O. Box 8602, Christchurch, New Zealand; Moss, M.E., Bayeswater, 6230 North Oasis Court, Tucson, AZ 85704, United States
Abstract: The relationship between the austral spring Southern Oscillation Index (SOI) and the austral summer runoff is investigated for a broad, contiguous region (20 000 km2) of the Southern Alps, New Zealand, representing 70% of the length of the Alps. Using a Bayesian method developed in an earlier study (Moss et al., 1994, Water Resour. Res., 30(10): 2717-2723), probabilities of summer inflows to alpine lakes when the spring SOI is positive (La Nina conditions) are shown to be significantly larger than in springs when SOl is neutral or negative (El Nino conditions). This has major economic significance because the lakes feed hydroelectric power plants that produce typically 43% of the electrical energy used in New Zealand. The lake inflows peak in spring and summer, and use of the available controlled storage must be scheduled carefully to meet power demands that peak in winter. We hypothesise that this occurs because in springs with La Nina conditions, there is a relative absence of snow accumulation, and hence less summer snowmelt.

Authors: Souch C., Wolfe C.P., Grimmond C.S.B.
Title: Wetland evaporation and energy partitioning: Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Indiana Univ. Purdue Univ. I., 213 Cavanaugh Hall, Indianapolis, IN 46202, United States; Sch. of Pub./Environmental Affairs, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Climate and Meteorology Program, Department of Geography, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Souch, C., Department of Geography, Indiana Univ. Purdue Univ. I., 213 Cavanaugh Hall, Indianapolis, IN 46202, United States; Wolfe, C.P., Sch. of Pub./Environmental Affairs, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Grimmond, C.S.B., Climate and Meteorology Program, Department of Geography, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: For most wetlands precipitation and evapotranspiration are the major components of water gain and loss. However, studies of the hydrology of wetlands largely ignore evaporation, or calculate it by difference or some very simple measure. As part of an integrated study of the hydrology and ecology of wetlands in the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, evaporation was measured directly as its energy equivalent, the latent heat flux, using eddy correlation techniques for a 10 day period in June 1994. In addition, data were collected on the other surface energy balance fluxes (net all-wave radiation and sensible heat flux), and ancillary meteorological variables (wind speed and direction, temperature, pressure, relative humidity, solar radiation and water depth). Overall, latent heat flux dissipated 48% of the available radiant energy, storage heat flux 35%, and sensible heat flux 17%. A simple hysteresis model for the storage heat flux was developed which performed extremely well. Proximity to Lake Michigan resulted in evaporation rates close to the equilibrium rate (average Priestley-Taylor α = 1.035), which were affected strongly by net all-wave radiation. Three commonly used models of evaporation, Penman, Priestley-Taylor (α = 1.26) and equilibrium (α = 1.0) are evaluated. The relative success of the equilibrium model, with its limited data requirements, offers great potential for longer-term modeling of water and energy exchanges in this type of wetland environment.

Authors: Knecht W.
Title: Engines for Natural Gas and Vehicle Applications - An Experience
Affiliations: Iveco, Arbon, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Knecht, W., Iveco, Arbon, Switzerland
Abstract: Road vehicles powered with internal combustion engines employing natural gas have attracted in recent years considerable interest. Apart from the widespread availability of natural gas, this interest is due to the potential to achieve extremely low emission levels in road vehicles. For some countries having natural gas sources, a promotion of natural gas may be an important part of the national energy strategy aiming at: reducing dependence on imported oil supplies reducing flare-off and wastage overcoming environmental pollution problems. This paper reviews basic aspects of gas engines and their mixture formation and combustion processes. Then the layout and characteristics of Iveco gas engines for heavy duty vehicles which are derived from present production diesel engines are described and their characteristics given. Subsequently some vehicle applications, aspects of gas storage, the vehicle installations and gas filling stations are outlined and in a final section the experiences with natural gas powered road vehicles such as city buses, trucks and community vehicles in Europe are presented. © 1996 SAE International. All rights reserved.

Authors: Fukuse T., Hirata T., Nakamura T., Ueda M., Liu C.-J., Hitomi S., Wada H.
Title: Effects of sugars on pulmonary function and metarolism after pulmonary preservation
Affiliations: Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fukuse, T., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Hirata, T., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Nakamura, T., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Ueda, M., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Liu, C.-J., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Hitomi, S., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Wada, H., Department of Thoracic Surgery, Chest Disease Research Institute, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Purpose: We studied the effect of glucose(Mw 180), sucrose (Mw 342) and trenalose (Mw 342) in preservation solutions on cold storage of rat lungs using an ex vivo rat lung model. Methods: Male inbred Lewis rats were used. The homologous blood deoxygenated by fresh rat lung was perfused to the postpreserved lung with a constant perfusion rate. Animals were allocated into four groups according to the solution and ischemic interval (4°C). Control group (n=6); saline and no ischemic time. Other 3 groups were preserved for 14 hours in extracellular type trehalose-containing solution (ET-Kyoto solution) (ET-K group, n=6) or in the modified ET-Kyoto solution in which trehalose was replaced by glucose (EG-K group, n=6), or sucrose (ES-K group, n=6). After ischemia, preserved lung was reperfused for 60 minutes. Airway pressure (Paw), pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) were continuously monitored and blood gas analysis was performed every ten minutes. Wet to dry lung weight (W/D) ratios after the experiment were calculated. ATP, ADP, and AMP levels in the lung after flush and storage were measured. P <0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results: In ET-K group, all lungs showed excellent physiological data. EGK group had significantly increased Paw, PAP, and pulmonary vascular shunt fraction compared to Control or ET-K group. W/D ratios of EG-K and ES-K group were significantly higher than those of Control or ET-K group. ATP levels and energy charge in the lungs after storage did not decrease compared to those after flush in all groups. Conclusion: Trehalose provides superior lung preservation compared to glucose or sucrose, and it probably is not due to energy state in the lung. Clinical implications: Trehalose will bring about the development of new and better solutions.

Authors: Artemenko S.N.
Title: Efficiency of transfer of microwave energy to a load with resonant compression of rf pulses
Affiliations: Scientific-Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, Tomsk Polytechnical University, Tomsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Artemenko, S.N., Scientific-Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, Tomsk Polytechnical University, Tomsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The transfer of energy from a microwave generator to a load is studied with resonant compression of the output signal from the generator through storage of the signal energy in a volume cavity with subsequent rapid delivery to the load. The dependence of the energy transfer efficiency and gain of microwave compressors arranged in "straight-through" circuits and in circuits with a combined energy input-output element on the duration of the signal from the generator is studied for different intrinsic quality factors of the cavity and durations of the output signal. The variations in the transfer efficiency are compared with the corresponding variations in the storage efficiency. It is shown that in a "straight-through" microwave compressor circuit the maximum transfer efficiency and maximum gain do not coincide with the maximum storage efficiency. © 1996 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Wong I.H.
Title: An underground pumped storage scheme in the Bukit Timah granite of Singapore
Affiliations: Sch. of Civ. and Struct. Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639746, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Wong, I.H., Sch. of Civ. and Struct. Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639746, Singapore
Abstract: Pumped storage is an energy storage method that involves the pumping of water from a lower reservoir to an upper reservoir during off-peak period using low cost power and releasing of the water from the upper reservoir to produce electricity during peak load period. Because of the very small and relatively flat land area of Singapore, a conventional surface pumped storage plant is not feasible. A pumped storage plant can be constructed here by siting the upper reservoir in one of the many abandoned granite quarries and by placing the lower reservoir and the powerhouse underground in the Bukit Timah granite, which is sound, massive and impervious. The capital costs for a pumped storage plant could be the same as those of an oil-fired plant of comparable size. When the very high cost of land in Singapore is taken into account, an underground pumped storage scheme for peaking purposes becomes attractive.
Index Keywords: Bukit Timah granite; pumped storage plant; reservoir construction; underground storage; Singapore

Authors: Dogan H.K., Bayindirli L.
Title: Mechanism of egg deterioration induced by exposure to high temperatures
Affiliations: Middle East Technical University, Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey; Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Dogan, H.K., Middle East Technical University, Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey, Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey; Bayindirli, L., Middle East Technical University, Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey, Food Engineering Department, 06531, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Storage deterioration of eggs induced by exposure of fresh eggs to high temperatures was studied. A comparative study was conducted to investigate the effects of different storage temperatures on the interior quality of eggs and to reach conclusions as to possible mechanisms by which deterioration occurs. Results were used to compare and to calculate reaction rates. An overall activation energy of approximately 13 400 calories was calculated for decrease in yolk index when stored at temperatures varying from 4° to 45 °C. The observed activation energy was considered evidence that the basic cause of the deterioration of yolk membrane is a conventional chemical or biochemical reaction.

Authors: Hawkins A.J.S., Day A.J
Title: The metabolic basis of genetic differences in growth efficiency among marine animals
Source title: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
Affiliations: Plymouth Marine Laboratory, Prospect Place, Plymouth PL1 3DH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hawkins, A.J.S., Plymouth Marine Laboratory, Prospect Place, Plymouth PL1 3DH, United Kingdom; Day, A.J, Plymouth Marine Laboratory, Prospect Place, Plymouth PL1 3DH, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper initially reviews evidence for genetic influences upon growth efficiency. We then discuss recent advances in our understanding of the metabolic links whereby genotype affects whole-animal physiology and growth efficiency through differences in protein metabolism. Most evidently, these differences are in protein turnover, defined as the continuous breakdown and replacement of cellular proteins and which provides the flux that is necessary for metabolic regulation and adaptation. Whether comparing individuals, including associations with genetic heterozygosity, or considering the response to breeding, selection or genetic manipulation, reduced whole-body protein turnover consistently underlies lower energy expenditure and higher growth efficiencies. The present paper describes results from our recent studies that have explored the metabolic basis and functional consequences of these differences in whole-body protein turnover by comparing the component activities of specific proteolytic pathways in the mussel Mytilus edulis. Traditionally, it has been thought that requirements for biosynthesis dominate energy expenditure. Nevertheless, a large component of about 30% of the empirical costs of protein deposition cannot be attributed to known synthetic processes and it has been suggested that costs of protein turnover may contribute to the discrepancy. Findings are presented showing that separate whole-body activities of the four main lysosomal proteases were collectively associated with as much as 73% of the variation in maintenance energy expenditure observed between individual mussels. These associations were positive for cathepsin B, cathepsin D and leucine aminopeptidase (Lap-2). Alternatively, higher whole body activity of cathepsin L was associated with lower maintenance energy expenditure, possibly because cathepsin L was most active in the main tissue of nutrient storage, thereby mobilising energy reserves and reducing the need for protein turnover in remaining tissues. Results therefore indicate profound physiological consequences of lysosomal proteolysis under conditions of partial starvation, but which vary according to functional differences between separate proteolytic pathways. These findings establish that the relative balance between proteolytic pathways is central to our understanding of different efficiencie 12989 as in energy requirements and conversion efficiency.
Author Keywords: Energy expenditure; Genotype; Growth efficiency; Net energy balance; Protein

Authors: Valenti Michael
Title: Putting power on ice
Authors with affiliations: Valenti, Michael
Abstract: Cogeneration plants are designed to maximize fuel efficiency by converting turbine exhaust into additional steam and/or electricity. These plants need to boost performance during the peak demand periods in the summer. However, gas-turbine output drops in the summer. PNNL researchers have found that refrigerative cooling, particularly when combined with off-peak chilling and storage, is the most effective inlet-air cooling technique. This method is now being used in pumped-storage hydroelectric systems, in which water is pumped into a reservoir at night to be released to generate power during the daytime.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Air conditioning; Compressors; Cooling; Energy efficiency; Evaporative cooling systems; Gas turbines; Heat storage; Ice; Industrial refrigeration; Power generation; Refrigerants; Absorption cooling; Inlet air cooling; Refrigerative cooling systems; Thermal storage; Cogeneration plants

Authors: Liu J., Liao C., Liu S., Xu W.
Title: The dynamics of direction-dependent switching in nonlinear chirped gratings
Affiliations: Institute of Quantum Electronics, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510631, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, J., Institute of Quantum Electronics, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510631, China; Liao, C., Institute of Quantum Electronics, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510631, China; Liu, S., Institute of Quantum Electronics, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510631, China; Xu, W., Institute of Quantum Electronics, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510631, China
Abstract: Nonlinear chirped gratings are numerically demonstrated to have a direction-dependent switching behavior. For the two incident directions, bistability exists with different switching-on powers, and the instable high transmissivity states have different critical powers. The direction-dependent bistability is due to the difference of the energy contained in the gratings for the two incident directions; the direction-dependent critical powers for instability origin from the different modulation instability threshold. Furthermore, it is first reported that for instable output there are spectral side lobes whose frequency shifts relative to carrier frequency have jumps at some input powers.
Index Keywords: Diffraction gratings; Electric field effects; Energy storage; Frequency shift keying; Numerical analysis; Optical bistability; Direction-dependent switching; Nonlinear chirped gratings; Optical switches

Authors: Brunger A.P., Hollands K.G.T., Anthony M.A., Zielonko D., Liang C.
Title: Performance penalties caused by thermal coupling in solar piping loops
Authors with affiliations: Brunger, A.P.; Hollands, K.G.T.; Anthony, M.A.; Zielonko, D.; Liang, C.
Abstract: Solar heating systems often employ conduits to carry cool fluid to the collector array and to carry the heated fluid back to the storage tank. In systems in which these two conduits are bundled together in one cover (in what has come to be known as the 'life-line') there is a thermal performance penalty caused by heat transfer from the hot conduit to the cold conduit. This cross heat transfer results in a penalty in system performance, and this paper is about evaluating this penalty. We show that the standard Hottel-Whillier-Bliss (HWB) equation can be modified to simultaneously take into account both the pipe heat losses to the ambient environment and the cross heat transfer between the hot and cold streams. Parameters in these equations are the thermal resistances between the fluids and between each fluid and the ambient. Methods are presented for both calculating and measuring these thermal resistances. We carry out sample calculations of the parameters in the modified HWB equation for a representative solar DHW system equipped with either of two different life-lines of commercial design. System simulations using these parameters reveal that the thermal effects of these life-lines are to reduce the net delivered solar energy by 6-14%, and that heat loss to the ambient is more detrimental to the system performance than heat transfer from the hot to the cold conduit.

Authors: Van Berkel J.
Title: Mixing in thermally stratified energy stores
Affiliations: Eindhoven University of Technology, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, WOC/WET, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Berkel, J., Eindhoven University of Technology, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, WOC/WET, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: Two important aspects of short-term thermally stratified energy storage, thermocline mixing and thermocline thickness, are studied analytically, experimentally and numerically. The storage detrimental aspects are investigated for a simplified configuration, i.e. an adiabatic box containing a quasi-stationary thermocline. Numerical finite difference/volume simulations agree well with experiments. The dissipation-free ID analytical model shows a large discrepancy. It appears that mixing inside thermally stratified stores is a two-stage process. First fluid is withdrawn from the thermocline by viscous drag. Subsequent mixing takes place by stretching and folding of fluid particles, thereby enabling diffusion to become active.

Authors: Chai P., Dudley R.
Title: Limits to flight energetics of hummingbirds hovering in hypodense and hypoxic gas mixtures
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Smithsonian Trop. Research Institute, PO Box 2072, Balboa, Panama
Authors with affiliations: Chai, P., Department of Zoology, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Dudley, R., Department of Zoology, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States, Smithsonian Trop. Research Institute, PO Box 2072, Balboa, Panama
Abstract: Hovering hummingbirds offer a model locomotor system for which analyses of both metabolism and flight mechanics are experimentally tractable. Because hummingbirds exhibit the highest mass-specific metabolic rates among vertebrates, maximum performance of hovering flight represents the upper limit of aerobic locomotion in vertebrates. This study evaluates the potential constraints of flight mechanics and oxygen availability on maximum flight performance. Hummingbird flight performance was manipulated non- invasively using air and gas mixtures which influenced metabolism via variable oxygen partial pressure and/or altered flight mechanics via variable air densities. Limits to the locomotor capacity of hovering ruby-throated hummingbirds (Archilochus colubris) were unequivocally indicated by aerodynamic failure in either air/helium or air/heliox mixtures. Air/helium mixtures are hypodense and hypoxic; failure to sustain hovering flight occurred at 63% of the density of sea-level air and at an oxygen concentration of 12%. Air/heliox mixtures are hypodense but normoxic; failure in hovering occurred at 47% of sea-level air density. Thus, hummingbirds demonstrated considerable power reserves in hovering flight as well as hypoxic tolerance. In air/helium mixtures, hovering was limited by oxygen supply and not by flight mechanics. Birds hovering in air/helium mixtures increased their mechanical power output but not their rate of oxygen consumption. By contrast, birds hovering in air/heliox mixtures increased both mechanical performance and metabolic expenditure. Under hypoxia, hovering hummingbirds demonstrated non-negligible, but still limited, capacities for anaerobic metabolism and/or oxygen storage. Depending on the physical context, hummingbird flight performance can therefore be limited by oxygen availability or by flight aerodynamics.
Author Keywords: air density; Archilochus colubris; heliox; helium; hovering flight; hummingbird; hypoxia; muscle power; oxygen consumption
Index Keywords: helium; oxygen; air; animal; bird; energy metabolism; flying; muscle; oxygen consumption; physiology; review; Air; Animals; Birds; Energy Metabolism; Flight, Animal; Helium; Muscles; Oxygen; Oxygen Consumption; Animalia; Archilochus colubris; Aves; Trochilidae; Vertebrata

Authors: Nemeth L.J., Paulley F.G., Preston K.R.
Title: Effects of ingredients and processing conditions on the frozen dough bread quality of a Canada Western Red Spring wheat flour during prolonged storage
Affiliations: Ready Bake Foods Inc., Mississauga, Ont., Canada; Canadian Grain Commission, Grain Research Laboratory, Winnipeg, MB R3C 3G8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Nemeth, L.J., Ready Bake Foods Inc., Mississauga, Ont., Canada; Paulley, F.G., Canadian Grain Commission, Grain Research Laboratory, Winnipeg, MB R3C 3G8, Canada; Preston, K.R., Canadian Grain Commission, Grain Research Laboratory, Winnipeg, MB R3C 3G8, Canada
Abstract: A laboratory scale no-time frozen dough procedure that approximates Canadian commercial practice has been developed and used to study the effects of ingredients and processing conditions on the bread quality of a straight grade Canada Western Red Spring (CWRS) wheat flour during prolonged storage (2 days to 26 weeks). All treatments (baking absorption level, mixing energy input, mixer type, fermentation and intermediate proof times, removal of oxidant and/or dough strengthening conditioners and partial freeze-thaw cycles) had significant effects (P≤0.05) upon bread quality (loaf volume and/or bread score). In general, these effects were more pronounced with extended frozen storage time. High baking absorption, undermixing, bulk fermentation (>1 h) and removal of oxidant and/or surfactants had the most dramatic effects. Addition of a very strong flour at 30% to strengthen the CWRS wheat flour had no significant effect (P≤0.05) upon bread quality under optimum conditions.
Author Keywords: baking; frozen dough; ingredients; processing conditions; wheat; wheat flour

Because with regard to influencing the product results this area assumes greater importance than the dryer and kiln.

Authors: Messer John, Miller Steve
Title: Boost circuit and energy storage capacitors prolong UPS battery life
Affiliations: Exide Electronics Group, Inc, Raleigh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Messer, John, Exide Electronics Group, Inc, Raleigh, United States; Miller, Steve, Exide Electronics Group, Inc, Raleigh, United States
Abstract: The CellSaver technology is a new concept that promises to prolong the battery life of uninterruptible power supply (UPS) systems via a two-pronged approach. The concept uses a boost regulator, a power factor correction circuit and storage capacitors to provide a wide alternating current input operating range. This approach prevents the UPS battery from being used unless the power line disturbance is greater than one cycle.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Computer control; Electric batteries; Electric current regulators; Electric inverters; Electric power factor correction; Battery life; Boost regulators; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Ficek Joseph
Title: Selection and sizing of storage tank water heaters
Affiliations: McGuire Engineers, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ficek, Joseph, McGuire Engineers, Chicago, United States
Abstract: Storage tank type water heaters are commonly used to generate hot water for commercial and institutional buildings. Storage type heaters are generally selected when the load profile has peaks that can be met from an adequate volume of water stored in the heater. Thus, the heater size and fuel/energy input are not based on the instantaneous peak load, permitting a more economical equipment selection. Storage heaters should be selected and sized based on the specific building requirements. Several factors need to be considered, including the type of facility served, the required water volume and load peaks, the type and number of fixtures served, the required water temperature, and the fuel/energy source for heating the water.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Heat exchangers; Hot water distribution systems; Storage (materials); Temperature control; Thermal expansion; Water tanks; Storage tank water heaters; Water temperature; Water heaters

Authors: Ryhanen V.
Title: Nuclear waste disposal - how to meet the concerns of the public
Affiliations: Posiva Oy, Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Ryhanen, V., Posiva Oy, Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: National laws and regulations and international recommendations on nuclear waste management has set the nuclear industry apart from other industries. Successful implementation of these laws require communication programs involving political decision-makers on the national and local levels, and the public and opinion-formers in general. The ultimate goal of these programs is to make the people understand that a final repository is needed for every country that uses nuclear energy so that the environment is protected from the hazardous effects of radioactive radiation.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Environmental protection; Geological repositories; Industrial management; Information dissemination; Laws and legislation; Radioactive waste disposal; Research and development management; Nuclear waste management; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Bentley Bill
Title: Basics of rechargeable battery management
Affiliations: Benchmarq Electronics, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bentley, Bill, Benchmarq Electronics, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Rechargeable batteries store energy when the applied voltage is higher than the discharge reaction. This process can be optimized by studying the different factors that influence a rechargeable battery's electrochemical behavior, such as temperature, charging current density, and electrical resistance of the battery electrolytes. Charging algorithms may also be used to prolong the life of rechargeable batteries.

Authors: Kellogg W., Nehrir M.H., Venkataramanan G., Gerez V.
Title: Optimal unit sizing for a hybrid wind/photovoltaic generating system
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kellogg, W., Department of Electrical Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Nehrir, M.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Venkataramanan, G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Gerez, V., Department of Electrical Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States
Abstract: The application of a hybrid wind/photovoltaic (PV) power generating system for utilization as a stand-alone or a network connected system is investigated. The optimum combination of wind and PV generation coupled with battery storage for a stand-alone system has been obtained for a hypothetical site in Montana. Generation and storage units for the hybrid system are properly sized in order to meet the annual load and minimize the total annual cost to the customer. The optimal solutions are found by a numerical study using the hourly load demand for a typical residential home in the Northwestern US. Hourly wind speed and approximate solar radiation data have been used. © 1996 Elsevier Science S.A.

Authors: Gomes J.
Title: Extreme value theory for a thermal energy storage model
Affiliations: Depto. Estat. Investigacao O., Universidade de Lisboa, Cidade Universitaria, Bloco C/2 Campo Grande, 1700 Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Gomes, J., Depto. Estat. Investigacao O., Universidade de Lisboa, Cidade Universitaria, Bloco C/2 Campo Grande, 1700 Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: A process to store solar energy to be used as thermal energy, with controlled input, may be represented by a stochastic process {Xn}, n = 0,1,2, ... with initial value X0 and a sequence of independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.) non-negative random variables, {Yi}, i ∈ ℕ, where Xn+1 = max(βXn, αβXn + Yn+1). 0 ≤ α < 1 e 0 < β < 1. Let X(β) be the stationary distribution of this Markov process for a fixed α. Our purpose is to generalize the results of Hooghiemstra and Greenwood (1988), who stated that X(β) - [log{1/(1 - β))/(1 - α)] has a limit law when {Yi} has an exponential distribution. When the Yi's, i ∈ ℕ, have a distribution with a tail like 1 - F(x) ∼ xθ exp(-xp) θ ∈ ℝ and p > 0, we shall show that X (β)/a(β) - c(β) converges to a non-degenerate random variable Xα, when β↑1, and calculate an approximation to the mean value of X(β) for β close to one.
Author Keywords: Domain attraction; Limit distribution

Authors: Wells J.C.K., Stanley M., Laidlaw A.S., Day J.M.E., Davies P.S.W.
Title: The relationship between components of infant energy expenditure and childhood body fatness
Affiliations: Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Queensland University of Technology, School of Human Movement Studies, Kelvin Grove Campus, Victoria Park Road, Locked Bag No 2, Red Hill, QLD 4059, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Wells, J.C.K., Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Stanley, M., Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Laidlaw, A.S., Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Day, J.M.E., Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Davies, P.S.W., Infant and Child Nutrition Group, Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downham's Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom, Queensland University of Technology, School of Human Movement Studies, Kelvin Grove Campus, Victoria Park Road, Locked Bag No 2, Red Hill, QLD 4059, Australia
Abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate whether any component of infant energy expenditure is related to fatness in early childhood, and whether infant fatness is related to childhood variables. DESIGN: Longitudinal investigation of infants studied at 12 weeks and followed up at 2.5 to 3.5 years of age. SUBJECTS: 30 healthy full-term infants selected from the general population. MEASUREMENTS: Sleeping metabolic rate, total energy expenditure, anthropometry and behaviour at 12 weeks; anthropometry, body composition and behaviour in follow-up. RESULTS: Energy expenditure an 12 weeks (minimal metabolism, total energy expenditure, energy expended on physical activity, behaviour) showed no relationship with later fatness. Infant fatness (skinfold thicknesses and percentage fat) showed in contrast a strong relationship with childhood fatness. Infant fatness also predicted childhood behaviour. CONCLUSIONS: These data do not support the theory that reduced energy expenditure in early infancy is related to later fatness. However, infant fatness influences both later fatness and activity patterns.
Author Keywords: Body composition; Minimal metabolism; Physical activity

Authors: Boyko E.J., Leonetti D.L., Bergstrom R.W., Newell-Morris L., Fujimoto W.Y.
Title: Visceral adiposity, fasting plasma insulin, and lipid and lipoprotein levels in Japanese Americans
Affiliations: Department of Medicine, University of Washington, School of Medicine, Seattle, WA, United States; Medical Service, Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Seattle, WA, United States; Department of Anthropology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Vet. Aff. Puget Sound Hlth. Care S., 1660 S. Columbian Way, Seattle, WA 98108, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boyko, E.J., Department of Medicine, University of Washington, School of Medicine, Seattle, WA, United States, Medical Service, Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Seattle, WA, United States, Vet. Aff. Puget Sound Hlth. Care S., 1660 S. Columbian Way, Seattle, WA 98108, United States; Leonetti, D.L., Department of Anthropology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Bergstrom, R.W., Department of Medicine, University of Washington, School of Medicine, Seattle, WA, United States; Newell-Morris, L., Department of Anthropology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Fujimoto, W.Y., Department of Medicine, University of Washington, School of Medicine, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the associations among visceral and subcutaneous adiposity, body-mass-index (BMI), fasting plasma insulin, lipid, and lipoprotein levels. DESIGN: Cross-sectional observational study. SUBJECTS: Non-diabetic second- (Nisei, n = 290) and third-generation (Sansei, n = 229) Japanese Americans. MEASUREMENTS: Intra-abdominal (IAF) and subcutaneous abdominal fat (SAF) area were measured using computed tomography. Fasting plasma insulin, lipid, and lipoprotein levels were measured using standard methods. RESULTS: Higher fasting insulin was significantly related to greater mean IAF and SAF area, plasma triglycerides, total HDL and HDL2 cholesterol in men and women of both generations. In a multiple linear regression analysis model among Nisei adjusted for gender, age, SAF, antihypertensive medication use, smoking, alcohol use, and exercise energy expenditure, IAF area and fasting insulin level were independently correlated with plasma triglycerides (IAF r = 0.22, fasting insulin r = 0.23), total HDL (IAF r = -0.29, fasting insulin r = -0.28), HDL2 (IAF r = -0.30, fasting insulin r= -0.27), and HDL3 cholesterol (IAF r = -0.19, fasting insulin r = -0.19). Among Sansei, similar associations were seen, except that fasting insulin was unrelated to total HDL or HDL2 cholesterol. These effects differed by gender in several instances. CONCLUSIONS: Both visceral adiposity and fasting insulin level are significantly and independently related to adverse levels of lipids and lipoproteins in both generations of nondiabetic Japanese Americans. The association between adverse lipid profile and visceral obesity is not mediated solely through detrimental effects of intra-abdominal fat deposition on fasting insulin level.
Author Keywords: Cholesterol; HDL-cholesterol; Insulin; Intra-abdominal fat; Japanese Americans; LDL-cholesterol
