Title: Design of the Ohio State University electric race car
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ., United States
Authors with affiliations: Grider, K., Ohio State Univ., United States; Rizzoni, G., Ohio State Univ., United States
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to document a three year process of product development of the Formula Lightningtm electric race car constructed at the Ohio State University. Today interest in electric vehicles (EV's) is growing, due to the technological advances in recent years, but also in part due to recent legislation which mandates the introduction of 'zero emission vehicles' in California before the end of the century. The definition of 'zero emission vehicle' is: a vehicle which does not emit any pollutants during operation. Technologically, the only near term vehicle which meets this definition is an EV. One of the most difficult problems of electric racing is that the usable energy in a given set of batteries is not as easily determined as the amount of fuel in a tank. Also, the motor controllers may limit power output as battery voltage drops, further decreasing the amount of usable energy in a battery set. Batteries have energy capacity which is a function of battery state of charge, time and battery life. This complex relationship makes the state of charge (SOC) of the battery pack a very difficult quantity to measure. In a vehicle, as the energy in the batteries is depleted, the battery bus voltage decreases to the controller minimum voltage. Determining the usable amount of energy in a given battery set is contingent upon knowing the history of the batteries, current draw, and a reasonable model of the batteries' charge and discharge characteristics. The energy storage problem is one of many which were overcome during the development of this vehicle. Many existing mature technologies, such as a manual transmission, were investigated as potential solutions to the new problems of electric vehicle development. A systems approach was taken to develop the vehicle as a set of coexisting subsystems. The success of the vehicle is a testament to the integration of these separate battery, motor, and mechanical systems. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Battery management systems; Charging (batteries); Electric automobiles; Electric discharges; Electric machine control; Fuel tanks; Integration testing; Racing automobiles; Traction motors; Vehicle transmissions; Battery state of charge; Charge and discharge; Complex relationships; Manual transmissions; Ohio State University; Technological advances; Vehicle development; Zero emission vehicles; Secondary batteries

Authors: Ross M., Wu W., Musser J., Walker F.
Title: A parallel hybrid automobile with less than 0.1 kWh of energy storage
Affiliations: University of Michigan, United States; Knusaga Corp., United States
Authors with affiliations: Ross, M., University of Michigan, United States; Wu, W., University of Michigan, United States; Musser, J., Knusaga Corp., United States; Walker, F., Knusaga Corp., United States
Abstract: The paper describes a new hybrid vehicle design option having very low energy storage capability, and in particular, a parallel hybrid with hydraulic storage and reapplication of braking energy. The operating efficiency of the propulsion system at light loads is substantially improved by splitting the engine into two segments, and finding ways of shutting down one or both engine segments whenever possible. The hybrid vehicle utilizes primarily current technologies. A diesel powered parallel hybrid as described demonstrates a reduction in fuel consumption of 53.9% on a volume basis when compared with an equivalent baseline vehicle. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Engines; Fuel consumption; Propulsion; Baseline vehicle; Braking energy; Current technology; Light loads; Operating efficiency; Parallel hybrids; Propulsion system; Vehicle design; Hybrid vehicles

Authors: Wang H., Lu Q., Wu P.
Title: Research on hydraulic energy storage transmission system of city bus
Affiliations: Jilin University of Technology, China; Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H., Jilin University of Technology, China; Lu, Q., Jilin University of Technology, China; Wu, P., Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Abstract: In View of the performance of high output torque moment, good response and continuously variable transmission of hydrostatic transmission, a new concept of Hydraulic Energy Storage Transmission System (HESTS) of city bus was put forward, although the hydraulic-mechanical split power hybrid city bus had run effectively in some cities, such as Copenhagen, Stockholm and Berlin, etc.[1][2]. HESTS was comprised of a variable displacement pump, a variable displacement pump/motor unit, two accumulators and an Electrical Control Unit (ECU). The high pressure accumulator could be controlled to absorb braking energy in hydraulic energy and reuse the stored energy to restart the prime mover or accelerate the vehicle. HESTS could operate in seven modes while the ECU outputs different combined control signals to pump, pump/motor and directional valves. The mathematical model of a HESTS for a city bus was established. Computer simulations showed that the efficiency of the HESTS city bus was improved, and there were potentialities to construct a city bus fixed with HESTS. An experimental rig of HESTS was built in the Fluid Power Laboratory of Harbin Institute of Technology. Experiment according to a practical running cycle showed that the HESTS city bus performed the operation demands efficiency. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Electric power transmission; Energy storage; Hydrostatic pressure; Pumps; Trucks; Continuously variable transmission; Electrical control units; Harbin Institute of Technology; Hydraulic energy storage; Hydraulic mechanicals; Hydrostatic transmission; Transmission systems; Variable displacement; Hydraulic accumulators

Authors: Kim J.H., Hyman N.L.
Title: Clementine thermal design and verification testing: Quick, cheap, unusual, successful
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Kim, J.H., Naval Research Laboratory; Hyman, N.L., Naval Research Laboratory
Abstract: The thermal control subsystem design, analysis, and test-verification that made possible the successful Clementine moon-mapping mission was indeed formidable in many respects, with very high ratios of requirements-to-available resources and performance-to-cost/mass, exacerbated by an unyielding tight schedule. Environments, requirements, program restrictions, design highlights, and lessons learned are presented. Emphasis is given to the sensor-bench payload and its unusual thermal components: three types of heat pipes (variable conductance, fixed conductance, and diode), a thermal-energy-storage beryllium block, and a multitude of flexible conducting straps. A description of the thermal design verification test emphasizes its unconventionally and lessons learned. Despite adverse schedule and cost-cutting effects on test hardware, planning, and execution, test data made possible thermal model refinements and important hardware design changes. Flight temperatures of the operating imaging sensors demonstrated success. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, lnc.
Index Keywords: Citrus fruits; Digital storage; Hardware; Heat pipes; Heat storage; Hardware design; Imaging sensors; Mapping missions; Test verification; Thermal component; Thermal control; Types of heat pipes; Verification testing; Cost benefit analysis

Authors: Strehlau W., Leyrer J., Lox E.S., Kreuzer T., Hori M., Hoffmann M.
Title: New developments in lean NOx catalysis for gasoline fueled passenger cars in Europe
Affiliations: Degussa AG; Nippon Shokubai Ltd.; ICT Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Strehlau, W., Degussa AG; Leyrer, J., Degussa AG; Lox, E.S., Degussa AG; Kreuzer, T., Degussa AG; Hori, M., Nippon Shokubai Ltd.; Hoffmann, M., ICT Inc.
Abstract: ABSTRACT: There is an increasing interest in running gasoline fueled passenger cars lean of stoichiometric air to fuel (A/F) ratio to improve fuel economy. These types of engines will operate at lean A/F ratios during cruising at partial load and return to stoichiometric or even rich conditions when more power is required. The challenge for the engine and catalyst manufacturer is to develop a system which will combine the high activity rates of a state-of-the-art three way catalyst (TWC) with the ability to reduce nitrogen oxides (NOx) under excess of oxygen. The target is to achieve the future legislation limits (EURO III/IV) in the European Union. Recent developments in automotive pollution control catalysis have shown that the utilization of NOx adsorption materials is a suitable way for reduction of NOx emissions of gasoline fueled lean burn engines. However, the primary task for the implementation of this technology in the European market will be to improve the high temperature stability and to decrease the susceptibility to sulfur poisoning. The present paper outlines results of a recent research and development program to achieve nitrogen oxide reduction under lean burn gasoline engine conditions. Model gas test results as well as engine bench data are used for discussion of the parameters which control NOx adsorption efficiency under various conditions. It is shown that the NOx adsorption technology enables an efficient removal of NOx up to 85% over a wide temperature range even at high NO x inlet concentrations. The major part of the paper is dedicated to the problem of sulfur poisoning under laboratory and engine operation conditions. The relationship between the uptake of poisons such as sulfur and phosphorus and the activity results is reported. It is demonstrated that relatively small amounts of adsorbed sulfur might cause a severe overproportional suppression of NOx storage activity. Regarding this, fundamental studies using various physicochemical and spectroscopic methods such as BET-surface area measurements, energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX), inductive coupled plasma (ICP) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) were performed to elucidate the nature of sulfur deposition on the NOx storage catalyst. Some evidence exists that at short time-on-stream the SO3 reacts preferably with the NOx adsorbents by forming surface sulfate species which block off the active sites of the adsorbents for further NO x adsorption. However, by treating the, sulfur poisoned NO x storage catalysts with hydrogen the equivalent activity of the fresh catalyst can be restored. The results obtained by thermogravimetrical analyses coupled to a mass spectrometer (TG-MS) show that high concentrations of hydrogen bring about high levels of H2S and little SO2 whereas low concentrations of hydrogen preferably lead to increased SO 2 emissions at expense of H2S. Another subject reported in detail is the progress made recently concerning improved sulfur tolerance of the technology by applying a sulfur trap mounted upstream to the NOx storage catalyst. The concept of the sulfur trap provides the periodical adsorption of SO3 whenever the exhaust is adjusted lean and the decomposition and emission of the sulfur as SO2 when the engine management provides the rich spikes. One target was to avoid the generation of H2S during the rich periods. Aided by the utilization of ion molecular reaction mass spectroscopy (IMR-MS) the general ability of the sulfur trap to function could be confirmed at different engine operating points and temperature levels. It is demonstrated that in the presence of sulfur a significant improvement in NOx activity retention by additionally applying the sulfur trap is feasible. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Automobile manufacture; Catalysis; Catalyst activity; Digital storage; Energy dispersive X ray analysis; Exhaust gases; Fuel economy; Gasoline; Hydrogen storage; Ion engines; Mass spectrometry; Pollution control; Spectrometers; Spectroscopic analysis; Sulfur compounds; X rays; BET surface area measurement; Catalyst manufacturers; Energy dispersive x-ray analysis (EDX); High temperature stability; Inductive coupled plasma; Lean burn gasoline engine; Nitrogen oxide reduction; Wide temperature ranges; Nitrogen oxides

Authors: Driscoll C.
Title: A new approach to remote powering
Affiliations: SatCon Tech Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Driscoll, C., SatCon Tech Corp.
Abstract: There are several existing and emerging alternatives to lead acid batteries to provide backup energy storage for remote powering applications. These alternatives include generator sets, flywheel systems, turbine alternators, fuel cells, and superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES). Flywheels offer dramatic improvements in performance, require little maintainance, are environmentally friendly in reliability, maintenance, lifetime, and cost over these energy storage technologies. High strength fiber composites, high efficiency electric drives, and frictionless magnetic bearings along with the declining size and cost of electronics have made these advanced flywheels. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Electric drives; Flywheels; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Lead acid batteries; Magnetic storage; Rotors; Superconducting magnets; Wheels; Energy storage technologies; Flywheel systems; Generator sets; High-efficiency; High-strength fibers; New approaches; Superconducting magnetic energy storages; Turbine-alternator; Electric energy storage

Authors: Wang H., Zhang Y., Xu Y., Wu P.
Title: Research on novel pump/motor displacement-varying mechanism controlled with high-speed on-off valve
Affiliations: Jilin University of Technology, China; Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H., Jilin University of Technology, China; Zhang, Y., Harbin Institute of Technology, China; Xu, Y., Harbin Institute of Technology, China; Wu, P., Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Abstract: A low cost, anti-pollution pump/motor displacement-varying mechanism was studied in this paper. In the hydrostatic energy storage transmission system(HESTS), a variable pump (motor) unit was used to transfer the energy. A new pump/motor displacement-varying mechanism was obtained based on low price manual manipulating variable pump with high-speed on-off solenoid valves supporting pressure oil. Simulation results showed that the position precision and the ability of following sinusoidal wave signal of the new mechanism met the requirement of the pump/motor unit. Experiment results proved that the new pump/motor displacement-varying mechanism operated precisely and reliably. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Automotive engineering; High Speed; High speed on-off valve; Low costs; New mechanisms; New pumps; Position precision; Sinusoidal wave; Transmission systems; Solenoid valves

Authors: Busse D.T., Braun C.G.
Title: Sensitivity analysis of hybrid electric vehicle designs
Affiliations: Colorado School of Mines, United States
Authors with affiliations: Busse, D.T., Colorado School of Mines, United States; Braun, C.G., Colorado School of Mines, United States
Abstract: In hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) design and operation, no parameter plays a more important role than efficiency. Unlike conventional vehicles, HEVs are generally energy and power limited by the battery bank and auxiliary power unit. As a result, the overall system efficiency in the conversion of chemical or stored energy into kinetic energy of the vehicle is the key parameter that drives the overall system design. We have undertaken a sensitivity analysis of HEVs to understand in detail the various factors and their respective weights that affect the overall system efficiency. Our goal is to identify the parameters that most significantly influence vehicle efficiency. The results of this study may be used as a guide to focus work on the areas of most benefit for HEVs as well as aiding in sizing vehicle components for maximum efficiency. The simulation tool used is SIMPLEV 3.1 developed by the DOE Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, which runs a time-based simulation on a set of parameter files for an (hybrid) electric vehicle. To accomplish this sensitivity analysis we have written a set of programs that conduct a parametric analysis of the vehicle parameters by creating the necessary sets of SlMPLEV input files. It then runs these SIMPLEV files on a standard test cycle and extracts out the results of the simulation. Using the data this generated, we were able to establish the relative importance of each system parameter. This paper discusses the assumptions within the SIMPLEV model, the development of input files and the parametric programs, and the test cycle chosen. The results of this sensitivity analysis are also presented and analyzed. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers Inc.
Index Keywords: Chemical analysis; Digital storage; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Laboratories; Sensitivity analysis; Auxiliary power units; Design and operations; Hybrid electric vehicle (HEV); Idaho National Engineering Laboratory; Maximum Efficiency; Parametric -analysis; Vehicle components; Vehicle parameters; Hybrid vehicles

Authors: Wang H., Wu P.
Title: Design and laboratory test of the hydrostatic energy storage transmission system
Affiliations: Jilin University of Technology, China; Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H., Jilin University of Technology, China; Wu, P., Harbin Institute of Technology, China
Abstract: A Hydrostatic Energy Storage Transmission System(HESTS) designed for vehicle is presented in this paper. A bench-scale HESTS was built in the Fluid Power and Control Laboratory of Harbin Institute of Technology. The laboratory testing HESTS was powered by a DC. motor which was controlled by a Silicon-Controlled Rectifier(SCR). Loads adding to the HESTS were regulated by a proportional valve control system. The HESTS is more complex because there are not only continuous variables-the shaft speed of the hydraulic axial piston variable displacement pump/motor unit and the position of the displacement-varying cylinder, but also discrete variables-the on/off states of clutch, 2/2 solenoid valve and 2/4 solenoid valve in the HESTS to be controlled. So a fuzzy logic controller with a mode selector is designed to perform the role of control to the HESTS. A personal computer stored control rules executes the tasks of data acquisition, fuzzy logic inference and control. Experimental results show that the HESTS had high efficiency and the control strategy was effective. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Computer circuits; Data acquisition; Digital storage; Electric power transmission; Energy storage; Fuzzy logic; Hydraulics; Off road vehicles; Personal computers; Shaft displacement; Solenoids; Vehicle transmissions; Continuous variables; Discrete variables; Fuzzy logic controllers; Fuzzy logic inference; Harbin Institute of Technology; Proportional valves; Transmission systems; Variable displacement; Solenoid valves

Authors: Oei D.-G.
Title: Direct hydrogen-fueled proton-exchange-membrane (PEM) fuel cell for transportation, part 2
Affiliations: Ford Motor Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Oei, D.-G., Ford Motor Co, United States
Abstract: A fuel cell (FC) powerplant is an electrochemical engine that converts fuel and an oxidant electrochemically into electric energy, water and other chemical byproducts. When hydrogen is used as the fuel, the only products of the electrochemical reactions are water and electric power. Other conventional and advanced powerplants for transportation, such as the internal combustion (IC) engine, the Diesel engine and others, are thermal combustion engines. The theoretical or thermodynamic efficiency of a fuel cell or electrochemical engine is much higher than the thermodynamic efficiency of a heat engine. The practical efficiency of a fuel cell is highest at partial load, whereas the practical efficiency of a heat engine is highest at maximum power. A survey is presented of the different fuel cell types and their characteristics. The proton-exchange-membrane (PEM) fuel cell is shown to be the best available fuel cell for transportation applications. Using hydrogen for its fuel, the PEM fuel cell powerplant is a true zero emission vehicle (ZEV) engine. Onboard compressed hydrogen storage will be discussed and other options of hydrogen generation are considered and analyzed. The results of design packaging studies for the fuel cell power system and the associated fuel storage and supply in a small vehicle, a mid-size vehicle and in a van will be presented. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers Inc.
Index Keywords: Byproducts; Combustion; Diesel engines; Hydrogen production; Hydrogen storage; Vehicles; Chemical byproducts; Compressed hydrogens; Electrochemical reactions; Fuel cell power systems; Hydrogen generations; Internal combustion; Thermodynamic efficiency; Zero emission vehicles; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC)

Authors: Butler R., McElroy J., Smith W.
Title: SPE® electrolysis for current and future space applications
Affiliations: Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Butler, R., Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corp.; McElroy, J., Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corp.; Smith, W., Hamilton Standard Division of United Technologies Corp.
Abstract: Recent advances in SPE® electrochemical systems have addressed risk areas identified early in the space station program and now support applications that can provide significant potential benefit to ISS in the areas of life support, propulsion and energy storage. Advanced high-pressure systems now under development for navy and aircraft applications can generate oxygen at pressures up to 2000 psi (13.8 MPa) with no moving parts on the oxygen side of the generating system. Zero gravity static phase separators have been developed and are being tested in component and system tests. Cyclic operation of complete systems has been demonstrated. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Fighter aircraft; Life support systems (spacecraft); Oxygen; Space applications; Space stations; Aircraft applications; Complete system; Cyclic operation; Electrochemical systems; Generating system; High pressure system; Potential benefits; Space station programs; Application programs

Authors: Ender M., Dietrich P.
Title: Duty cycle operation as a possibility to enhance the fuel economy of an SI engine at part load
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Ender, M., Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Switzerland; Dietrich, P., Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Switzerland
Abstract: The potential of Duty Cycle Operation (DCO) of a Spark Ignited (SI) engine on part load has been investigated. DCO keeps an engine running at full throttle in a stop and go mode to speed up a flywheel as a short time energy storage device. So the actual power demand is covered by the flywheel instead of the convenient direct power transfer from the engine. This work includes the calculation of the theoretical potential and preliminary results of a test setup. The results show a clear advantage of fuel consumption at the engine's low power output. The potential of DCO has proved to be higher than that of variable intake valve timing. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Energy transfer; Flywheels; Wheels; Direct power transfer; Duty cycle operations; Power demands; Short-time energy; SI Engines; Spark-ignited engines; Stop-and-go; Test setups; Fuel economy

Authors: Kowalczyk R.J., Shepard Jr. W.L., Smith J.M., Williams R.G.
Title: Efficiency considerations in the GM impact electric vehicle: Ride. Handling, and steering function
Affiliations: Delphi Chassis Systems; GM Electric Vehicles; Delphi Saginaw Steering Systems; Sachs Automotive of America
Authors with affiliations: Kowalczyk, R.J., Delphi Chassis Systems; Shepard Jr., W.L., GM Electric Vehicles; Smith, J.M., Delphi Saginaw Steering Systems; Williams, R.G., Sachs Automotive of America
Abstract: The design of a practical battery powered vehicle must feature efficiency in every system, in order to provide maximum range given limited on-board energy storage. As GM's impact electric vehicle was designed exclusively for battery power, priority consideration of efficiency was given to the design of every function in the vehicle. This paper addresses such considerations in one of the major functions of the chassis system: ride, handling, and steering. The ride, handling, and steering function is a major player in the efficiency of Impact. It includes such energy dissipaters as tire rolling resistance, component deformations or accelerations due to road surface irregularities, suspension viscous damping, and energy requirements of power assisted controls. Also factors in design efficiency are limited packaging envelopes associated with a highly aerodynamic body, and last but not least, mass efficiency of the chassis components. These factors were all considered in an effort to develop innovative chassis systems contributing to vehicle efficiency while providing pleasible ride, handling, and steering to the customer. The results of this effort are chassis systems which contribute significantly to unprecedented total vehicle efficiency, while providing remarkably contemporary ride, handling, and steering pleasibility. This has been achieved through innovations in system electro-mechanical design and mechanization, component materials selection, and simultaneous engineering practices used by the GM Electric Vehicles team and its key suppliers. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Automobile steering equipment; Chassis; Electric vehicles; Machinery; Magnetic levitation vehicles; Secondary batteries; Chassis components; Component materials; Electro mechanical design; Energy requirements; On-board energy storage; Road surface irregularities; Steering functions; Vehicle efficiency; Steering

Authors: Roberts C.A., Rushbrook M.A.
Title: Ride, handling and overall chassis development of GM impact electric vehicle
Affiliations: Lotus Engrg.; Delphi Chassis Systems
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, C.A., Lotus Engrg.; Rushbrook, M.A., Delphi Chassis Systems
Abstract: With limited on-board energy storage, the GM Impact Electric Vehicle design focused on highly efficient systems to provide maximum range. Recognizing the need for this pioneering product to exhibit a high level of ride, handling and refinement, the chassis development team blended analysis, objective testing and subjective evaluation. The development program was structured to assist the integration of all chassis-related systems, from tires to seats. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Electric vehicles; Subjective testing; Development programs; Development teams; Maximum ranges; On-board energy storage; Related systems; Subjective evaluations; Chassis

Authors: Aceves S.M., Ray Smith J., John Perkins L., Haney S.W., Flowers D.L.
Title: Optimization of a CNG series hybrid concept vehicle
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States
Authors with affiliations: Aceves, S.M., Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States; Ray Smith, J., Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States; John Perkins, L., Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States; Haney, S.W., Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States; Flowers, D.L., Lawrence Livermore National Lab., United States
Abstract: Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) has favorable characteristics as a vehicular fuel, in terms of fuel economy as well as emissions Using CNG as a fuel in a series hybrid vehicle has the potential of resulting in very high fuel economy (between 26 and 30 km/liter, 60 to 70 mpg) and very low emissions (substantially lower than Federal Tier II or CARB ULEV) This paper uses a vehicle evaluation code and an optimizer to find a set of vehicle parameters that result in optimum vehicle fuel economy The vehicle evaluation code used in this analysis estimates vehicle power train performance, including engine efficiency and power, generator efficiency, energy storage device efficiency and state-of-charge, and motor and transmission efficiencies Eight vehicle parameters are selected as free variables for the optimization The optimum vehicle must also meet three performance requirements accelerate to 97 km/h in less than 10 s, climb an infinitely long hill with a 6% slope at 97 km/h with a 272 kg (600 lb) payload, and have a 610 km (380 mile) range in the combined urban/highway driving cycle The optimizer used in this work was originally developed in the magnetic fusion energy program, and has been used to optimize complex systems, such as magnetic and inertial fusion devices, neutron sources, and rail guns The optimizer consists of two parts an optimization package for minimizing non-linear functions of many variables subject to several nonlinear equality and/or inequality constraints and a programmable shell that allows interactive configuration and execution of the optimizer The results of the analysis indicate that the CNG senes hybrid vehicle has a high fuel economy and low emissions These results emphasize the advantages of CNG as a near-term alternative fuel for vehicles © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Alternative fuels; Battery management systems; Compressed natural gas; Constraint theory; Fuel economy; Functions; Gas emissions; Gas fuel analysis; Gas fuel storage; Magnetic levitation vehicles; Magnetic storage; Natural gas vehicles; Neutron sources; Rail guns; Seats; Vehicle transmissions; Compressed natural gasses (CNG); Inequality constraint; Magnetic fusion energy; Optimization packages; Performance requirements; Series hybrid vehicles; Transmission efficiency; Vehicle fuel economy; Hybrid vehicles

Authors: Song Y.K., Park S.H., Han C.-S., Lee K.-S.
Title: Development of an automotive thermal energy storage unit (I: Preliminary study)
Affiliations: Korea Automotive Technology Institute, South Korea; Mando Machinery, Inc.; Hanyang Univ., South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Song, Y.K., Korea Automotive Technology Institute, South Korea; Park, S.H., Korea Automotive Technology Institute, South Korea; Han, C.-S., Mando Machinery, Inc.; Lee, K.-S., Hanyang Univ., South Korea
Abstract: A preliminary study was conducted to develop an automotive thermal energy storage unit for reduction in emissions and for increase in occupants comfort in winter. To prevent thermal storage performance degradation of the thermal storage media some additives were mixed with the base material Bariumhydroxide-octahydrated(Ba(OH)2·8H2O), and offers promising degradation-resist characteristics. The thermal energy storage unit was then optimally designed based on parameter study and empirical analysis. A comparison was made with a commercially available heat battery. Peak power of the developed thermal energy storage unit was about three times higher than that of the existing one. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Barium compounds; Heat storage; Thermal energy; Base material; Empirical analysis; Parameter studies; Peak power; Thermal storage; Thermal storage performance; Storage (materials)

Authors: Washburn G.A., Delcambre L.M.L., Whiting M.A.
Title: Reuse of high-level information requests: Leveraging the investment
Source title: Proceedings - 8th International Conference on Scientific and Statistical Data Base Management, SSDBM 1996
Affiliations: Professional Services, DSS Sequent Computer Systems, Beaverton, OR  97006, United States; Computer Science and Engineering, Oregon Graduate Institute, Portland, OR  97291, United States; Information Technology Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA  99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Washburn, G.A., Professional Services, DSS Sequent Computer Systems, Beaverton, OR  97006, United States; Delcambre, L.M.L., Computer Science and Engineering, Oregon Graduate Institute, Portland, OR  97291, United States; Whiting, M.A., Information Technology Department, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA  99352, United States
Abstract: Vertical information management (VIM) is a term coined to describe a particular set of information management activities. These activities support decision makers working within various levels of a management hierarchy, who seek information from potentially large, distributed heterogeneous, and federated information sources. Decision makers usually require information beyond what is stored. Yet, the collected data is a valuable resource. This as particularly important for scientific experimental results where the samples are expensive to collect and analyze, as in environmental remediation and restoration. One sample from a storage tank containing nuclear waste can cost over $1000000. A fundamental assumption of the work is that high-level information requests may involve data that is extracted or derived from underlying information sources, as well as data that is not present in the underlying information sources (referred to as "gaps"). The authors observe that current practice often involves manual processing and negotiation to select relevant information and to fill gaps. They present a VIM framework for the specification, refinement, and partitioning of a high-level information request resulting in the extraction, collection, aggregation, and abstraction of the underlying data. This framework captures the specification of the information and the summarization steps used in a highly manual process to leverage the investment against future information requests. The work has been supported, in part, by the Department of Energy's Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. © 1996 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Data mining; Digital storage; Information management; Investments; Specifications; Statistics; Current practices; Department of Energy; Environmental remediation; High-level information; Information request; Information sources; Manual processing; Pacific northwest national laboratories; Decision making

Authors: Nishimoto Y., Tobase T., Hori M., Sawada T.
Title: In-situ chamber tests for underground Compressed-Air Storage facilities
Affiliations: Electric Power Development Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; New Energy Foundation, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishimoto, Y., Electric Power Development Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Tobase, T., Electric Power Development Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Hori, M., Electric Power Development Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Sawada, T., New Energy Foundation, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Significant efforts are being made in Japan to study power generation systems using Compressed-Air Energy Storage Gas Turbines (CAES-G/T). Split-lining structure was applied for the airtight lining of the underground compressed air storage cavern, to assure the safety and economic efficiency of pressurized air storage under the various geological conditions. In-situ tests were performed in actual caverns, to verify the design of splitlining structure in practice. This paper sums up the in-situ test procedures and results and compares the theoretical analysis with the measurement data for the tested structures. © 1996 Balkema, Rotterdam.

Authors: Howell J.P.
Title: Durability of aluminum-clad spent nuclear fuels in wet basin storage
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, SC  29808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howell, J.P., Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, SC  29808, United States
Abstract: Large quantities of Defense related spent nuclear fuels are being stored in water basins around the United States. Under the non-proliferation policy, there has been no processing since the late 1980's and these fuels are caught in the pipeline awaiting processing or other disposition. At the Savannah River Site, over 200 metric tons of aluminum clad fuel are being stored in four water filled basins. Some of this fuel has experienced significant pitting corrosion. An intensive effort is underway at SRS to understand the corrosion problems and to improve the basin storage conditions for extended storage requirements. Significant improvements have been accomplished during 1993-1995, but the ultimate solution is to remove the fuel from the basins and to process it to a more stable form using existing and proven technology. Other methods, like dry storage are viable, but they will require development over several years. This paper presents a discussion of the fundamentals of aluminum alloy corrosion as it pertains to the wet storage of spent nuclear fuel. It examines the effects of variables on corrosion in the storage environment and presents the results of corrosion surveillance testing activities at SRS, as well as discussions of fuel storage basins at other production sites of the Department of Energy. © 1996 by NACE International.
Author Keywords: Aluminum-clad; Pitting corrosion; Savannah River Site; Spent Nuclear Fuel
Index Keywords: Aluminum alloys; Aluminum corrosion; Fuels; Nuclear fuel cladding; Pipeline processing systems; Pitting; Spent fuels; Aluminum alloy corrosion; Corrosion problems; Department of Energy; Non-proliferation; Savannah River sites; Spent nuclear fuels; Storage condition; Storage requirements; Fuel storage

Authors: Lee H.S., Lee H.-K., Park Y.-J., Kwon K.-S.
Title: The mechanical and hydraulic characteristics of granite and gneiss under temperature variation
Affiliations: Department of Mineral and Petroleum Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea; Korea Institute of Geology, Mining and Materials (KIGAM), Taejon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.S., Department of Mineral and Petroleum Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea; Lee, H.-K., Department of Mineral and Petroleum Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea; Park, Y.-J., Korea Institute of Geology, Mining and Materials (KIGAM), Taejon, South Korea; Kwon, K.-S., Korea Institute of Geology, Mining and Materials (KIGAM), Taejon, South Korea
Abstract: Most underground engineering projects, including the safe disposal of radioactive wastes, geothermal energy production, underground oil storage and heat storage in rock cavern, require knowledge of the mechanical, thermal, hydraulic characteristics of rockmass. This paper describes the results of various tests conducted on Whangdeung granite and Gyounggyi gneiss to understand the mechanical behaviors of rock under temperature variation. The effect of the anisotropy caused by the rift and foliation of the rocks, and the hydraulic characteristics of the rocks and artificially fractured joints were also studied at different temperatures. The results could be used in the design of various underground facilities. © 1996 Balkema, Rotterdam.
Index Keywords: Geothermal energy; Granite; Heat storage; Temperature distribution; Thermal Engineering; Waste disposal; Fractured joints; Hydraulic characteristic; Mechanical behavior; Oil storage; Rock cavern; Safe disposals; Temperature variation; Underground engineering; Buoyancy

Authors: Patchkovskii S., Thiel W.
Title: Analytical second derivatives of the energy in MNDO methods
Affiliations: Organisch-chemisches Institut, Universität Zürich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zürich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Patchkovskii, S., Organisch-chemisches Institut, Universität Zürich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zürich, Switzerland; Thiel, W., Organisch-chemisches Institut, Universität Zürich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zürich, Switzerland
Abstract: Analytical second derivatives of the energy are derived and efficiently implemented for semiempirical MNDO-type methods including AM1, PM3, and MNDO/d. A new algorithm for the simultaneous solution of several CPHF equations is proposed in which the amount of memory required is independent of the number of iterations. The analytical approach is faster than the numerical approach typically by a factor of 5 and exhibits a reliable convergence over a wide range of molecules. The asymptotic memory and secondary storage requirements of the reported procedure can be as low as O(N2) without significant degradation of the performance. © 1996 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
Index Keywords: Chemistry; Analytical approach; Number of iterations; Numerical approaches; Reliable convergence; Second derivatives; Secondary storage; Semiempirical MNDO; Simultaneous solution; Computational chemistry

Authors: Oyama J., Xia X., Higuchi T., Kuroki K., Yamada E., Koga T.
Title: VVVF On-line Control of Matrix Converter
Affiliations: Nagasaki University, Japan; Toyo Electric Manufacturing Co.,Ltd., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oyama, J., Nagasaki University, Japan; Xia, X., Nagasaki University, Japan; Higuchi, T., Nagasaki University, Japan; Kuroki, K., Nagasaki University, Japan; Yamada, E., Nagasaki University, Japan; Koga, T., Toyo Electric Manufacturing Co.,Ltd., Japan
Abstract: A matrix converter doesn't have any energy storage components, so it is smaller than a converter-inverter system with same KVA. Though matrix converter requires 18 switching devices instead of 12, each device capacity is 0.383 times and total capacity is 0.575 times that of the converter-inverter system. For the matrix converter, we proposed a firing sequence which eliminated voltage and current spikes in switching operations, and control method I which generated the output voltage of 0.866 times the supply voltage. Moreover, we proposed control method II which improved the waveform distortion of the input current and realized unity input power factor. In this paper, we propose a new VVVF gate circuit based on control method II for matrix converter, which can on-line control input current waveform and output voltage waveform to sinusoidal even if there are fluctuation, asymmetry and/or harmonics in the supply voltage. We also confirm by experiments that the waveform distortion of the input current and the input power factor were greatly improved. © 1996, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wajima T., Kawashima K., Yamashita T.
Title: A Strategy Analysis of the Fast Breeder Reactor Introduction and Nuclear Fuel Cycle Systems Deployment
Source title: Nippon Genshiryoku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Nuclear Power Systems Div., Hitachi Ltd., United States; Power/Industrial Systems R & D Div., Hitachi Ltd., United States; power Group, Hitachi Ltd., United States
Authors with affiliations: Wajima, T., Nuclear Power Systems Div., Hitachi Ltd., United States; Kawashima, K., Power/Industrial Systems R & D Div., Hitachi Ltd., United States; Yamashita, T., power Group, Hitachi Ltd., United States
Abstract: A study is made on a strategy analysis of the long term nuclear fuel cycle systems deployment in accordance with the nuclear power growth projection and fast breeder reactor (FBR) introduction. In the analysis, the reprocessed plutonium (Pu) is charged into the reactor in such a way that the reprocessed Pu is not stored outside the reactor, i.e., there is no excess Pu outside the reactor. The analysis characterized the fuel cycle systems, and showed the usefulness of the present method to determine future directions for the FBR introduction and nuclear fuel cycle systems deployment. Concerning an intermediate-term strategy, the time of introduction and required capacities of a second commercial LWR reprocessing plant, Pu-thermal, and the first FBR reprocessing plant deployment are evaluated. A long term strategy analysis shows that the two or three large plants are run in parallel for each fuel cycle facility and that FBR related facilities deal with a markedly large amount of Pu. It is concluded that the early stage introduction of FBRs of significant capacities seems necessary to materialize a consistent total FBR/fuel cycle system where Pu balance becomes feasible through its flexible operation of, for instance, adjusting breeding ratio, in order to keep the transparency of the Pu utilization. © 1996, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: FBR type reactors; fuel cycle system; long term nuclear strategy analysis; nuclear power growth projection; plutonium balance; plutonium utilization; plutoniumthermal; spent fuel reprocessing plants; spent fuel storage; uranium resources

Authors: Zauhar R.J., Varnek A.
Title: A fast and space-efficient boundary element method for computing electrostatic and hydration effects in large molecules
Affiliations: Tripos, Inc., 1699 S. Hanley Road, St. Louis, MO 63144, United States; Department of Chemistry, University of Strasbourg, 4 Rue Blaise Pascal, Strasbourg, France
Authors with affiliations: Zauhar, R.J., Tripos, Inc., 1699 S. Hanley Road, St. Louis, MO 63144, United States; Varnek, A., Department of Chemistry, University of Strasbourg, 4 Rue Blaise Pascal, Strasbourg, France
Abstract: At present, there are two widely used approaches for computing molecular hydration and electrostatic effects within the continuum approximation: the finite difference method, in which the electric potential is directly computed on a cubic grid, and the induced polarization charge or boundary element method, in which an induced charge distribution is first computed on the molecular surface and in which solvation effects are then calculated by reference to the reaction field arising from this induced surface charge. While the induced surface charge approach has a number of advantages over finite differences, especially in the computation of hydration forces and solvent stabilization, the applications of this technique have been largely restricted to small molecules. This is primarily due to the very large system of equations that results when the surface of a macromolecule is discretized into elements small enough to ensure an acceptable level of numerical accuracy within the continuum model. This article describes a new algorithm for implementing boundary element calculations within the continuum model. The essence of our approach is only to compute explicitly those interactions between surface elements that are relatively close together and to approximate long-range interactions by grid-based multipole expansion. The resulting system of equations has a relatively sparse coefficient matrix and requires disk storage that increases linearly with molecular surface area. The technique has numerous applications in the analysis of solvation effects in large molecules, especially in the area of conformational analysis, where it is critical to accurately estimate the global hydration energy for the entire structure. © 1996 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Authors: Luchini C., Wynne P., Hudson M.K.
Title: Investigation of GAT as a high regression rate hybrid motor fuel
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, University of Arkansas at Little Rock, Little Rock, AR  72204, United States; NASA JPL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Luchini, C., Department of Applied Science, University of Arkansas at Little Rock, Little Rock, AR  72204, United States, NASA JPL, United States; Wynne, P., Department of Applied Science, University of Arkansas at Little Rock, Little Rock, AR  72204, United States; Hudson, M.K., Department of Applied Science, University of Arkansas at Little Rock, Little Rock, AR  72204, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this investigation was to find a high regression rate fuel suitable for use as a mixture with HTPB. Guanidinium Azo-Tetrazolate (GAT) is the compound which is the focus of our research. GAT is an organic salt consisting of a high percentage of nitrogen. It has two conjugated nitrogen rings which are negatively charged, and a positively charge component consisting of nitrogen, carbon, and hydrogen. In addition to the high energy content of this compound, as a salt, it has a lower heat of degradation due to the ease of breaking its ionic bonds. GAT was found to react with N100, a common curative for HTPB. An alternative isocyanate curative was found. PAPI. with which it did not react. This polymer matrix was found to be suitable for GAT. The resulting fuel grains were difficult to cast due to the rapid polymerization of the HTPB'PAPI. Once grains were cast, they required no special care in storage or firing. Initial data indicates that GAT is indeed a highly regressing fuel. This data was obtained at only a 15% by mass concentration of GAT in the fuel grains, with the exception of one 20% GAT grain which regressed fast enough that a pressure spike cause a safety shutdown of our labscale rocket. © 1996, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Automotive fuels; Carbon; Digital storage; Nitrogen; Propulsion; Rockets; Energy content; Hybrid motors; Mass concentration; Negatively charged; Organic salt; Pressure spike; Rapid polymerization; Regression rate; Fuels

Authors: Cady E.C., Olsen A.D.
Title: Cryogen storage and propellant feed system for the integrated solar upper stage (Isus) program
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Advanced Propulsion Technologies, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cady, E.C., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Advanced Propulsion Technologies, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States; Olsen, A.D., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Advanced Propulsion Technologies, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States
Abstract: The Integrated Solar Upper Stage (ISUS) is a high performance bimodal upper stage capable of transferring payloads from low earth orbit (LEO) to geostationary equatorial orbit (GEO) in 30 days and then providing electrical power for the payload in the final orbit. The ISUS can nearly double the GEO payload of expendable launch vehicles (ELVs) compared to chemical (O2/H2) transfer stages. This allows downsizing of ELVs for a given payload (e.g., launching Titan IV payloads on a Delta III/ISUS) at significant cost savings of up to $150 million per launch. In addition, ISUS enables GEO payloads to be launched by single-stage-to- orbit (SSTO) vehicles, which currently have no GEO- transfer-orbit (GTO) capability. The ISUS uses large concentrators to focus sunlight on a high temperature receiver. The receiver heats hydrogen to 2500K and expels it from a nozzle for thrust (1-10 lb) at high Isp (800-1000 sec). The fuel is stored as subcritical liquid hydrogen (LH2). The ISUS is autonomously guided through approximately 240 bums (orbits) on its 30 day transfer mission from LEO to GEO. After insertion in the final orbit, the ISUS switches to a power production mode with thermal energy transported to thermionic elements that convert heat to electrical power for the satellite payload. The ISUS concept requires that a number of technologies be matured prior to undertaking full development. These technologies include the concentrator, the receiver and thermionic elements, and the LH2 storage/feed system. The USAF Phillips Lab will develop these technologies concurrently during the engine ground demonstration (EGD) test to be conducted in a large vacuum chamber at the NASA Lewis Research Center (LeRC). This paper describes the design and expected performance of the ISUS Cryogen Storage and Propellant Feed System (CSPFS) to be used in the EGD. The CSPFS must provide efficient storage of the LH2 over the 30 day mission duration, while providing propellant as required by the receiver/absorber/ concentrator (RAC) in low-gravity and at the proper conditions. The LH2 tank is multilayer-insulated to restrict tank pressure excursions during coast. It uses a zero-g thermodynamic vent system (TVS) integrated with a screen liquid acquisition device (LAD). The TVS subcools the LAD flow thus eliminating a pressurization system for the tank. Additionally, an active TVS consisting of a pump and compact heat exchanger will be used to remove additional heat from the tank and thereby maintain better tank pressure control. All of the vent flow from the TVS is used in the engine, none is vented overboard. © 1996 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Aerospace vehicles; Chromium compounds; Concentration (process); Engines; Geostationary satellites; Hydrogen; Hydrogen fuels; Liquefied gases; NASA; Propellants; Propulsion; Tanks (containers); Compact heat exchanger; Expendable launch vehicles; Ground demonstrations; Liquid acquisition devices (LAD); Low earth orbit(LEO); Pressurization system; Single stage to orbit vehicles; Thermodynamic vent systems; Orbits

Authors: Miles B.J., Kerr J.M.
Title: Coatings for high temperature graphite thermal energy storage in the integrated solar upper stage
Affiliations: Babcock and Wilcox, Naval Nuclear Fuel Division, Lynchburg, VA  24505-0785, United States; Nova Tech, Lynchburg, VA  24502, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miles, B.J., Babcock and Wilcox, Naval Nuclear Fuel Division, Lynchburg, VA  24505-0785, United States; Kerr, J.M., Nova Tech, Lynchburg, VA  24502, United States
Abstract: Key components within the Integrated Solar Upper Stage (ISUS) bimodal system must be able to operate at temperatures as high as 2500K within both hard vacuum and hot hydrogen environments. Graphite has been selected as the primary thermal energy storage device for initial ISUS system level and engine ground demonstration testing. The selection of graphite has dictated the need for development and testing of high temperature coatings to determine which can maintain structural integrity at elevated temperatures, be compatible with graphite, and mitigate carbon loss from the graphite known to occur from exposure to high temperature vacuum and hydrogen environments. This paper presents the methodology which led to selection of CVD rhenium as the coating material. Initial results from vacuum and hydrogen flow tests conducted between 2000K and 2600K on rhenium coated graphite coupons indicate mass loss reductions as much as one order of magnitude lower than unprotected graphite under similar temperatures, pressures, hydrogen flowrates, and exposure durations. The durability of rhenium coatings 0.015” thick was also demonstrated as the rhenium maintained its structural integrity throughout testing. © 1996 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Coatings; Durability; Heat storage; Hydrogen; Propulsion; Rhenium; Solar power generation; Structural integrity; Thermal energy; Coating material; Development and testing; Elevated temperature; Exposure durations; Ground demonstrations; High temperature; High temperature coatings; Rhenium coatings; Graphite

Authors: Meckel N.J., Hoskins W.A., Cassady R.J., Myers R.M., Oleson S.R., McGuire M.
Title: Improved pulsed plasma thruster systems for satellite propulsion
Affiliations: Olin Aerospace Company, Redmond, WA  98073, United States; NYMA, Inc, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; Analex Corp, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meckel, N.J., Olin Aerospace Company, Redmond, WA  98073, United States; Hoskins, W.A., Olin Aerospace Company, Redmond, WA  98073, United States; Cassady, R.J., Olin Aerospace Company, Redmond, WA  98073, United States; Myers, R.M., NYMA, Inc, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; Oleson, S.R., NYMA, Inc, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; McGuire, M., Analex Corp, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Abstract: Pulsed Plasma Thruster (PPT) systems are enjoying renewed interest for a variety of mission applications. The renewal is primarily driven by the large growth in LEO small satellite designs that can make effective use of the unique characteristics of the PPT. NASA LeRC and Olin Aerospace are working together to develop improved PPT systems for these applications. NASA has established ambitious goals for the improved PPT: a system mass reduction of a factor of two while delivering increased thrust and total impulse. PPT design improvement activities have focused on these goals. To allow test of several design parameters, OAC designed and built a breadboard PPT thruster. The thruster is modular in construction allowing quick, easy changes from one configuration to the next. A series of configuration tests have been completed including changes to the electrodes, energy storage capacitor energy, and fuel bar geometries. Mission application studies have been performed for both primary AV propulsion and attitude control functions. PPTs have been examined for orbit raising and acquisition of small satellites, constellation stationkeeping, drag make-up, and attitude control options including momentum wheel replacement. Missions examined include the AF MightySat, New Millennium Interferometer, NASA SMEX and MIDEX concepts, and commercial LEO constellations. Details of the results of these mission studies are discussed and examples of mass, cost, and reliability trades with conventional ACS are given. © 1996, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Attitude control; Fuel storage; NASA; Orbits; Plasma devices; Propulsion; Satellites; Spacecraft propulsion; Application studies; Control functions; Design improvements; Design parameters; Energy storage capacitor; LEO Constellation; Satellite propulsion; Small satellite design; Pulsed plasma thrusters

Authors: Kumar R.R., Seywald H.
Title: High-resolution trajectory refinement via hodograph ballooning
Source title: 1996 Guidance, Navigation, and Control Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: Analytical Mechanics Associates, Inc, 17 Research Drive, Hampton, VA  23666, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, R.R., Analytical Mechanics Associates, Inc, 17 Research Drive, Hampton, VA  23666, United States; Seywald, H., Analytical Mechanics Associates, Inc, 17 Research Drive, Hampton, VA  23666, United States
Abstract: Solutions to optimal control problems obtained via direct methods are usually of low resolution. As the desired resolution becomes higher, the number of parameters in the resulting parameter optimization problem increases nonlinearly. A concatenated approach to trajectory optimization previously introduced by the authors to obtain high resolution optimal solutions with low storage requirements is applicable only to a specific class of problems, such as minimum time and minimum energy optimal control problems. The hodograph ballooning approach introduced in this paper generalizes the concatenated approach to the most general optimal control problem. © 1996 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Direct approach; High resolution; Low memory requirement; Trajectory optimization

Authors: Crosa G., Pittaloga F., Martinengo A.T., Beltrami F., Torelli A., Traverso F.
Title: Heavy-duty gas turbine plant aerothermodynamic simulation using Simulink
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: Universita' di Genova, Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi Energetici, Italy; Ansaldo Energia, Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Crosa, G., Universita' di Genova, Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi Energetici, Italy; Pittaloga, F., Universita' di Genova, Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi Energetici, Italy; Martinengo, A.T., Universita' di Genova, Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi Energetici, Italy; Beltrami, F., Ansaldo Energia, Genova, Italy; Torelli, A., Ansaldo Energia, Genova, Italy; Traverso, F., Ansaldo Energia, Genova, Italy
Abstract: This paper presents a physical simulator for predicting the off-design and dynamic behaviour of a single shaft heavy-duty gas turbine plant, suitable for gas-steam combined cycles. The mathematical model, which is non linear and based on the lumped parameter approach, is described by a set of firstorder differential and algebraic equations. The plant components are described adding to their steady state characteristics the dynamic equations of mass, momentum and energy balances. The state variables are mass flow rates, static pressures, static temperatures of the fluid, wall temperatures and shaft rotational speed. The analysis has been applied to a 65 MW heavy-duty gas turbine plant with two off-board silo-type combustion chambers. To model the compressor, equipped with variable inlet guide vanes, a subdivision into five partial compressors is adopted, in serial arrangement, separated by dynamic blocks. The turbine is described using a one dimensional row by row mathematical model, that takes into account both the air bleed cooling effect and the mass storage among the stages. The simulation model considers also the air bleed transformations from the compressor down to the turbine. Both combustion chambers have been modelled utilising a sequence of several sub-volumes, to simulate primary and secondary zones in presence of three hybrid burners. A code has been created in Simulink environment Some dynamic responses of the simulated plant, equipped with a proportional-integral speed regulator, are presented.
Index Keywords: Combustion chambers; Compressors; Dynamic response; Gas turbines; Thermodynamics; Two term control systems; First-order differentials; Gas steam combined cycles; Heavy-duty gas turbines; Physical simulator; Proportional integral; SIMULINK environment; Static temperature; Steady state characteristics; Turbine components

Authors: Totmšič M.G., Perović O.
Title: Sizing of a gas turbine for repowering of cogeneration power plant Ljubljana by mathematical optimisation
Source title: ASME 1996 International Gas Turbine and Aeroengine Congress and Exhibition, GT 1996
Affiliations: Jožef Stefan Institute, Energy Efficiency Centre, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Totmšič, M.G., Jožef Stefan Institute, Energy Efficiency Centre, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Perović, O., Jožef Stefan Institute, Energy Efficiency Centre, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: The paper deals with optimal sizing of a gas turbine for repowering of cogeneration power plant Ljubljana considering possible plant operational strategy with respect to variations of electric and heat loads and energy costs. CHP plant is a main source' for the Ljubljana town district heating system. Existing plant consists of two condensing steam turbines with steam extraction, back pressure turbine with steam extraction, auxiliary steam and hot water boilers for peak heat load production. This system delivers up to Ill MW into the power grid and up to 348 MW of heat. Repowering with gas turbine generator set with additionally fired heat recovery boiler is considered. For uncoupling heat and power generation a heat storage tank is assumed. For sizing of new equipment and plant operational strategy a model based on mixed-integer linear programming was developed. Zero-one integer variables are adopted to indicate the on/off status of operation, continuous variables to indicate the operational level of each constituent equipment and an optimal solution is derived by branch and bound method. Two prospective sizes of TO sets were tested for range of assumptions regarding power purchase tariff schedules. Different optimal operation policies resulted. The study provides background for contract negotiation and for investment decisions. Copyright © 1996 by ASME.

Authors: Utamura M., Ishikawa A., Nishimura Y., Ando N.
Title: Economics of gas turbine inlet air cooling system for power enhancement
Source title: ASME 1996 International Gas Turbine and Aeroengine Congress and Exhibition, GT 1996
Affiliations: Thermal Power Plant Engineering Department, Hitachi Works, Hitachi, Ltd., Saiwai-cho 3-1-1, Hitachi City, 317, Japan; Electric Power Research and Development Center, Chubu Electric Power Company Incorporated, Kitasekiyama 20-1, Ohdaka-cho Midori-ku Nagoya, 459, Japan; Engineering Department, Chubu Area Operation, Hitachi, Ltd., Sakae 3-1 7-12, Naka-ku Nagoya, 460, Japan; Power Group, Thermal Power Engineering Div., Gas Turbine and Combined Cycle Project Domestic, 6, Kanda-Surugadai 4-chome, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, 101, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Utamura, M., Thermal Power Plant Engineering Department, Hitachi Works, Hitachi, Ltd., Saiwai-cho 3-1-1, Hitachi City, 317, Japan; Ishikawa, A., Electric Power Research and Development Center, Chubu Electric Power Company Incorporated, Kitasekiyama 20-1, Ohdaka-cho Midori-ku Nagoya, 459, Japan; Nishimura, Y., Engineering Department, Chubu Area Operation, Hitachi, Ltd., Sakae 3-1 7-12, Naka-ku Nagoya, 460, Japan; Ando, N., Power Group, Thermal Power Engineering Div., Gas Turbine and Combined Cycle Project Domestic, 6, Kanda-Surugadai 4-chome, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo, 101, Japan
Abstract: A cost estimate method is presented, which enables to compareinlet air cooling system for power enhancement of combustion turbine with other power generation system. A new energy conversion index is developed which arranges system design parameters in a dimensionless form and also exhibits running cost. It is suggested that the inlet air cooling system is equivalent to simple cycle or pumped storage in view of the dimensionless running cost. Next, a cost diagram relating capital cost to power generation cost is presented also in non-dimensional form, which could provide a measure to examine investment worth for a power producer. Moreover, cooling effectiveness as function of cooled inlet air temperature is investigated using specific thermal energy. It is revealed that cooling beyond dew point requires a larger thermal energy per electric energy produced and thus less economical unless the price of electricity depends on electricity demand. Copyright © 1998 by ASME.

Authors: Vestli K., Ziegler E.
Title: Optimization of multilayer reflectivity and bandpass for soft to hard x‐ray applications [0.1–200 keV]
Affiliations: European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BP 220, F‐38043 Grenoble Cedex, France; Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Institutt For Fysikk, N 7034 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Vestli, K., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BP 220, F‐38043 Grenoble Cedex, France, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Institutt For Fysikk, N 7034 Trondheim, Norway; Ziegler, E., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, BP 220, F‐38043 Grenoble Cedex, France, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Institutt For Fysikk, N 7034 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: In the last decades, the major motivation for manufacturing multilayer mirrors has been in soft x‐ray applications, particularly for astronomy, microlithography, and polarimetry. The advent of high energy synchrotron storage rings has provided a new significant impetus emphasizing high energy applications and especially when flux, rather than resolution, is desired. In this paper we present the reflection properties of the most promising multilayer material combinations for the energy range from 0.1 keV up to 200 keV. Previous calculations by Rosenbluth were limited to a maximum of 2 keV and to multilayers composed of pure elements and operating under normal incidence. As alloys might be essential for a smooth growth and/or for stability under high heat load, our screening consisted of a list of up to 300 solids having a melting point above 100°C and that could be deposited in a sputtering process. A full computer search calculates 45000 multilayer combinations for each angle (or multilayer d‐spacing) and energy of operation, the only necessary input variables. Other manufacture‐related parameters can be specified to give a more realistic picture of the performance. As the number of layers is often limited, a nonperiodic design could minimize absorption effects. © 1996, American Institute of Physics. All rights reserved.

Authors: De Witt Huberts P.K.A.
Title: Intermediate-energy hadronic physics with the AmPS-NIKHEF facility
Source title: Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics
Affiliations: Natl. Inst. Nucl. Phys. High-E., P.O. Box 41882, 1009 DB Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: De Witt Huberts, P.K.A., Natl. Inst. Nucl. Phys. High-E., P.O. Box 41882, 1009 DB Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: We report on recent experimental results obtained at the Amsterdam (700-900) MEV Pulse Stretcher and Storage ring (AmPS) at NIKHEF: high-momentum components in few-body (2H,4He) and heavy-systems (208Pb); and two proton correlations from the (ee′pp) reaction on 16O. We discuss spin asymmetries measured with a tensor polarized deuterium target and a 100 mA beam stored in AmPS.

Authors: Mesić I., Krištofek B., Babić T.
Title: Geothermal energy resources in the republic of Croatia-over pressured zone
Affiliations: INA-Nalbplin, Šubićeva 29, HR-1OOOO Zagreb, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Mesić, I., INA-Nalbplin, Šubićeva 29, HR-1OOOO Zagreb, Croatia; Krištofek, B., INA-Nalbplin, Šubićeva 29, HR-1OOOO Zagreb, Croatia; Babić, T., INA-Nalbplin, Šubićeva 29, HR-1OOOO Zagreb, Croatia
Abstract: The great quantities of stared heat, at relatively shallow depths, enable us to perform two fundamental human activities. suitable for an industrially clean country. The first one is agriculture throughout the whole year and the second one is tourism with the considerable potential for health resorts. Besides the subsurface and subsurface and surface hydropotentional, there is also good geothermal energy present, especially in the western and central part of the Drava Basin.
